projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p:
POEMS, viz.
1. A PANEGYRICK to the KING.
2. SONGS and SONNETS.
3. The BLIND LADY, a COMEDY.
4. The Fourth Book of VIRGIL,
5. STATIUS his ACHILLEIS, with ANNOTATIONS.
6. A PANEGYRICK to GENERALL MONCK. By the Honorable Sr ROBERT HOWARD.
LONDON, Printed for Henry Herringman, and are to be old at his hop at the ign of the Anchor on the lower Walk of the New Exchange. 1660.

div.head: TO THE READER.
div.p: IT has been the uuall cutom of Epitles, to give the Reader an account of the caues that brought thoe writings into publick, that were onely intended for a private Cloet; and commonly it has been at the requet of friends, perhaps with mingled truth and deigne, to prae-engage the judgments of many, by telling the opinion of ome, o to preerve their modety as much in the pretence, as they could have done in the concealment of their Writings.

Though I cannot pretend uch a caue as this, I can yet free my elf from that vanity that others would avoid, by auring the Reader, I had not tock of confidence enough to hew thee things privately to many friends, much lee to be furnih'd with enough, to make them publick to all
indifferent perons, had not the deires of the Book-eller prevail'd with me: to whoe civilities I believ'd my elf o far engag'd, as to deny him nothing that he thought a kindnee, which could not be everely prejudiciall to my elf: Yet I doubted not, but that I hould receive the cenures of many; which, upon the granted principle of prejudice, appear'd not a reaonable argument to prevail with me to deny his requet, ince the ame hould as well perwade me not to live, for life and converation r • nder man in Print more than letters can do; and is made more publick by that way, than he can be by this. His life is mingled more with his defects and paions, than probably his writings are; and whether they are equall, or exceed others, need not trouble him that writes: He may be atisfied, the production of retir'd hours are the bet of himelf. I had no great reaon then to deny his requet, that imagin'd he ask'd his own advantage, when he deired nothing that I believed contrary to mine.

Yet I wih that it may o far give atisfaction to all, that they may as little repent the r • ading, as I did the writing; whilt in thee gentle tudies I found a diverion from greater follies; and by that comparion they received obliging natures. Perhaps, there's few that read them, may
not as well be concious to themelves, to have pent ome time not o <> ; and for that caue forgive that, which for its own ake they cannot admire.

For the everall ubjects which here make one bundle, there is not any of them that have not layn by me thee many years (two or three copies of Veres onely excepted); and had been wholly perhaps laid aide, but for the reaons given, applying my elf now to more erious tudies, according to the everall eaons of encreaing age, as the earth produces various fruits to the different eaons of the year. By this hort account of time, the Reader may dicern in what clowdy days my Mue pread her wings, as little contributing to her flying a noble heighth, as to hew a jut ubject: He that mot deerv'd it was mot deni'd it (as he was indeed his right in all things) either from private fear, or publick power, though I equall not the crime of faint thoughts in paive ubmiion, to the guilt of bold profeion in publick action. 'Tis now to be hop'd, that the praies of our Prince, who o much merits it, may be received willingly by all, ince nothing can be aid of him, that has not been done by him; and man's larget invention has been excell'd by His actions, there being nothing capable • o
make him appear more excellent than himelf; unlee it had been our want of him, when by experience we found his mieries were ours, and all that we inflicted on him returned in double meaures on our elves; l • ke tones madly tot into the air, and forc'd from their proper center, that fall back with encreas'd weight upon their heads that flung them. We are now preented that in him, which this world paringly produces; in one compoure, an object for our Conciences and Interet, in whoe preervation, our Temporall and Eternall tates have equall hares. Yet I hould a little be disatisfied with my elf to appear publick in his praie, jut when he was viibly retoring to power, did not the reading of the Panegyrick vindicate the writing of it, and, beides my affirmation, aure the Reader, It was written when the King deerved the Praie as much as now, but eparated farther from the Power; which was about three years ince, when I was Prioner in Windor-Castle, being the bet diverion I could then find for my own condition; to think, how great his Vertues were for whom I uffered, though in o mall a meaure compar'd to his own, that I rather bluh at it, than believe it meritorious.

For the other Veres and Songs, I mut profee
they were never directed to any particular Beauty, which may (to the Amorous Reader at leat) be a jut excue, if they want Perfection, to remember I wanted Paion, and had onely my own warmth, unaited by the influence of a Mitree. Nor hall I envy him that writes better, by being much in love, if he mut purchae the advantage of Wit by the loe of Freedom.

For the Tranlations, the Authors have already received thoe Characters from the world, that they need none of mine, epecially Virgil, of whoe works I have onely publih'd this one Book, that lay finihed by me; not judging it convenient to perfect thoe other Books of his Aeneid's, which I have rudely gone through, having long ince laid aide all deignes of that nature; and this little of it rather grew publick from accident, than deigne, the Mingle it had with my private Papers, was the greatet caue, that it received its hare in the publick Impreion.

For Statius, he had received commendations enough, had he been alone commended by Juvenal in his 7 Satyr. but Alexand. ab Alex. alo, lib. 6 ch. 14. relates, that he thrice received the Victor's Lawrell in the publick reading of his Veres, and was once vanquih'd; as unjutly
perhaps as Agelli lib. 17. ch. 4. Menander was judged to be overcome by Philemon, whoe faction was greater, though his wit lee; inomuch that meeting him afterwards, Menander deired him to confee ingenuouly, if he did not bluh when he vanquih'd him. For this piece of his, I confee I choe it as mot pleaing to me, I wih it may be o to the Reader; though there wants not
<> in unâ Achilleide ita urgit ut illic multo ublimi • s ferri v • deatur, quam quó potuerit toto • hebaide perveniter Demit. ingenious men, who preferr'd it before his other Poems. The Annotations may in ome places perhaps be judged too large; yet, had I omitted any thing, it is probable that the ame perons would have cenur'd me for ignorance: o that being equally enible of thee extreams, I judg'd it the tetimony of the greatet modety, By omitting little, to hew my elf not at all ecure in the world's opinion.

I have thus, ingenuous Reader, given you a clear and true account of my Self and Writings, not oppret with apprehenion, nor rais'd by neglect; but preerv'd by an indifferency, that detroys not my civilitie to others, nor my own content; deiring not to engroe, but hare atisfaction. If in any thing I jutly need, or deigne to ask pardon, 'tis for Errors that probably the
Reader may meet with; having been reduc'd to the trait of neglecting this, or buinee. I confee my Interet prevail'd with me though, not wholly to neglect the Reader, ince I prevail'd with a worthy Friend to take o much view of my blotted Copies, as to free me from groe Errors. Having thus et down all my deigne and reaons, I leave the Reader with as little Concern to ue his, as I have hewed him mine.

div.head: To my Honored Friend, Sr ROBERT HOWARD, On his Excellent Poems.

lg.l: AS there is Muick uninform'd by Art
In thoe wild Notes, which with a merry heart
The Birds in unfrequented hades expree,
Who better taught at home, yet pleae us lee:
So in your Vere, a native weetnee dwells,
Which hames-Compoure, and its Art excells.
Singing, no more can your oft numbers grace
Then Paint adds charms unto a beauteous Face.
Yet as when mighty Rivers gently creep,
Their even calmnee does uppoe them deep,
Such is your Mue: no Metaphor well'd high
With dangerous boldnee lifts her to the sky;
Thoe mounting Fancies when they fall again,
Shew and and dirt at bottom do remain.
So firm a trength, and yet with all o weet,
Did never but in Sampon's Riddle meet.
'Tis trange each line o great a weight hould bear,
And yet no igne of toil, no weat appear.
Either your Arthides Art, as Stoicks feign
Then leat to feel, when mot they uffer pain;
And we, dull ouls, admire, but cannot ee
What hidden prings within the Engine be:
Or 'tis ome happinee that till purues
Each act and motion of your gracefull mue.
Or is it Fortune's work, that in your bead
The curious Rete Mirabile. Net that is for fancies pread,
Let's through its Mehes every meaner thought,
While rich Idea's there are onely caught.
Sure that's not all; this is a piece too fair
To be the child of Chance, and not of Care.
No Atoms caually together hurl'd
Could e're produce o beautifull a world.
Nor dare I uch a doctrine here admit,
As would detroy the providence of wit.
'Tis your strong Genius then which does not feel
Thoe weights would make a weaker pirit reel:
To carry weight and run o lightly too
Is what alone your Pegaus can do.
Great Hercules himelf could ne're do more
Than not to feel thoe Heav'ns and gods he bore.
Your eaier Odes; which for de • ight were penn'd,
Yet our instruction make their • cond end,
We're both enrich'd and pleas'd, like them that woo
At once a Beauty and a Fortune too.
Of Morall Knowledge Poeie was Queen,
And till he might, had wanton wits not been;
VVho like ill Guardians liv'd themelves at large,
And not content with that, debauch'd their charge:
Like ome brave Captain, your uccesfull Pen
Retores the Exil'd to her Crown again;
And gives us hope, that having een the days
VVhen nothing flourih'd but Fanatique Bays,
All wi • l at length in this opinion ret,
"A ober Prince's Government is bet.
This is not all; your Art the way has found
To make improvement of the richet ground,
That oil which thoe immortall Lawrells bore,
That once the acred Maro's temples wore
Elia's griefs, are o expret by you,
They are too eloquent to have been true.
Had he o poke, Aeneas had obey'd
VVhat Dido rather then what Jove had aid.
If funerall Rites can give a Ghost repoe,
Your Mue o jutly has dicharged thoe.
Elia's hade may now its wandring ceae,
And claim a title to the fields of peace.
But if Aeneas be oblig'd, no lee
Your kindnee great Achilles doth confee,
VVho dres • d by Statius in too bold a look,
Did ill become thoe Virgin's Robes he took.
To undertand how much we owe to you,
VVe mut your Numbers with your Author's view;
Then we hall ee his work was lamely rough,
Each figure tiffe as if deign'd in buffe;
His colours laid o thick on every place,
As onely hew'd the paint, but hid the face:
But as in Perpective we Beauties ee;
VVhich in the Glae, not in the Picture be;
So here our ight obligeingly mitakes
That wealth which his your bounty onely makes.
Thus vulgar dihes are by Cooks disguis'd,
More for their dreing than their ubtance priz'd.
Your curious Annotations on Statius. Notes o earch into that Age,
VVhen all was fable but the acred Page,
That ince in that dark night we needs mut tray,
VVe are at leat miled in pleaant way.
But what we mot admire, your Vere no lee
The Prophet than the Poet doth confee.
Ere our weak eyes dicern'd the doubtfull treak
Of light, you aw great Charls his morning break.
So skilfull Sea-men ken the Land from far,
VVhich hews like mists to the dul Paenger.
To Charls your Mue firt pays her dutious love,
As till the Antients did begin from Jove.
VVith Monck you end, whoe name preerv'd hall be,
As Rome recorded Hic itus et Rufus qui pulo vindice quondam, Imperium aeruit non fibi ed Patriae. Rufus memory,
VVho thought it greater honor to obey
His Countrey's interet than the world to way.
But to write worthy things of worthy men
Is the peculiar talent of your Pen:
Yet let me take your Mantle up, and I
VVill venture in your right to prophey.
"This VVork by merit firt of Fame ecure
"Is likewie happy in its Geniture:
"For ince 'tis born when Charls acends the Throne,
"It hares at once his Fortune and its own.
THE true Parnaus (Sir) which Mues know,
Are Subjects which they chooe; to whom they owe
Their Inpirations, differing as the times,
Unhappy Vertues, or uccesfull Crimes.
The greatet Choyce is, where the mot Succee
Makes Fears as great, nor their Ambitions lee.
With the Uurped Crowns they trive for Bays;
Thoe readier not to Act than Thee to Praie.
My Mue (Great Sir) has no uch fears, or knows
A better Impiration than your Woes.
To ing thoe Vertues which are all your own,
But by the malice of the world withtood:
So much 'tis eaier to be Great than Good.
Which knows no end, or change by human things,
But like the world (Eternall) whence it prings.
Greatnes is, as forbidden Pleaures are,
Reach'd by th'impious hands, that will but dare
Attempt all Crimes, till corning a retreat:
Onely the Bad can be unjutly Great.
By Falls from Thrones, uch, and the vertuous know
What Fate to them, or they to Fortune owe.
By courage nor by vertue can be taid
Fortune, which tired grows by lending aid.
So, when all Thrones on Caear were betow'd,
Not Fate to him, but he to Fortune ow'd,
And paid her back the vatet Principall
She ever lent, in his too-wretched Fall;
To whoe uccesfull Courage once he gave
The Rome, call'd by Livie, Totius Orbis D • minatri • . Mitres of the World to be his Slave.
To fair days, torms ucceed; to torms, the fair:
We know but what we are by what we were.
And Mans condition's valu'd more or lee,
By what he had, not what he does poee.
For no Extreams could ever gain a Height
From their own natures, but each other's weight.

So
—Sed longi poenas Fortuna favoris
Exigit a miero, quae tanto pondere famae
Res premit adveras, fatique prioribus urget.
Lucan. Phar. lib. 8.
Lucan made the flying Pompey blame,
Not preent Woes, but his too-early Fame.

Great Hannibal, in his excellent Speech to Scipio between their Armies, then ready to fight, et down by Livie; among other motives to Scipio for peace, by his own example, advies him to be ecure from the Ingratitude of his Country; which afterwards was too largely evident by their reducing him to Privacy as great as his former Glories, and render'd themelves unworthy of his Ahes, which to this day lie in an unknown Grave. Scipio, whoe too happy courage made
His Country free, and Hannibal's enlay'd,
Had been more happy, had he been but lee,
And not fear'd want of glory, but excee.
Whoe Countrie-men's ungrateful fears were more,
For his uccee, than Hannibal's before.
So much Plebeian Souls from Nature's School,
Are fitted more for Servitude than Rule.
Would uch Examples had been onely known;
But we have felt a greater of our own,
In your Great Father een; whoe Sunhine-days
Deerves not more our wonder than our praie:
Nor did his days of Tempets lee proclaim,
But taught us more of Miracle and Fame.
And equal'd all the mieries it brought;
By vertues, which unequal'd ufferings taught.
Frailty affliction brings; and yet a friend,
In giving thoe afflictions too an end.
Yet immortality can no bleing give,
But make that perfect, which mut ever live.
His oul, refin'd o by Celetiall heat,
One could not hurt; and t'other ha's made great.
He pay'd his cores of Frailty, and of Joy's,
To live, where nothing that's enjoy'd detroy's.
And ell, let this frail World like Heaven might be,
At once admitting Him, and Contancy.
Happy were we, had we but undertood,
None were too great, nor we out elves too good!
Within our elves, and by our elves confin'd:
One by our Ocean; t'other by our Mind.
Whilt the obliged World, by War unought,
Was willingly by gentler Traffick brought.
Secure and Rich; whilt every welling Tide,
That brought us afety, brought us Wealth beide
Above the reach of the World's power grown,
And had been afe, had we but fear'd our owne.
What the Grave Spaniard, and the Belgian too,
The active French, by power could not do,
Our paions did; and quickly made it known,
We could be Conquered by our elves alone.
And acting that which others could not do,
Are now fit for their Scorn, and Conquet too.
How jut, and ure Heaven's revenges are!
We lighted peace; and grow depi'd by War.
Like Mad men then, poet with Lunacy;
We now mut find a Cure in miery.
And by our uffering, to our wits redeem'd,
Our long-lot peacefull temper grows eteem'd.
For man does mot, by the Comparative,
At the true knowledge of Extreams arrive.
And in affliction's ready to adore,
That which he hardly could indure before.
How fatally this Nation proves it true,
In mourning for our banih't Peace; and You!
To You, Great Sir, Fortune's in debt alone,
Who can be no way pai'd, but by your owne.
Your Vertues have not more made Crowns your due,
Than ufferings taught you how to ue them too.
Stroaks upon olid bodies do provoke
A ecret brightnee free, unmixt with moak:
No gronee mingled; but bright parks declare,
What mighty firmnee their Compoures are.
So whilt the troaks of Fortune on You light,
Your mighty frame appears more firm and bright.
Affliction often by its powerfull weight,
Is the Cae-hot of Detiny and Fate.
Routing faint principles together brought
By properous vertues; not by hazards taught.
Whilt the weak man is too much undertood,
His frailty more, than his ubtantiall good.
As in the low declining of the day,
Mens haddows more enlarged hew, than they;
So in the worlds great, lat, adverity,
When every Element their power mut try;
To diolution they mut all retire,
And leave but one pure Element of fire.
All that was groe, which from weak nature flows,
In your great trialls, o expiring hows.
And all unto your Nobler Soul reign'd,
Nothing eems l • fe in you, but what's refin'd.
No longer, now, ubject to what is frail,
But have from Nature, cut off the entail.
Nor yet could Fortune with her pow't or frowns,
Ravih your Father's Veroues, though his Crowns;
So little was th' eteem of human things,
To that once bet, and now mot blet, of Kings.
One that in all his time, was never known,
Greedy of Lives, though weary of his own.
Peace Crown'd his thoughts, though not his wretched time,
His Nature was his fate, his Crown his crime:
Depi'd by his own people, firt; becaue,
He toop't below his power, and their laws.
His eaie gifts eem'd all but debts; when they,
Had nothing left to ask, nor he to pay.
Yet that he might unjut, or mean, appear,
For what his nature gave, they thank't his fear.
All the fair vertues of his Halcyon-times
Intead of gratitude contracted crimes
In thoe, who from the fears he ever had,
Of being ill, took boldnee to be bad.
Such as on peace, the name of [idle] fling,
And make their Prince a Tyrant or no King;
So fell that Prince, too good for uch bad times,
By his own Vertues, and by others Crimes.
Now againt you, Great Sir, their words are turn'd,
And joy in what the VVorld beides has mourn'd.
Still contant in their Crimes and Cruelty,
All Concience turn'd into Neceity.
Which by the view of acted ins before,
Does afe appear, onely by doing more:
As thoe who quit firm hores, when the wind raves,
Mut not retire, but butle till in waves.
The wandring Needle o can never tay,
Till it finds out the Point it hould obey.
Our Contitution toucht by Monarchy,
Till it rets there, mut always wandring bee;
And that mut fix in You: None could convay
True light, but He that ought to rule the day.
VVhen Phaeton did to that heighth apire,
He brought not influence to the world, but fire:
So thoe led by Ambition to your Throne,
Have brought us ruine, and have found their own.
VVhilt thus our Sphear is over-cat with Clowds,
You (the bright Sun) their envious darknes hrouds,
As ready to break forth, when Factions here
Divide, as when dark clowds part in the Sphear,
The Sun can be. No offer you neglect,
To warm us with your lutre, and protect
From uch foggs of mean Souls, which till will flie
O're us, till all's dipell'd by Majety.
Once for your Kingdome's ake you durt oppoe
Your Laurel'd Enemies with your Comming in with the Scots, who were before Conquer'd by the Englih at Dunbar. conquer'd foes.
Yet Heaven from your aitance then was taid,
Let the ill Act the good had over-vveigh'd;
And in the Victory thoe Scots had found
Their Crimes together vvith your Vertues crovvn'd.
Then 'twas You did attempt your debt to pay
To Us or Nature, by a noble way.
The bold Stat caus renovare omneis, omnemque reverti Per Trojam, et rurus caput objectare perîclis. Virg. lib. 2. Aeneid. Aeneas o, having left Troy
In its own funerall flames, corn'd to enjoy
Safety alone; but, led by Vertues great
As vvere the Dangers he was to repeat,
Return'd among his ruin'd Friends and State,
To bring them afety, or to fetch their fate.
VVhilt our dull ouls all nobler vvarmth deny'd,
The Covvard and th'Inenible divide
Our vvoes made habits by the ue, or dare
Not think vve knovv hovv great our ufferings are.
Like thoe vvho dvvell in till-reounding Caves,
VVhere Nile ends headlong dovvn his rapid vvaves,
Are deaf, becaue the Clamors contant are,
The VVater not out-thundered by the Air.
So, till oppres'd, Cutom at lat denies
Unto our Souls the ue of Faculties.
Thus is Your cae in forlorn habits dret,
Rob'd of your friends by fear and interet.
VVhilt Princes little think (ince change is ure)
To pitty others is to be ecure;
Like thoe, vvho neither dying men deplore,
Nor have more thoughts of frailty than before.
But HE above, to make his Povver knovvn,
VVhat exceeds ours, has fitted for his ovvn;
And can by thoe bad Intruments retore
Your Crovvns, that were their ravihers before.
By Jealouie, and their ambitious Pride,
VVhich may their Crimes among themelves divide;
Till in each others guilty boome too,
They heath their Svvords more jutly than they drew.
Like Cadmus children that vvere born vvith trife,
Their quarrell's not lee antient than their life,
VVhich never in ucceive michief dyes,
And factions till on other's ruines rie.
So a vvell'd VVave in all its pride appears,
VVhoe certain fate the follovving billovv bears.
In Storms, ruine on ruine till depends,
Till vvant of giddy vvaves the quarrell ends.
So Jutice your returning Throne prolongs,
Till they upon themelves revenge your vvrongs.
That without Vict'ry you may Conquet find,
And without Blood your peacefull Brows may bind
With all thoe Crowns, which are as much your due
As Birth and Vertue can contribute to.
Thus the great Power of all, having firt choe
To make your Vertues great and afe by Woes,
Will, by as unexpected ways, retore
Your ravih'd Crowns, as they were lot before.

div.head: To AMARANTA. The Fate of Scorn.

lg.l: IF you the world could Conquer one by one,
You'd then want Trophies for your boundles mind;
Like that ambitious Alexander the Great, of whom Juven. 10. Aetuat infelix anguto limite mundi. Prince, who wanted room,
In the trait circuit of the world confin'd.
Such fate's as his due to uch cruelty,
Unpittied and unminded too of all,
At once without a Friend or Enemy.
The Souldier that joyns Conquet to his name
By Victories, when overcome with years,
(As you mut one day be) preerves his fame,
Not by thoe wounds he gave, but thoe he bears.
So when your Charms in Age's furrows lie
Lot, and forgotten, they had once o mov'd;
One Wound amidt your heaps of Victory
Would better tell, that you had been belov'd.
Then like a Tyrant ravih'd from his Throne,
You'l wih, that you had gentlier us'd your own.

opener.U: et to the Tune of ARCHIBELLA.

lg.l: FAir Amaranta, if thy Eyes
Could force ome feigned tears to rie,
It might my eaie thoughts uffice.
And joyn'd with mine, perhaps might prove
Enough my Sorrows to remove;
I do not ask they hould my Love.
But mine, I fear, thy tears will fright;
And like thoe The Sava and Danubius, whoe treams never mix in threecore miles together, as Sir Henry Blunt in his Travells affirms. Rivers that take flight
In the ame Banks, yet ne'r unite.
Thoe treams from prings like ours might flow,
The tears can ne'r united grow,
Of feigned grief and reall woe.
Should you too weep, though 'twere for me,
I hould be o concern'd for thee,
To beg again thy cruelty.
No, there's no way to cure my pain,
But paying Truth and Love again,
Such, and as great as feeds my flame.

div.head: To the unconstant CYNTHIA. A SONG.

lg.l: TEll me once, Dear, how it does prove
That I o much forworn could be?
I never wore always to love,
I onely vow'd till to love thee:
And art thou now what thou wert then,
Unworn unto by other men?
In thy fair Breat, and once-fair Soul,
I thought my Vows were writ alone;
But others Oaths o blurr'd the Scrole,
That I no more could read my own.
And am I till oblig'd to pay,
When you had thrown the Bond away?
Nor mut we onely part in Joy,
Our tears as well mut be unkind:
VVeep you, that could uch truth detroy;
And I, that could uch falenes find.
Thus we mut unconcern'd remain
In our divided Joys and Pain.
Yet we may love, but on this diff'rent core,
You what I am, I what you were before.
YOu are not, Cynthia, better pleas'd than I,
That you firt led the way
Through this dark night of blind Incontancy,
And firt found break of Day.
To freedom now we'l acrifice dreams pat.
'Twas my good fate to cry Good-morrow lat.
Perhaps o oon I could not di-engage,
Having a greater core.
Some Birds will longer hover round the Cage,
Though 'twas their Jayl before.
Yet ure I meant not long to it about
The ahes, when the fire was quite burnt out.
Since now my Jaylor has my Chains unty'd,
I'le hold my hand no more
Up at Love's Bar; he is condemn'd untride,
That has been burnt before.
Now that heart-icknes which he gave, protects;
'Tis eldom that the ame plague twice infects.
Breats that have known Love's cruell lavery,
Are better fortifi'd
By that experience than they ere can be,
By reaon or by pride.
Then bluh not that you quench'd this am'rous flame,
But bluh with me, if we two love again.
TEmpt me no more (fair Cynthia) 'tis as vain,
As was the hated Action when you lot,
What you unjutly fancy novv to gain;
Though at the ame repeated vice's cot.
For he you lov'd more than your Contancy,
Mut uffer now as then you injur'd me.
Such punihment attends that hated inne,
That the repentance of it, is a Crime:
And you to gain my heart mut act agen
The vice which lot it firt, from being thine.
How jutly does Love's-god his power how,
In making the uncontant ever o?

That Cleop • tra, whole beamy gain'd her as abolute an Empire over Julius <> ; as he had over others, by his victories and vertues. After him, this Queen as various in Love, as in Ambition, extended her Conquets over Marcus Antoni • s, to whoe power Octavius Caear put an end, overthrowing the Lovers in a Batrell, and deign'd Cl • opatra to adorn his Triumph, who by death prevented a hame, o contrary to her former glories. Queen whoe charms on Caear all could do,
He did to others by his Sword and Mind,
Making the VVorld his Slave and Lover too;
Had he as contant been as fair and kind.
Octavius vvould have bluh'd at thoughts to have,
Romes conquering Caear's Mitris for his lave.
Nor did one Caear jutlier think his Love,
Paid to her charm's, vvhilt equall flames he feels,
Than t' other vvhen he did uncontant prove,
Deign'd thoe beauties for his Chariot-wheels.
So you may fall unpitti'd as he did,
Uncontant unto all things but her pride.
Thoe beauties vvhich in your fair face and eyes,
So long have rendevouz'd in Contant pay,
Like Armies till attempting victories,
And alway's kept on duty, mut decay.
Then vvhen thoe troops of beauties once decline,
You'l feel the vvant of your lot Truth and Time.

div.head: To CELIA. Who deired to have Veres, that were written on Her in a glae Window, to be given Her in a heet of Paper.
div.l: YOur praies vvhich the vvounded glas did bear,
By your Command this paper now mut wear;
Both's due to you, 'tis jut all praies meet,
Of VVomen, in a glae, or in a heet.

lg.l: NOvv I confee, I am ore'come,
Though the out-vvorks vvere torm'd before,
Yet they eem'd lighted and not vvonne;
VVhilt I had a Reerve in tore.
But he that Conquers not in part,
Storm'd then my heart;
VVhich famih't reaon kept before.
She had corrupted o my Spies,
And me to that Condition brought,
I durt not end abroad my eyes;
But like a Covvard vvink't and fought.
For vvhen I did thoe helpers ue,
They brought me nevv's;
She had freh troops of beauties got.
See vvhat is unretrain'd deire,
And to give leave to vvandring eyes,
Like that fond fool that plaies vvith fire;
VVhere all the Ammunition lies.
And to attempt retreats is vain,
VVhen the laid train.
Had taken fire from her eyes.
Now my blown flame can fewell find,
Of every thought I have, and knows
How to diget my peace of mind;
For in ditemper'd breats Love grows.
Well did the antient Poets feign,
That from the Main,
And troubled Waves, Love's goddee roe.
Yet though condemn'd, I bluh to grieve,
As much as once I did to love;
I'm pleas'd his Laws grant no reprieve:
He that to Fate would lowly move,
Has lot his courage with his heart,
And that mean part
May make her corn a jutice prove.

div.head: To Mrs. Mor. on the Birth of her Firt Son.

lg.l: THus Heaven does you & us from fears redeem:
At once gives Joy; and to that, Joy Eteem.
Thoe relih Eae that firt have tated Pain;
By knowing what we want, we value gain.
So great and perfect now your bleings are,
You eem in more than what is frail to hare;
Whilt you renew your leae of life and fame,
By living thus in vertues and in name.
'Tis jut this child hould be in all your heir,
And equally of life and vertues hare.
For whilt he lay within his living Tomb,
How could he but contract what was your own?
So water, pour'd into a veell, owes
A relih to the cask through which it flowes.
Thus you give vertues and give life away,
Yet not lee good, nor uffer by decay.
One flame unto a thouand may give light,
Yet has not lee, nor does remain lee bright.
But thus whilt life and vertue you betow,
Think to his happy paion what you owe.
Had you left unrewarded his pure flame,
You mut have lot your hare in time and fame.
So in the Chaos before Love made way,
Both Time and Glory unregarded lay.
But ee what mutuall obligations pat,
You gave him Joys, and he thus makes them lat.
STay thou till, dearet Shape, O do not fly!
Why do thoe charming looks appear o trange?
In t'other world there's no incontancy,
Nor has my Love in this admitted change.
The Joys in t'other world the gods betow,
Do from enlarged love and knowledge flow.
Since then you needs mut know I have been true,
And my faith tells, you cannot but be o;
What cruell unknown Law obliges you,
By this reerv'dnes, to encreae my wo?
Like Tantalus, who always is deny'd
Thoe treams which by his longing enes glide.
Is it as wie men often tell us here,
Though love and knowledge hall have an encreae,
They'l have no partiall applications there;
Knowledge reolves in Praie, and Love in Peace.
As Sunhine equally on all reflects,
Yet to one object mot no beam directs?
Or are you now forbid to own a fire,
(Though kindled by the bleed hape you bear)
Whilt rak'd in living ahes? This deire,
You ure may own, and ure the gods will hear.
In pitty of my woes this bleing give,
That I may die, or unconcern'd may live.

sp.speaker: Thir.
sp.l: CHaron, O gentle Charon, bring thy Boat.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Who's this that calls with an unuuall note?

sp.speaker: Thir.
sp.l: Hither thy Veell, gentle Charon, drive.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Thou peakt as if that thou wert now alive.

sp.speaker: Thir.
sp.l: And may I till be o, unlee to me
Thou tell't large joys of your Eternity.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Why wouldt thou know? ince thoe that bodies have
I eldom row, or thoe that want a grave.

sp.speaker: Thir.
sp.l: Ep •• thee why?

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: A inful Soul will inck
My patcht-up Bark almot below the brink.
Should Bodies too with their offences go,
'Twould inck me quite.

sp.speaker: Thir.
sp.l: By that then thou dot know
If any Soul has pat thee fatall treams,
Whom good or ill has govern'd in extreams.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Perhaps I may.

sp.speaker: Thir.
sp.l: Then, gentle Charon, tell
What I hall ask, and I'le reward thee well.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Ask quickly then, for here I never wait,
Souls croud o fat; Ambition, War, and Fate
Send cutom till.

sp.speaker: Thir.
sp.l: Did not thy fatall Boat,
But lately, as if lot in tempets, float?
If thy Boat feels the humor of the Soul
It bears, ure it did lately trangely roul.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: I carried uch a one, a Woman too,
Who then I guet had been too much untrue,
My Boat o totter'd till. Wouldt go where he
Now lives?

sp.speaker: Thir.
sp.l: Not I, but rather tel to me,
What he does there?

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: She fickly wanders now,
And ever mut, in glo • my hades below.
'Tis jut they never hould directly find,
Or know their way, that never knew their mind.

sp.speaker: Thir.
sp.l: I hould have wander'd too, it eems; had I
But thought it fine to whine, and grieve, & die.
Nor yet her falnes, nor the cruelty
Of one more fair and good, could work on me,
To break my heart; perhaps it did my leep.
Didt thou not carry, o're this fatall Deep,
One that appear'd evere, yet trictly good?

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: My Bark did then but gently kis the Floud;
She was no weight, for vertue was her guide,
And helpt me too as much as could a Tide.

sp.speaker: Thir.
sp.l: She ure its always till; but hould I find
Her in your World, Might he at lat grow kind?

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: No, Never now; for there may grow a crime,
Where there can be a change in thought or time.
But if to go to her thou dot deire,
Thy joy mut be, at ditance to admire.

sp.speaker: Thir.
sp.l: I thank thee, gentle Charon; now I'le tay,
Since I mut either doat, or loe my way.
I'le back to our dull World again, and find
A Mitres, if I can, both fair and kind.
For ince at lat we hither all mut throng,
'Tis good, I ee, to bring one's heav'n along.
I hope the gods too will with this dipence,
To be uncontant in one's own defence.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Why then farewell.

sp.speaker: Thir.
sp.l: When I return my cores
I'le pay in vertues which hall be thy Oars.
Back to my World I'le go,

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: and I to mine.

sp.speaker: Chor.
sp.l: That Breat has heaven's light where Vertues hine.
Heaven dwells in breats, kept free from crimes and hate;
The place does but preerve from change and fate.

lg.l: NO Cynthia, never think I can
Love a divided heart and mind;
Your Sunhine love to every man,
Appears alike as great as kind.
None but the duller Perians kneel,
And the bright god of Beams implore:
Whilt others equall influence feel.
That never did the god adore.
The riches of your Love's put forth,
And ev'ry man retains a part,
You can't call't in, to make you worth
The purchae of a faithfull heart.
Hope not to be mine, or your own;
You can't your elfe to me retore,
The Net is left, the Birds are flown.
And bankrupt-Love ets up no more:
Your kindnee which at randome flyes,
Makes your Love-patients all ecure,
But they will find your Emp'rick eyes;
Can only palliate, never cure.
Though I reolve to love no more,
Since I did once; I will advie.
The love of Conquets now give o're,
Diquiets wait on Victories.
To your much injur'd peace and name,
Love's farewell as a tribute pay,
Grow now reerv'd and raie your fame;
By your own choice not your decay.
She that to Age her charms reignes,
And then at lat turns Votary;
Though Vertue much the change inclines,
'Tis ullied by Neceity.
LOng have I thought, It was in vain,
To eek to purchae Love or Fame:
For both alike would lide away,
Or by my own, or her decay.
For Love and Fame, crown'd with uccee,
Do from enjoyment both grow lee.
Had the god's o, but been content,
I would have liv'd indifferent.
Not to have fear'd extreams of fate,
Or Cares, that from lot Joyes take weight;
Indifferency all afety keeps,
Ther's none unhappy whilt he leeps.
But trangely wak't, he did urprize,
My blie and reaon with her eyes:
So lazy Princes wanting aime,
To eck to purchae love and fame,
Are by ome lighted power o'recome,
The corn of others, and their own.
Now he too much her power knows;
So ome reited tream o'reflows
More than its uuall banks; nor I
Dare longer her jut power deny:
That mut above the Common rate,
Not reward paions but Create.
AS from a neigh bouring rock, afflicted eyes
See their lov'd object, tot by threatning waves,
Rude meengers of angry detinies;
Their welling wombs grown fertile too with graves.
Safety and joy, their nature loe; whilt he,
Share's with the others, fears and detiny.
So from the height of all my happinee,
Whilt I ee torms of fears oppree thee o,
I wih thy jutice more, though kindnee lee;
My grief is far more gentle then thy woe.
Though both wayes led unto my fate, yet I
Would as thy Martyr, not thy Traitor, dye.
Seldome, its true, the mighty tock of Love,
Meets in one mind, with uch refined ene,
As to preerve that which it can't improve,
Only by paying its own jut expence.
Not all thoe taxes which vain eyes deigne,
To many beauties, and decaying time.
Yet there is Love, like mine, can know no end,
Above the reach of any change or fate,
Ile mile at beauties too, that would pretend
A reformation in my happy tate;
Be but as kind, as I will contant prove,
And make my Joyes as perfect as my Love.

div.head: Upon hearing Mrs. M. K. ing.

lg.l: OUr vain Philoophy can only teach,
But not command, when orrows make a breach
Upon the heart: but to thy voice we pay
Obedience, whilt we light what wiemen ay.
Thy charming breath through our enchaunted ears,
Poeion takes, where once our hopes and fears
Rai'd torms before, and the becalmed breat,
No longer now by cruell care's oppret.
'Twere Heaven protected thus from all extreams,
Were but thy breath Eternall, and our Dreams.
So Orpheus, led not by his fate but choice,
To the dull world of hades his charming voice;
Brought Heaven there, and made the torments ceae,
Th' infernall buinee all lock't up in peace.
His voice, the buie Furies could compoe,
And thine our paions, Furies great as thoe.
By Lethe's treams, which brought forgetfulnee,
Souls were ecur'd of preent happinee.
So thy Loud voice, not only Joy procures,
But, by oblivion too, our cares ecures.
We, whilt you Sing, in tate of blie remain,
And when you ceae, hrink to our elves again.

div.head: AMARANTA, to the god of Love.

lg.l: AH, mighty Love, what power unknown,
Hat thou now u'd more than thy own!
It was thy conduct and deigne,
But not thy power that Vanquih't mine.
As a great Captain to his Name,
Of every Conquet joynes the fame;
Though 'twas not by his power got,
But Army's, by his Conduct brought:
So when thou could't not do't alone,
Thou lead't his troops of Vertues on.
And I now feel by my urprize,
Thou hat not only darts but eyes;
Jut god! now take again thy Arms,
And rally all I have of charms.
What pow'r and conduct cannot do,
Make his beliefe contribute to.
So, when the earth ome promie hows,
That he does greater wealth incloe;
Believing men earch her rich veins,
And crown their hopes with unknown gains;
May he, but at the firt, incline to Love,
Then by my Faith, and Time,
His Jutice, after the urprize,
Shall be more fetter'd than his eyes?

div.p: THE BLIND LADY A Comedy.

list.item: Philena, a great Lady attending the Princee.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: BUt upon what injury, Phylanter?

sp.speaker: Phy.
sp.l: Love and Ambition, Sir, thoe two great injuries
Of mens educed minds, which fill the thoughts.
Full of Revenge, not with the jutnee of it.
What Mironault has done, moves not my hate;
But what he may, my fears. By her, a Kingdom, Sir;
And, with her elf, a World—
Falls in my arms. How low you are to crown
Me and your elf with happinee?
You can love neither, and deny.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: But are you ure he comes?

sp.speaker: Phy.
sp.l: I am certainly inform'd o.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Yet conider, on, how will the King reent,
That whilt he's paying his duty to the Princee,
He hould be there urpried?

sp.speaker: Phy.
sp.l: That is your part for to prevent, Sir,
Telling the King, (uch minds are ever jealous)
That his deignes were to urprie the Princee.
'Twill appear ervice then, and may detroy
My Rival's interet, if not advance my own.
Thoe, Sir, that traffick in thee eas,
Fraught not their Bark with fear • :
Beides, there needs none now.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Yet think again, though, as you are my on,
I can deny you little; and 'tis more jut
You hould, deny your elf, and not obey
Thee haty paions. He ne're injur'd you;
Or if he had, there were a nobler way
For your reven • e than this. You are angry
That the world's pleaed with him, and that he may
Enjoy a blis you wih for; or, at leat,
Becaue he wihes it as well as you;
A Quarrell which Mankind mut lay aide,
Or all be Murtherers.

sp.speaker: Phy.
sp.l: You told me, I did obey my paions,
To thoe you give your reaons then:
As much you may expect from them,
As if you told the winds they blew. too hard.
Think of the Caue, then judge of the Effect.
'Tis Love—Love for the Princee too,
For whoe fair ake, Who'd not attempt
The angry billows well'd with horrid torms,
The Sea-gods Pyramids, when every wave
Bears too, like thoe, within its womb a grave,
Or dangers yet unheard of? Determine, Sir,
For I reolve to act; and let the tory then
Come to his unprepared ears.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Well, that I may proerve you
From ome more unadvied coure, (if more can be)
I'le do it; but take heed
Of letting violence be offer'd to him:
Preerve thy elf free from o foul a crime.
Love's way lies not through blood. Conider too
What we now go to act; nor bluh
To think thou didt do ill, or that 'twill throw
Aperions on thy judgment, to dilike
The folly thou hadt dotingly embrac'd.
Hee's wie that ees his error at the lat,
Who weighs all thee in perfect cales,
Shame of his crime, and not his wit, prevails.
Farewell, I leave you to your thoughts.
—I'le on my way to night.
Heaven direct and proper you.

sp.speaker: Phyl.
sp.l: How nice his concience was—now to my buinee.
And thou, great god of Love, that rul't my heart,
Attempt but Fortune with as kind a Dart;
That whilt I reach at what can carcely be,
Fortune as madly too may dote on me.
—Now all things but deigne
Leave me—and yet—it looks but odly,
To put off all this honety at once,
And to have none about me.
Or was it ever mine? ure I borrow'd it,
And 'tis a thing that's taken up on trut;
I owe the world o much; I'le think on't
When I can pay it. Lycepes, welcome,
I was reolved jut now to eek you.

sp.speaker: Lyce.
sp.l: You would have found me till prepar'd to erve you.

sp.speaker: Phyl.
sp.l: You are my noble friend, nor will I ay,
That I hall try it now; this onely can
Preerve it. But words are waters of our time,
And robs us till of action. As fat then as you can
Get all our friends in readinee, as many
As poibly you can, well arm'd and mounted.
Return with all the peed your Love can make.
As we go you hall know all,
The ret mut live in ignorance.
What Power now to invoke I hardly know,
Yet every god has felt what Love can do.
COme, the Princee is hard at hand:
And if we hate not, he may overtake us.
To night too, we mut lodge the Deer.
We need not care for that; this Forret
Is o well tor'd, that Game's in every Thicket.
It caues the Princee contant progree
Into thee parts—But who are thee?
'Tis the brave Mironault.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Well overtaken, Huntmen,
Is the Princee
Yet far behind?
No, my Lord, he is almot in ight.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: I thank you—
—Whither does Love thus hurry me?
A Tyrant that denies the mallet hopes,
Where he gives larget wihes!
The greatet Beauties are like greatet Wealths,
Subjects for all mens wihes, not their hopes.
Fears hare with Love the Empire of the heart,
Rendring alike the Lover and the Coward.
Danger's the awfull Mitree of the one,
Who fears to tempt her, let he hould endure
That fate too quickly, which he knowes is ure.
So, whilt the other's Mitres too is ignorant,
Onely more low, the pining Lover dies,
And that ure fate but hates, if he denies.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: Dear Sir, let not grief thus torment you.
You hould have there a nobler Guet, your Reaon;
And were that there, there hardly could be room
For uch diorders. Paions are like Thieves,
That watch to enter undefended places,
And rob you too of all that put's a difference
Between Wild-beats and Man. Yet, mitake not;
Your grief, if not dipair, is the fond paion
I peak againt, and not the love they pring from:
That were her injury, to whom alone
All is due, as Rivers to the Ocean.
Yet Nature has decreed, that he mut love:
Believe your worth and your devotion then
As great as any—

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: O Hyppaus—
'Tis eaier far to counell than to act;
And every one's provided with the widom,
That has not interet in the misfortune.
And thoe that in Feavors, though 'tis their ruine,
Wih Rivers of drink; the tanders by,
That then advie, and, may be, wonder at them,
Would, in the ame dieae, do jut o too.

sp.speaker: Pyan.
sp.l: You know not, Sir, but this great goddee
May be a little mercifull: by this hand,
If he be not, I'le be revenged,
On half the Sex at leat, by proving rigorous
To thoe poor Wenches I have prated to;
That's every one almot that e're I aw—Then forooth
Will the poor creatures wih their amorous heads
Fill'd with Romances, pine, and die,
With Willow-garlands under Myrtle-hades:
And grief for them will kill the Mothers too.
Your Princee hall not have many Female Subjects.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: I thank thee, good Pyander, for attempting
To mix thy mirth with my oppoing griefs.
But they are contraries, and cannot meet in one.
—but let it perih withme—I mut again
Deire your ecreies.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: Nay that's—

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Pardon me, Hyppaus—
I know it's needlee to repeat
A wih of mine to either of you:
But what men's thoughts are full with, iue forth,
With too much hate and freedom.

sp.speaker: Pyan.
sp.l: Will you take my advice, Sir?

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: Nay pray, Sir, hear him.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Come, what is't, Pyander?

sp.speaker: Pyan.
sp.l: Wholom extreamly! For the kind contitution
Of a decaying Lover; this is the hort Receipt.
In the firt place, make your elf—very—drunck.
Nay, nay, you need not wonder; by divine Bacchus,
'Tis a rare expreion of paion to court diorderly,
To make a meer Chaos of one's elf, and then give her
The honor of Creating you; then, beides,
All truth and all good nature will appear.
If this be not the way to be conider'd, I'l be judg'd—

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: How do you like it, Sir?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: There's kindnee in't to me, I know, Hyppaus;
And were I capable of mirth, it might produce it.
But Grief and Love are throng'd together,
And have carce room enough.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: Have either Joy or Grief, wee'l hare with you;
Nor was't our fears of having part
That made us wih you none; we value you
And our own lives at the ame rate:
We wih them free from all misfortunes,
Yet hare all willingly rather than part.
But we mut alter now that hew of trouble
Which we have given our elves; for the Princee
Mut needs be neer.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: See Hippaus—.
I had forgot the ubject of my thoughts,
How greedily I wih, yet fear to ee her!
Like ome poor Votary, whoe holy thoughts
Sets off o much, the joyes of Paradie,
That it employes as many fears as wihes.
—Hark he comes! You Powers above,
Lend Love and Fortune now their eyes,
To help, or ee at leat, their acrifice.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: You 're well met, my Lord,
Was it a chance,
Or your deigne that brought you?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: 'Tis all I have about me of ambition,
And of large wihes, that I may often
Have leave thus to preent my ervice.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: Your ervice, Sir, has been o much coniderable,
That I hould be alone guilty of folly,
Did I not valew it at uch a rate,
As the whole World have ett upon it.

sp.speaker: Miro.
sp.l: If I had uch a power, to oblige
As much, as you are plea'd to ay I have;
The World's applaue, could not o much reward
My ervices, as your receiving of them.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: My interet, next to my Father's,
In this obliged Nation by your valour,
Has made it gratitude ever for me,
To avow that and more.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: I have then much of my bet wihes crown'd,
Yet hould you know all that my heart conceals,
Though it be much like this, you'd be diplea'd
With what you have pretended to allow.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: I cannot find this guilt about me, and can lee guee.
How you hould have a thought that hould dipleae me.
You cannot but oblige, and I as hardly
Can tell what's injury, if you hould do it.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: This is a kindnee, till admired Princee,
That I mut never ask the meaning of;
But to my flatter'd fancy, o interpret
As you would never do: yet 'tis unjut,
That I hould ue, the leat kind word from you,
With an advantage to my elfe.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: Sure, I may give you leave to do it,
For uch a confidence I jutly have
Of your great vertues, that you ever
Purue your own advantages with others.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: 'Tis true, to the undeerving World,
I can perform all this, only to you
I am unjut, that never wih
A good to you, when I deire mot.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: I hardly undertand you: if I do,
The world is more oblig'd to you than I.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Such a trange Character, my fate
Has thrown upon me, yet my elfe,
And all that World, which eems o much
Beholding to me more than you,
Are as much lee in my eteem,
As are the ands unto the mingled jewells,
The Negro brings up from the Deep together.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: Is there a poibil • y to know,
Your meaning then?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: You hould, if I were ure you would forgive it,
Yet thus much take in guees. Could Shades be enible,
And wih the embraces of the Sun, were not that Lamp,
Injur'd by that which lov'd it, could rude beats
Be paionate for Empire, and not injure
The Throne becaue they lov'd it. 'Tis I
That am more dark then all thoe hades,
You brighter then that Sun; 'Tis I
That am that Beat rob'd of all reaon.
And you above all Empires; I have acknowledg'd
My unupected guilt, becaue t'was o,
And though I cannot leave my Love,
I may my Life.—

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: You have done more than given me leave to guee,
And ince I have my elfe been guilty too,
In giving you the occaion I hall forbear
Such a dipleaure as is due, and let you know.
T'was eaie too for me to erre, that could o little
Imagine you to be o guilty: I hall adde
Only thus much, that as you valew
My preence or eteem, repeat no more
Any thing of this nature—Come let's on:

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: So Merchants for a tempting venture
Bankrupt themelves; yet what wealth had I
Before I knew my poverty from her?
'Tis nothing I have lot, the difference is,
That I have omething now I wih to loe,

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: She is not, Sir, a greater enemy,
To your content, than you are to your elfe:
'Tis you enlarge her frowns by fancied fears,

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Thoe that are free from danger, my Hyppaus.
May look and wonder at another's fears,
That is environd with it: 'tis Concern
That is the excue for Paion; were you my Rivall,
The Counell would be juter if you gave it,
—Come we mut not tay behind,—
Ther's nothing but a Lover plea'd with ufferings.
All other rigors of this World,
Our wihes and endeavours till oppoe,
The Prioner hates his bolts, whilt he remains
Plea'd not o much with reedom as his chains.

sp.speaker: Phyl.
sp.l: TRut me a little, Fortune, with my elf,
I do not ask thy aide grow big my hopes,
And well unto a Throne,
To Crown my Love, and my Ambition on;
From thence I'le view the thing cal'd Honety,
And grieve 'tis o contemn'd, and ought to be.
—Man is like pliant Wax,
That yields unto a fair Impreion,
Though ent not from the noblet Metall:
And, in this world, it bears an equall how
To eem but onely honet, or be o.
And when the Crown's once gain'd, there needs no fears:
Crimes change their natures then, or Men change theirs.
—Dye—Scruples—in my thoughts,
And let my mind be a prepoterous grave,
That bore you firt, to bury you again:
—and your bae iue—Fear—
Dye too, when Beauty and a Crown's o near.
—Lycepes welcome; what news?

sp.speaker: Lyce.
sp.l: All as you would have it, Sir:
The Troop is march'd, and tays you in the VVood,
Between this and the Catle.

sp.speaker: Phyl.
sp.l: Let's follow then;
For Time's a buie Offerer of our Interets
To every check of Fortune.

sp.speaker: Lyce.
sp.l: VVe make ome threecore Hore,
VVhich will be three Diviions; one for each Port.

sp.speaker: Phyl.
sp.l: Let Martianus command the lat.
As we go, I'le give you perfect Orders.
I wih they had ome means to cherih a Reitance,
That he may help to his own ruine;
He mut not live to plead his innocence.
But Time, that never will be taid,
Calls us to act what we have carcely waigh'd.

div.head: ACT. 1. SCEN. 4.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: YOu're welcome now, my Lord, and I deire
No clowd may dwell on any brow;
Let no uch prejudice happen amidt our ports.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: If you be not obey'd, admired Princee,
Where you command, it is extreamly trange;
And yet, I fear, 'tis poible.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: As poible it is I may upect my power.
But, my Lo • d, I had forgot to put you in remembrance

Of perfec •
<> torie you began,
As you <…> it, of unhappy Lovers.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: The Princee, Madam,
Was taken by Phylanter, whoe great valour,
Shewn in that day, deerv'd all Prioners:
To whom he nobly offer'd Liberty,
Without a Ranome, or Acknowledgment
Unlee to you. Before he thank't him,
She made enquiry for the Prince, my Prioner;
As if he knew not how to ue
Freedom nor life without him; and by reaon
That he was full of wounds, Phylanter
Waited upon her to my Tent; at the firt ight
Of him he o much lov'd, cover'd with wounds,
She tood amaz'd, perhaps too wih'd her elf
What he appear'd, but a dead Statue.
At the ame time he rais'd his feeble eyes,
Which eem'd to take unkindly her delay.
At that he came, and kneeling by him,
Made uch expreions of unfeigued grief,
That though we undertood not what he aid,
Yet that was plain enough. He now grew peechles,
(And he almot) yet till with ignes,
That eem'd expreions of more trouble.
For leaving her then all the world
Within her arms, he died; he but tayed
To be aur'd that he was dead. Then with a hate,
That hew'd a willingnee to follow him,
She drew a Viall from her boom,
And drank it off, before that we could hinder her;
Whoe violence, on an enfeebled heart
By o much grief, with unbelieved hate,
Wrought Execution.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p: Poor Princee! 'twas her hard fate to love;
sp.l: She had been ele no more concern'd,
Than thoe that now urvive.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: And he perhaps as unconcern'd to dye.
sp.l: Nothing but a deerving Love
Could have taught her a way o glorious
To end all cares. She now enjoys him too,
Or ele inenible that e're he lot him.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p: Did that young Prince command that day the Army?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Yes, and, as we learnt, he was the Heir
sp.l: To the Tartarian Empire.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: 'Tis nothing but a Prince
Could have been o unhappy to loe at once
His Love, his Life, his Empire.

div.stage: [Enter hatily Hyppaus, Lyander. Hyppaus takes Mironault aide.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.p: My Lord—

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Ha

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.p: Let not the Princee ee it:
sp.l: The Catle is urrounded by a Troop of Souldiers,
Commanded by Phylanter; I fear you are their aim.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: I?

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.p: You may guee the caues, Jealouie and Baenes.
sp.l: Think, or you'r lot.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Ha—'tis very happy.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: I don't undertand that.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: I'le pree them nobly: Are they many?

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.p: They are divided, as we guee. The gates are yet kept hut.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: I'le go view, and in • antly return.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: The Devill on the michief! if their aim
sp.l: Be towards me, it mut be for my life.
A Parly cannot ave me, I am reolv'd
To ell it.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Upon my life, Madam, there's ome diorder.
sp.l: View but the eyes of Mironault.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p: My Lord, why are you mov'd?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: I, Madam?

sp.speaker: Prin
sp.p: Pray, Sir, let me entreat of you the caue.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.p: Nothing that ought to give you trouble, Madam,
sp.l: There's omething that requires
The preence of my Lord without.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: If there be any that would peak with him,
They hall be here dipatcht.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: That cannot be, Madam.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: Come, my Lord.
There's omething I can guee at (if I be not deceiv'd)
That does aure me, I may command you.
What buines breeds this alteration?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: I dare not diobey you;
The Catle is urrounded by Phylanter
With Troops of Soldiers; and, as we guee,
My life's their aim.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: The Catle urrounded! and your life their aim?
It is impoible: they dare not think it.
I will go ee their rudenee.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Not for the world, they know that you are here:
And their intents they'l act unto their power.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: Is there a better way?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Yes any, rather than dye tamely,

sp.speaker: Pya.
sp.l: For heaven's ake, Sir, reolve: Phylanter's now,
Forcing the gates, being denied entrance
For all his Souldiers, who loudly now
Call you, A Traitor. Upon one ide
Which I'le conduct you to, it is mot probable
You may ecape—.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: Ah me!

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: May I believe, (fair wonder of your Sex)
That though your cruelty deignes my fate,
Yet you're diplea'd, that thee hould be
The Executioners? I hall then dare
To oppoe all their furies, that my Life
May be Love's acrifice alone; forgive me too,
If I dare own that Love, you frown upon.
You need not cruple to grant this—,
To any that mut aske no more.
And may that peace, you give my dying thoughts,
For ever live with yours—.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: Pray ay no more, think of your afety,

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: See, he weeps—.
With pitty ever dwells forgivenee too,
My wihes then are crown'd, and I can have
No greater, unlee that it were poible,
I might hope more and live.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: O Mironault!—
So much confuion mingles with my thoughts,
I know not what to ay; and yet I wih
That you might live, and cannot be diplea'd,
Though hope hould be the caue.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: So Saylers in a inking veell,
May ee a calm begin—. This treacherous world,
Never wants michiefs to prevent
The greatet bleings that are near-approaching,
To crown man's greedy wihes.—
But I mitake, to doubt that Life
Which you have given leave I hould enjoy.
Who only have the power of it. This hall witnee,
How much I covet to preerve,
What you wih afety to; nor is it poible,
That I hould unuccesfull prove,
That have no other ue for life but love;

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: The gods protect and guide you, O Phylena,
What's to be done?

sp.speaker: Phy.
sp.l: Collect your elf, dear Madam, all may be well,
Let's to a window, that o're-looks that ide,
Where they intended to break forth.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: I dare not ee him fall.

sp.speaker: Phy.
sp.l: Fear not Madam, Heaven will preerve.
So fair a Life, that has your prayers too.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: Hark, they are ingag'd, lets ee if it be poible,
To give him more aitance than our wihes.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: STay haty drops, not to preerve
The life that does purue you.
But the blet hrine, where Mirramente dwells,
See, 'tis not my wihes tayes the purple current:
Man's till mot near to dye, when he would live,
And live when he would dye; calamity,
And, the more dangerous extream, properity
Commits this violence upon mens wihes.
Yet ince the gods denied for either caue
To detroy life, or to protect;
In tead of Choice, we hould oppoe Neglect.
Hark, the noie increaes till.
—ure they are lot—
They fought it nobly, though, if my ears
Deceive me not, I hear ome comming.
Ha Hyppaus and Pyander!
Then I am happy in pight of all mifortunes.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: Dear Sir, you cut your way o nobly,
We hould have reach'd you ooner ele.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: And o we had Sir, but two or three goodfellows
Still • aid us upon conference—

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Well, here's no taying, we mut forward;
But whither, Heaven knows; 'twas an unworthy action.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: For the honorable part of the tory,
Wee'l, if you pleae, comment upon it hereafter.
In the mean time, 'tis more needfull to oberve
What a condition we are in to help one another.
Hyppaus would make dainty whitles,
My bones are already rattles:
The bet houe of receipt I know would be an Hopitall.
A noie again—On, good Sir.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: The mot by-ways mut guide us.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Heaven direct us—

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: O what a peech could I now make
Of this frail world. But however,
I'le not tay now to do it.

div.head: ACT 1. SCEN. 6.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: HE cannot ure ecape.

sp.speaker: Phy.
sp.l: Rather believe he mut, there is a better fate
Reerv'd for o much worth. Our hopes are now
The policy as well as jutice of our hearts.
You know we did dicern, how o're the plain
Some hated ingle, and Pylander aid, they were divided.
At firt you aw how fat he made his way,
Triumph and Danger waiting on his Sword.
The villains too, like dull oppoing clowds,
Gave way to the fair Sun; And then Phylanter
Was on the other ide.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: Alas, Phylena, Fears are o powerfull,
That in concerned breats they govern all.

sp.speaker: Phyl.
sp.l: It is our follies that enthrones them o;
And to jut wihes hopes are much more due:
Ue them, dear Madam—

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: I need not bluh, Phylena, to confee,
(And yet I hall, whilt I am doing it)
That I have more concern for him
Than others have. VVhen you know this,
You will not judge your counell then
So eaie to be followed—

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Pardon me, Madam, if I confee,
That I believ'd as much when I advis'd you.
I have had many reaons for uch thoughts
From yours, though greater from his vertues.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: O Phylena, advie me how to do, not how to grieve.
I ee I mut be forc'd to a hard exigent,
To let him perih, or in his relief
To appear too concern'd, though not too jut.

sp.speaker: Phyl.
sp.l: Your reaon, Madam, will not have leave
To decide that; 'tis Love will be the judge
Of all his dangers. But now, Madam,
VVhat is the next thing we mut act?
Or mut we uffer too?

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: Nay, Heaven knows; I ent one to enquire.
Now—what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: They ay, Madam, they came for Mironault,
Who had deignes upon your Highnee.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: And have they taken him?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: No; but we hope they will.
He has left abundance hurt and dead.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: Go, be gone you fool; you are all upitious racalls,
Fain would be thought State-wie.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Madam.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: Be gone, you hoping Coxcomb.
There's omething more in this, Phylena.

sp.speaker: Phyl.
sp.l: I cannot guee, unlee it be Phylanter's jealouie,
Urg'd by your contant favours unto Mironault.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: Its poible. Hark, a noie; we hall be more inform'd.

div.stage: Enter Phylanter, and, being half enter'd, peaks

sp.speaker: Phyl.
sp.l: —Ecap'd—
Now by the gods your lives hall pay for all.
You dogs and Cowards—
—Madam, I humbly crave your pardon,
My paion makes me haly, when your Caue
Gives the jut anger.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: My caue, Sir?

sp.speaker: Phyla.
sp.l: Excellent Princee, Yours; for this foul man
That eem'd to pay his duty to you,
Bore in his breat a traiterous deigne
Here to urprie you; which I hearing of,
Straight hated to prevent it, though my fate
Was too unhappy in the loe of him.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: Ha!

sp.speaker: Phyl.
sp.l: But let—

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: Dot, thou not bluh, or bluh for me at leat,
That I have let thee injure Truth thus long
And wrong'd an innocence, which never dwelt
Within thy infant breat? Stay not to reply,
But leave me with your tumults.

sp.speaker: Phyl.
sp.l: Then I am lot; my lat troak now I'le trike,
And trike it bravely too—Depair,
Thou ha's the noblet iues of all ill,
Which frailty brings us to, for to be wore
We fear not, and who cannot lofe
Is ever a franck Gameter.
Nor will I fall alone, hould he enjoy her,
I hould repining dye. Envie's the vice
That never leaves us till we fall from that,
The bet ompanion of a hatie fate:
I'le cherih it as others would a Vertue.
He that declines himelf—
—when Chance or Fortune has declin'd him firt,
He learns of thoe mean helpers to do wort.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: IT was this day, Sir, that he intended the urprie;
And, notice given my on, with uch few men
As he could get in readinee, he hated thither.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: 'Tis well; but take heed there be no foul play in't.
For Mironault has ever appear'd
A ubject fit to ruine mean upitions.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Love, Sir, can alter all; none more than I
Did hear (and wonder, with a pittying thought)
This error of his hopefull Youth; but when I think
He is a Man, and Youth dwells in his veins,
That till pr • pares for Beauty and Ambition,
The eaie heart. Then look upon the Princee,
And ee in her the pain and pride of Nature,
Her freh unullied beauty, that would tempt
The gods to gaze and love; I could almot forgive—
—but mut believe.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Ha!

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: To add unto the power of Love, and alf thoe joyes
Her heavenly beauty brings a Kingdom too:
Crowns the ambition of his high-fed youth,
That makes all dangers lee, from whoe high top
They ee it leen'd in the common vale, and onely fit
To tame the pirits of the meaner minds.
—he that dares do,
Will act what his ambition tempts him to.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: I know not; I would ee jut to all, and would be afe;
And Injuries are as unpleaing to me as Injutice,
I would not bear the one, or act the other.
When malice preads a rancour in the breat,
That needs a policy to bear it forth,
The minds of Kings mot think to fit with jealouie,
As ever apt for that; believing till,
That all uch fears dwells with their height of glory.
Take heed, my Lord, that this o looe opinion
Leads not your tongue, and cats that brand on me.
I believe well of all. On farther proof
I hall think bet of you.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Would I were well off.
We have not yet (Great Sir) o little left
Of kindnes to our elves, to play with Thunder;
Nor yet o mean—
A thought of you, to let you live in danger.
Heaven knows all the ambition that now rules our thoughts;
And all we hope for that hould crown our wihes,
Is to appear loyall to you, we are as free,
(Whilt you are o from danger), as a young Lamb
From hate or malice.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Nay my Lord, you do mitake, if you believe
You uffer in my thoughts, I am prepar'd
Still to reward your care, equally o
To punih or preerve his crime, or innocence.
When Kings do fall from this, and let each wind
Conduct them with its giddinee;
Their Kingdoms at the lat, mut uffer hip-wrack.
Perhaps your innocence, may once as well
Suffer unheard, from ome malitious tongue:
I never yet harbour'd an ill opinion,
Rai'd from upition, or a meaner thought
From others envy, nor yet forget
To cherih thoe, whoe loyalties are greatet.
Jutice is till impartiall, and all Kings,
Should only hold her cales: he that trives
To weigh down one with power, is unjut
To that Great King, that put him firt in trut;

sp.speaker: Alber.
sp.l: I'me lot—

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: But my Lord; we give you thanks now for your early care,
We would have none dicourag'd, to be loyall,
'Tis that which will adorn you here,
And help you to Eternity hereafter,
Whilt men are jut, pleaing rewards will live
Within their breats; greater then I can give.

sp.speaker: Alber.
sp.l: Hee's gone.—
—I would his honety were too,
That its upon him like o fit a garment,
The workman's paid, to have the credit of it.
Hee'l help the gods to many cu •• omers.
How now!

sp.speaker: Me.
sp.l: My Lord;—

sp.speaker: Alber.
sp.l: From whence comet thou,—Ha,—
What newes? my mind mi-gives.—

sp.speaker: Me.
sp.l: From your Son.

sp.speaker: Alber.
sp.l: Why, what's the newes?

sp.speaker: Me.
sp.l: But ill,—when that your on
Had round beet the Catle, and all thought ure,
The gallant Mironault, in his fearlee mind
Weighing the bonds of death, and of an enemy,
In perfect cales; the firt appear'd the lightet,
And through one Port, bravely with his two friends,
Iued like Lightning which foretells a Clap,
And Thunder follow'd too: whilt in depight
Of their reitance, through their lives
He forc'd his way and afety.—

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: And o ecap't?

sp.speaker: Me.
sp.l: Yes, but they are till puruing; the Princee too,
When that your on appear'd, as if her eyes
Had borrow'd, rage from the afrighting danger,
That Mironault was in; upon her brow
Inthron'd it with revenge, and o with threats,
Left him unto his fears, who by me
Deires you to retire traight from Court,
Whither the Princee now directs her hate,
And march with all your forces; no other way
Is left to make Conditions. In the mean time,
He's till puruing Mironault.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: 'Tis unhappy.

sp.speaker: Mes.
sp.l: Neceity has left no other means:
Without this, he bids me tell you,
You may dye tamely.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Well, I mut go; it is the fate of guilty men,
That uch hould eek at afety through more crimes.
Men are unhappy when they know not how
To value Peace without its loe;
And from the want learn how to ue,
What they could o ill manage when enjoy'd.
Ambition gives this blindnee, yet permits
The eyes to gaze upon her tempting baits;
But in attempting, not what dangers are,
They ee the Throne, and not the blazing Star.
Thus foolih his ungovern'd youth
Has made us both alike,
Who, rather than to hare a common good,
Ventur'd through danger at uncertain glory:
Nor could my power or prayers perwade him from it.
With uch a grief the Ruler of the day
Shook his illutrious trees, when he heard
The ambitious Phaeton make his bold Requet,
—who did prefer—
Before the counell of the god himelf,
The long'd-for glories of his glittering Throne.
Yet Phoebus mourn'd, the bonds of Nature tye
Fater then our own good or honety.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: THat I had wings, Phylena; this revenge
Jutice it elf will follow.

sp.speaker: Phyl.
sp.l: Pray heaven, Madam, no deigner
Has been before us.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: It is my fear.

sp.speaker: Phyl.
sp.l: But yet,
You may be confident of your father's temper,
Which does dipence Jutice with deliberation
Beides your interet.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: Would we could learn what were become of him.
They till purue him, ure; and heaven preerve
His noble life from an untimely fate.
How the State-racalls too were pleaed
VVith the upition of a trecherous danger;
And grew as buie as a new wak't Fly,
At the firt news of Summer.

sp.speaker: Phyl.
sp.l: There is a baenee runs through all their veins,
And ranckles in their bloods, which to their children
Decends; a loath'd Inheritance.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: But who are thee?

sp.speaker: Phyl.
sp.l: A very handom peron.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: Extreamly fair, I wear; he bends this way.

sp.speaker: Amio.
sp.l: Excellent Princee—
Pardon the rude griefs of a ditreed Maid,
That throws her at your feet; for your clear eyes
(VVhich ends a comfort upon pleaed beholders)
To ee and pitty; you, that nature gave
Perfections above all; 'tis you alone
VVe mut believe excells in goodnee too.
Nothing that's ill can have o fair a dwelling.
You hall have till a Virgin's prayer,
That yours may ne're ucceslee fly
To thoe above, that thoe fair blooms
Never have cares for to diturb their calmnee,
Or force a wrincle on thoe nowy plains;
But may the beauty of a peace within,
Preerve and equall thoe your outward lutres.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: Rie, pretty Maid, you hould have ask'd and tri'd,
VVhether at firt I had been worth thee prayers.
She mut be very good that does deerve 'em
See, Phylena, flowers, I wear,
Receive not o much weetnee from freh drops,
As he from thoe. Her grief adds to her weetnee.
VVhat is it, gentle Maid, you would deire?
Promie your elf, if I can help you in't.

sp.speaker: Amio.
sp.l: The gods reward you. Let me but bluh,
And I will ay, the act may too; he is too near
That I hould tell you more. And yet, me-thinks,
He does deerve as much as I can ay;
And his caue named to my poor heart,
Seems eloquence enough to move a pitty.
Pardon my diturbed paions.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: Nay, fairet Maid—
You injure me and your own hopes together,
To keep me in upence: I would as willingly
Yield you my aid, as you could hate to ask it,
For the ble •• ubject of your fair opinion.

sp.speaker: Amio.
sp.l: I do not doubt your goodnee; pardon the throng
Of all my tedious griefs. Know then,
You bet of Princees, for ure his name
Has reach'd your ears, the unhappy Mironault,
That much deerv'd to live, is like to fall
By bloody and unworthy hands.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: O Phylena! I'me lot.
In that beauty is all my comfort buried.

sp.speaker: Phyl.
sp.l: Madam, what do you mean?
Madam, for heaven's ake; why, Madam?

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: I prethee let me go, thou art too cruell.
I hall enjoy peace unditurb'd hereafter.

sp.speaker: Phyl.
sp.l: But hear her out, and do but earch the truth,
Then I will let you die. I would not for the world
Any hould guee the caue.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: Alas!

sp.speaker: Phyl.
sp.l: Why, if they do, they cann't condemn the grief.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: O Phylena, when Love has entred in the outward Forts,
Yet there is till a mall reerve of Reaon,
Which Love laughs at, rather than thinks it worth
His rage or torming; for he knows it mut
Perih and tarve, when the relief
Of all the nobler Faculties are kept out
By the inulting Conqueror, who contemns
All the attempts I fain would make againt him.

sp.speaker: Amio.
sp.l: I ee I am decreed to all misfortunes,
That I hould now diturb you too, who, heaven knows,
I willingly would pleae. Why do you turn
Away your head? How often have I heard
His prayers ent to heaven for your joys,
That now denies to look upon his woes?
I'le kneel again, for in uch a caue
It were impiety to rie ucceelee.
Nothing but Seas and Winds are deaf to prayers,
And Beats to mercy; who would expect
A hidden form in unditurbed skies?
Or in that clearer breat a cruelty?
If you deny, I'le grow a fixed Monument,
Still to upbraid your rigour.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: O Phylena, why do you let me languih?
In her beauty dwells an undoing lutre.

sp.speaker: Phyl.
sp.l: What mean you, Madam? can you believe
The world can hew a ubject for your jealouie?

sp.speaker: Amio.
sp.l: I ee I grow a trouble, I durt have worn
You had been more charitable. How often have I heard
The now unpittied Mironault affirm,
You were the treaure of this world's perfections;
And wondred any thing but your fair elf
Should know what joys were. Perhaps you too
Believe as much, or ele you could not think
All his unpittied micries are jut. Had Nature
Given you a Brother, and your early loves
Blet unditurb'd from Nature's fruitfull Cradle,
You would have begg'd—as now—
His hopelee iter does.
But ure I hould have pittied more.
And yet perhaps our interets makes us partiall:
Yes I could wih I had your power to try.

sp.speaker: Phyl.
sp.l: Now, Madam—

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: Forgive me, gentle Maid; it was the power
Of thy told griefs that eiz'd my faculties,
And left me able to do nought but grieve.
Forgive the time I lot to hare with thee:
You may forgive the injuries of kindnee.
And though my elf were witnee to the action
Thy griefs made it a new afflicting tory.
Each torm renews in Merchants minds
The tory of the hipwrack. Nor do I bluh
To avow this, ince I mut not loe
The jutnee of my breat, that does believe
His innocence above upition.

sp.speaker: Amio.
sp.l: May heaven inpire you to wih well,
And grant your wihes too, you might have then,
Perhaps, a joy as great as he would have,
Did he but know you pitty him.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: In the performance then of what I ay,
He will have more; which I o much wih him
That you hall witnee all purued with hate.
Nor hall you be a tranger longer to me.
Yet I hall bluh, although I give you leave
To ee the partiality: but more time
Now pent in gras or leaves, would be his injury.
And we may ruine, what we would relieve,
