Should we without attempting uccour grieve.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: WOuld I were a Dog, and could lick my elf whole.
I hall be as fly-blown, as a ruine cheee,
How i't Hyppaus!

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: But curvy, would we might ret.

sp.speaker: Miro.
sp.l: O me;
'Tis an unhappinee, that I hould bring
You into thee misfortunes, you have deerved
Better of me, and yet you may forgive me,
I would have hared as much with you.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: We would not make uch an excue then, Sir.

sp.speaker: Miro.
sp.l: You chide me nobly, I find, I need ome ret.
And yet by all thoe powers, that caued thee michiefs,
My life hall end them, e're I'le be his prioner.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Nay, wee'l all dye; I hope 'tis no offence
To talk of aving our weet lives;
In order to that, this next fair houe
Mut be our Garrion, 'tis ten to one,
But there we find ome three or four brown loaves,
To victuall us for a day; perhaps a ample
Of good eed-Corn, lies in the parlour Cubbard;
We hall eat moderately, come we mut advance
And torm it.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: You have no other way Sir, we are o weak,
There is no refuge ele, and we are till
Hotly purued, if they intend our michiefs,
VVe may hold out againt that petty number
If they raie more, we too hall have relief
By the Princee, or your friends; if not,
VVe may make ome Conditions.—

sp.speaker: Miro.
sp.l: A wretched hift, and yet it may preerve us,
But let us ue it nobly: Heaven guide us.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: I'le advance, and knock: Within there
Ho!
He truck o hard, the baon broke,—
Ho! what a Tarquin's here,

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: VVho have we here?

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Two or three trangers that have lot their way.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: And you would be directed.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Pox on your nimble Charity;
We have been ett upon by thieves, and hurt,
And mut deire ome mall refrehment.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Why, this 'tis; The age is grown o perfect now,
That all fall's in the way of Begging,
And by the word Refrehment.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Nay, Sir, none of your moralities on the age,
Help us to the peech of the Mater,
Or Mitris of the houe, It mut be o, Sir;

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Here's neither.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: What the Devil i't.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: A Lady.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Plague on your formall Coxcomb.
Lets ee your Lady then,

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: That's more then hee'l do you.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: By this light, but he hall.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Had he worn o, he had been for-worn;

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Sir, we would willingly be Civill,
Pray let's receive your Ladie's anwer,
But no more of yours:

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: You hall have it.—

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: This Rogue has bagg pipes in his Lungs.
A meer Land-Remora, we wanted but the plague
To have heard his pedigree;
He had learn't the policy of the old Roman,
To ruine by delayes; we might have fainted
Under his wie Cunc-tator-hip.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: 'Twas a rare Scene, be ure, Pyenor,
You hall have none of the bet drink.

sp.speaker: Miro.
sp.l: VVhen he comes, you hall be chief,
And we your humble ervants.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: And I'le be inolent enough: now Sir,
For uch a Bird as the Princee.

sp.speaker: Miro.
sp.l: Nay Pyenor.—

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Hang it, this love, 'twill make your wounds ranckle.
There's nothing like a merry plaiter.
Hark, I hear them ruling,
Mercy on us, what have we here,
December, with the too curvy months at her heels?
She ha's dig'd up all her ancetors;
And wrap't their winding heets about her,
I'le advance.

sp.speaker: Caeca.
sp.l: VVhere tands he, Peter

sp.speaker: Peter.
sp.l: Straight on; now mut not I proceed
For fear I hould dicover, he were blind.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: VVhither a divell will he march
Hippaus, lie down in the way,

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: And be hanged, put on your erious face,

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Save you weet Reverence.

sp.speaker: Caeca.
sp.l: Are you the Gentleman? Peter, is this he?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Yes, forooth.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Slight, hee'd have her man make affidavit of it,
VVe are thoe Madam, that would fain obtain
Some pitty in your eyes,—why,—hee's blind,
Blind, as an old Do-Cunny.—
VVe want a Charity, and we hope
That your grave years, ha's taught you that fair tory,

sp.speaker: Caeca.
sp.l: From whence come you?

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: VVe are Gentlemen, and have been hurrby thieves.
You need not fear to help our hard misfortunes,
Our weak Conditions cannot threaten danger,
You may believe, we would deerve your kindnee,
And our lives, which if you preerve,
Shall wait upon your beauty.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: What a diembling tongue the rogue has,

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: We went as long, as we could gain a leave
From weaknee, as unwilling—
To be a burthen to any, but our fates
Threw us on you, for which we dare not chide them.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: This rogue would court a bitch—

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Sirrah, I'le fit you.—

sp.speaker: Caeca.
sp.l: A fine well-poken gentleman.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: For if we did, we hould be too unjut
For you mut needs be good, becaue the gods
Let you o long live to intruct the world,
—Or ele afraid of your blind company—
But at your feet—
We throw our elves and all our mieries,
And cancell fear, whilt we exp • ct to hear
Our doom from your fair lips.

l.hi: Quinever.
Madam.

sp.speaker: Caeca.
sp.l: I't a handome man?

sp.speaker: Quin.
sp.l: Yes indeed, as e're I aw.

sp.speaker: Caeca.
sp.l: I feel jut uch a Qualm, as I had
When I was till falling in love, he has a weet tongue.
Noble gentleman, you're very welcome;
You hall have all you want, pray come neer:
Indeed, I am much taken with your peech,
'Tis very curteous, once in my youth
I undertood thee complements,
And have not yet forgot them;
I hall remember them more freh
If you repeat them.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Why o, I hall be engaged to tell tales
In the chimney-corner.

sp.speaker: Caec.
sp.l: Peter, Go in, get the bet chambers ready;
Let them have omething preently to eat.
Pray come • n, you'r very welcom.
Your hand, good Sir.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: We are your ervants. Now do I walk
Like the great Turk, that newly has put out
The eyes of an old kinwoman. Here we hall find
Good Fortune ure, for that whore too is blind.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: HOw much unknown is reall happinee?
And all are cheated with the name of thing?
Or we are all deceiv'd, or ele the joy
Grows poor by the enjoyment; to me
A Crown's a glorious miery,
Supition waits on all our appetites,
And leep not pleaes but affrights.
Kings have hard ways for to preerve a Crown,
To give to others fears, and hide their own.
The way's but narrow between frowns and miles,
To avoid both Contempt and Tyranny.
For either is a Rock to plit upon
This glorious and frail Bark of Majety;
When-People do not ask, and yet Kings give,
Content and afety with them both may live.
But when they venture to reform the State,
Princes mut uffer then
By their own fears, or by their people's hate.
They hide till what they mean in a redree,
And know ill acts are buried with uccee.
Seek peace in torms, and in diorder afety,
—Till in a Chaos they have felt
Contraint and Freedom unditinguiht dwelt.
Their firt fond way to reach at Liberty
Is, to aault thoe they believe too high.
And had the gods not Thunder, ure there are
That would attempt—
—to light a Candle at a Star.
But Kings, like Suns, that at ome time mut pay
Their lutres in another Sphear, mut leave
Stars fitted with influence to direct this night.
—Yet, like the Queen of Night, to know,
That to his beams their lutre they do owe.
O Symathocles, you'r welcom; Did you dipatch
What I directed you?

sp.speaker: Sym,
sp.l: I did, Sir; and the Troops were marching,
But the arrivall of the Princee prevented.

sp.speaker: Kin
sp.l: Is he come, then?

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.l: But now arrived, Sir.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: 'Tis well, Symathocles.
You have heard ure of the late accident:
'Tis odd; What think you?

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.l: 'Tis hard to guee, Sir, eaier far to doubt.
The Princee mut inform us all.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: I have upended too my thoughts in this.
Hate is an ill companion till to Jutice.
And whilt we hear at ditance things unprov'd,
The tory of their lives prevails till mot,
That has been fair in Mironault. Yet our frailty
Guides us to unupected acts, o may the bet of men
Fall to the leat upected crimes; that weaknee
Crows with our years, and alteration • s till
By Nature nur • .

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.l: You have weighed, great Sir,
Things in o jut and erious a cale,
That whilt thus evenly you preerve your mind,
You'l need no other Oracle; mean haty fears
Still tyranny begets, non can deerve
Their afety, that attempt it that way
That poorly tells the world, he fears the reach
Of common hands; none but the Eagles gaze
Upon the Sun, unlee it hrinck in clowds.
Nor do the common eyes attempt your glories,
Till hrouded in your fears. He's till mot afe
That tells the world, He cannot be in danger,
For they'l believe it then, and 'tis mot jut,
If they will borrow fears, that he hould trut.
Jutice will then be ripe, when every thought
Takes its low birth neither from fear nor paion.
And 'twill be fruit worthy a King to bear,
And bles the appetites of them that gather.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: You have hit my thoughts; See,
Here comes more Information.
I'le ee if he'l begin.
—Rie, you are welcom.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: I mut not, Sir, till I receive
—more then a common Bleing—
Your Jutice is enough to cae my fears.
Yet pardon me, if o much of Woman rules me,
To tell you all I uffer'd.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: What mean you?

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: Great Sir, you might believe indeed
I hould be unditurb'd, where you procure
Peace from your carefull thoughts. And ure it was
The child of Inolence and high Contempt
That curt attempt the ruden • e.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: It was o, but to the matter.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: When at my journey's end I was arrived,
Thither came Mironault in his own language
To pay a duty which he owed your child;
Where being carcely reted, and reolved
With the next riing Sun to eek our port,
But word was brought, the Catle was urrounded
By Soldiers, commanded by Phylanter;
Their buinee was for Mironault, w • o they aid
Went to urprie me there, who onely came
With two brave friends, and I dare wear with thoughts
As innocent as Infants; when he heard
The Catle was be-et, eriouly weighing
Not Jutice ought his life but Treachery,
Didain'd to fall upon o mean a core.
As an ungovern'd Torrent iues forth,
Bearing down all before it, and in the action
Finds its unknown power, when its treams
Are with a top reited, o're-whelming
What was believ'd beyond its power before.
So from reitance his didaining rage
Atchiev'd a victory, which his thoughts
Would ne're have hop'd nor aim'd at; till Philanter's rage
Purues his noble life. This is enough
Whilt you are jut, nor need I to repeat
The injury to me.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: But they perhaps
Might have a ecret meage of the intent
Of Mironault, you would be loath I ee
To have one tetifie as much.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: You cannot find one o extreamly bad,
So far from being to himelf a friend;
His tory in the world has nobler truths,
Than to be fouled by any bae accuer.
If all were true, it is your jutice ure,
And not their furie, that hould punih.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: For farther atisfaction of you; Who waits there?
Go call the Lord Albertus hither.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: In this petition too, Sir, oyns with me
This Maid, who from one womb
With the unhappy Mironault took her birth:
You will have many knees as he has hearts;
And yet none needs to beg, for you are jut:
Yet you mut pardon thoe loves that mix with fears.
We oftner then we need wipe pretious Jewells.
His value makes us foolih.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: He is beholding to you—
How now—

sp.speaker: Me.
sp.l: The Lord Albertus, Sir, is fled
As oon as he came from your Majety,
He intantly took Hore.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: He was in hate—Symathocles—

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.l: Sir.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Gather the Forces in a readinee
That were to meet my daughter, then wait
For further Orders.

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.l: I hall, Sir.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Your pardon, fair Maid, that I eem'd o to forget you;
It onely was my care, you hall have jutice
And hould have had without an Advocate,
Your beauty though's a great one.

sp.speaker: Amio.
sp.l: The gods preerve your Majety, with your years
May peace till grow, that give it unto others,
Till you hall go to have eternall ret.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Thanks, gentle Maid, the rich Arabian Fumes
Are not o weet to the delighted gods,
As thy calm prayers from thy harmlee breat.
Come hither, Mirramente, I have not been
At leiure yet to bid thee kindly welcom.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: Pardon me, Sir, that I mut once again
Trouble your ears, nor think too lightly, Sir,
Of my requet, it is the child of gratitude.
I would in peron, Sir, relieve
Him, that has uffer'd for my ake,
And in my ight contemn'd.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Symathocles, would you not take it ill
To have a Generall put o're your head?

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.l: Not, if it may erve you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Look here, Symathocles, this Amazon has begg'd it.

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.l: She does the better, Sir, if there be danger
From her fair name we all hall fight in afety.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Well, take your coure, on more intelligence
Move as you pleae.

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.l: Excellent Princee,
—How happy I am now to be your Soldier,
Let thoe be judge that would be ure of victory.
So fair a Caue fought by o fair a Generall,
—Can never be foraken
By Victory or Fortune—

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: I thank you, Sir, nor can I think my elf
Lee happy in o brave a Soldier; if you pleae
For to dipatch before for ome intelligence,
Wee'l intantly away.

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.l: With all peed, Madam.

sp.speaker: Amio.
sp.l: Excellent Princee;
Which way to tell you all my heart returns
I know not, the gods in bleings thank you,
Who till ait the innocent and mean,
Becaue they made them o;

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: I thank you gentle Maid, from hence my friend,
You cannot cheat my confidence, you'l deerve it,
So does your Brother all my bet aitance,
I reckon it my happinee, to procure
Your joyes and afety; that I may then
Have mine more perfect.

sp.speaker: Amio.
sp.l: Now all the powers defend, they hould not be:
You never ure broke yet an houres repoe
With a di • urbing dream; in that calme harbour,
All thoughts have been ecur'd from torm,
May they be ever o.—

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: Thy brother's caue deerves as much as that.
—A thouand bluhes top me,—
Beides thou mayet be much deceived: the hip-wrack pat,
The calmet waters may conceal the fate,
As well as the inulting waves,
—Why do • t thou weep.—

sp.speaker: Amio.
sp.l: To hear, you have been ad, O Madam,
• ardon me, to ay an undicerned power
Ioynes my affliction to your grief;
Forgive me that, I cannot chue but dare,
To accompany you in any thing.
There's omething tells me, that I ought to love you
More then the world does, yet that's very much.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: When I firt aw thee, dearet maid,
I could have worn as much,
And yet thou didt not pleae me then,
Come, I hall diturb thee, 'tis an unkindnee
Not to be pardon'd, to let thee hare my griefs;

sp.speaker: Amio.
sp.l: Now you afflict me more: Is there a way,
To be a friend and tranger to your breat,
Though 'tis ambition, to be an humble one?
'Tis vertue, not your greatnee crowns my wihes,
And I hall fear, that you will think me only
A friend to that, or ele not worth the other.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: I do not doubt thy Love, the tory will
Diturb me, when I tell it, perhaps thee,
And yet it mut return to me unhelpt.

sp.speaker: Amio.
sp.l: How do you know? the meanet thing in nature,
May bring an unexpected aid; Gyants that pae,
And lets the obtacles alone, do lee
Then dwarfs that do remove them: as they are
Shut in your breat, fed with that pretious food,
How can they ever tarve? they may at lat
Conume your tock of joyes, he does like you,
That would defend, within a fair built Fort,
His enemies againt his preing friends
And patiently detroyed by thoe he aved,
If you believe me worthy, the gods have then
Finih't their parts; for they decreed us mot
To one anothers aid: So to encreae
Our joyes that way, and leen all our cares,
For till imparted comforts do increae,
And grief divided to a friend grows lee,
Our natures too are like o'rec • arged prings,
Willing to vent themelves, and o are you,
Had I but as much worth, as you have trouble.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: I am not proof againt thy perfect kindnee,
I will keep nothing from thee, but be ure
You quickly undertand me, my bluhes too
Will tell t • ee half the torie, what dos't guee?

sp.speaker: Amio.
sp.l: That you hould have no cares—

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: Can love have any?

sp.speaker: Amio.
sp.l: What in this world hall ever be o happy?
I hope it is not that—

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: And why?

sp.speaker: Amio.
sp.l: A thouand times I have heard my brother pray
That day might never be, I wih as he does too.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: Your Brother would not have me then?
—How innocent he is!—

sp.speaker: Amio.
sp.l: He thinks it were unreaonable
That one alone hould make the world unhappy.
Weighing their own misfortunes from his joy's
I hope it is not that:

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: 'Tis that I wear. Love has caued all my trouble,
And if thy brother thinks me uch a bleing
Why doth not he then wih it?

sp.speaker: Amio.
sp.l: Alas he dares not welcome uch a thought
He onely dares to wih none ele hould have you;
But who mut be o happy?

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: Your Brother.

sp.speaker: Amio.
sp.l: Madam?

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: Wonder no more, I could have told
When I firt aw thee that me-thought I lov'd thee
As I would do a iter; yet I was jealous too:
Nay I hall bluh, as much as thou cant wonder,
Yet he deerves my Love; ure you did then
Read a confuion in me; and I am till,
Diorderd by my fears;

sp.speaker: Amio.
sp.l: O Madam,—
—Pardon me to ay the gods have jutly o
Decreed that it hould be: for I have heard
Him it and pleae himelf with tories of you,
Till he has made his griefs too montrous,
And I thought then too prodigall of comfort,
Yet now I think't was all but due to you;
And though I am turnd of his religion too
And can think nothing upertition in't,
Yet you may pare the acrifice.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: Sweetet maid,
I have ome reaon to believe he loves me,
He cannot ure diemble; Wert thou ne're yet in love?

sp.speaker: Amio.
sp.l: Never;

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: Pray that thou never mayt, or that it ne're
Have fears for it's Companions, night will wear
Diturbing blacknee and not quiet hades,
The light will be too cheerfull, whilt you fare
Like an impatient Sea-man that would fain
Attain the Port, the gentlet calm
Makes mad, and croing torms diturbs
But from our own experience thus we raie
Advices that are chid and and corn'd by Fate
Who oftnet ends what we leat wih, and makes
What we mot covet mot unfortunate:
But now to his relief, for time
Perues his coure with an impartiall hate
And my revenge mut it upon his wings.
You Powers above what now is jut ait:
Their thoughts were poor, that trifled time and wiht.

sp.speaker: Mir • .
sp.l: TO be till ubject to calamities,
We all mut bear: yet not eteem it hard
Our frailty ets this odds from higher powers,
And their di-orders are appeas'd by ours,
It is a hard injunction of the gods
To et our natures and our elves at odds
When they afflict though due unto our crimes,
Yet they give to the nature that repines
Though if we ue it well, none but they give
That bleing, that we are dipleas'd to live
'Twas life firt couned man, and did entice
By knowledge its fair gift to cheat him twice;
Man was a happy tranger to himelf,
When he believ'd his ignorance his wealth;
Did thee Extreams our knowledge ne're employ
VVe hould have lee of cares, though le • of joy,
For in the mind, they never gain a height
From their own natures but each others weight;
Thus truly man has either more or lee,
From what he had, not what he does poee.
As if the god's would give us nothing here
VVorthy of our affections, but our fear,
For hould we fall from happinee the tore
Makes us more wretched of thoe joy's before.
Such a dieae is life we hold o dear,
Health's in the other world, our Phyick here;
—O—Hyppous—what's to be done
Fortune has trangely jaded us—

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: Heaven knows: I am confident we are perued,
The houe is trong, had we but any men
VVe might reit their numbers, and by that time
They have upplies, we may have too relief.

sp.speaker: Miro.
sp.l: Where's Pyander?

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: Shifting from the old blind Lady, who follows him
As if he were her dog and led her,
And as the devil would hav'it, her reverend blindnes
Is at a venter • am in love

sp.speaker: Miro.
sp.l: We mut reolve of ome thing, and whats mot hard
In ignorance, and without any aid: o may a hip,
With wounds in pieces torn, expect as well
To ail or fight;—
—And yet me thinks there might be made
Some ue of this Pyander's fooling.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: By the Mae it's true, he has Tenants
That were obliged, without all doubt to ait her
In the holy War; they live here till they dye
Of the infection of old age; ee Sir,
Where Pyander comes marching with her maid.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Let's conceal our elves a little, and oberve.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Nay, by this light I'le ne're lye for the matter.
If thou hat no faith • hou'lt be damn'd.

sp.speaker: Quin.
sp.l: Say you o, Sir?

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: How couldt thou chue but guee it? didt thou e're know
A dunghill without a Cock upon't. Meer ympathy
Guides me to love thee, dot thou not find
Some uch kind of thing for me?

sp.speaker: Quin.
sp.l: Indeed I have a grudging towards you.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: The devill take up the quarrell.
Nay 'tis grown to that I dream on thee,
Me-thought lat night I rode a Flanders Mare,
And every night I dream of a freh Beat,
And then I think on thee.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: What means the Rogue?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Peace, on my life he has ome farther purpoe.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: Lord how he I wells, hold a tick of fire to her
And he'l pie.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: But ince I love you o, you mut ait me
In what I told you, for I hould be loath
Now to be taken from thee; and I know
The racalls will attempt the houe for me.
This can be brought about no other way,
But by report that I hould marry
Thy Lady, for then all her Tenants
Will be the willinger to ait me.
But all this while thou halt be dear Lindabrides,
Thou halt rule and govern; and for thy comfort
Above pragmaticall Peter; and, by this hand,
If he at all croe us in this deigne,
I'le hang a thouand crackers at his britch,
Then throw him off from ome high Tower,
In a high wind, hung between bladders;
And all this for thy love.

sp.speaker: Quin.
sp.l: And will you till be contant?

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: As a Bell, till in one Tune:
And that we may be uddain, and I afe
To follow our Amours, perwade thy Lady
And intantly conduct her this way.

sp.speaker: Quin.
sp.l: I'le take my leave firt—

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Slid, her lips are lin'd with Coier's wax,
She kis'd me in a full Career.
Sure he has hoarded up a tore of onyons
In her dry chaps, to butter againt winter.
The Devill's troubled but with one Dam, I have two
—And there's a formall Weathercock,
They look which way the wind its by him,
That from deliberation fetches widom;
And when he gapes at bed-time, 'tis a clinch
For my blind Mitree now, whoe chaps are mew'd
Of all their teeth, which yet he hopes again
Will pring like a fell'd Copice, and from the gums
New prouts hoot up, he's almot deaf,
Would he were dumb too, for her tongue's oblig'd
To upply other organs, and tells us all
Her life, perhaps the Hitory
Of twenty years a time—This thing
Mut I make love to, with brevity and eae.
I'le go through all the cenes of Courthip with her,
She hall have Serenades on an old Jews-trump,
That was Pirk-abboths, an emblem of antiquity,
And all my little Oaths hall be
By Cupid's Eye and hers, the Devill's in't
If I am then forworn—O how now,
What are you bolted? Come Gentlemen,
What's to be done? Hyppaus, thou wert wont
To be nimble at udden chances.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: How inolent the Rogue is? now he thinks
We know not his deign.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Nay, Pyander, we referr'd all to you,
We onely are your poor friends.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Well, a Mathematician would not have breath enough
To tell the kindnee of my Starrs—

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: But for this rare fortune—

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Why my old veell is ailing this way,
When he appears, tand cloe
And you hall hear it.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Come I conceive, and did over-hear
Some of your policy, and believ't
There is no other way to ave us now.
If we can get but men, 'tis but throwing
A work up in two places, the other parts
Are trong enough.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: That hall be my care too, but when you ee
The old Beldam comming, be ure you vanih.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: We mut be quick, our time has traitned us.
As oon as they can have intelligence
They will be here.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: What if we could end away to Court?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: I'le rather perih than believe I can
Be worth her care.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: VVhy thanks then to Pyander
That believes himelf—
VVorthy his own—

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: VVould her Ladihip were come.
Prethee Pyander let's have no time delay'd
In asking how he does, and what's a clock.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Thou hat reaon to be more confident of my wit.
—See where they come—
And like the Graces leading one another.
Let's over-hear a little.

sp.speaker: Caec.
sp.l: Indeed he is a proper Gentleman,
And 'tis great pitty he hould uffer.

sp.speaker: Quin.
sp.l: It is indeed, I would not for my Maidenhead
It hould be in your houe.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Nor I by this light.

sp.speaker: Caec.
sp.l: I think as much; indeed he peaks as well
As any that I knew thee ix King's Reigns:
VVhere is he, Quinever?

sp.speaker: Quin.
sp.l: He aid he would be hereabouts.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: Now Pyander uncouple them.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: So I may be hunted, but I'le advance.
—Save your weet Ladihip—
I took the boldnee, urged by my love,
To trouble your kind ears with a petition.

sp.speaker: Caec.
sp.l: You'r very welcome, I hall be glad to hear it;
And though I am old, and people think decay'd,
I can tell how to judge a worthy Gentleman.
Hey ho, in my time I have heard many complements,
And blet was he could gain but a good look.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: He hall be damn'd now that does.

sp.speaker: Caec.
sp.l: The world and I am alter'd.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: A Carthuian wear the world is,
—I'le wear for thee.

sp.speaker: Caec.
sp.l: And yet I have warm blood now in my veins,
And it will beat ometimes: I have heard men ay,
That age has vigour lies within.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: She'l tell me by and by he can fart fire.

sp.speaker: Caec.
sp.l: And o indeed—

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: I mut interrupt her; But you forget
To hear what your poor ervant asks.

sp.speaker: Caec.
sp.l: I pray what is't?

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Firt I mut beg you, that you'l have the confidence
To believe, I love you; old Lutes
Still ound the weetet; many a man
Has travailed many miles, and tedious wayes,
To ee a leer monument, and ince I love you,
I would preerve my happinee, ure you ought then
To return equall kindnee.

sp.speaker: Caeca.
sp.l: By my troth, but jutice, and indeed, I will,
I hall not be o cruell to grieve you long
So worthy a kind gentleman; I eteem
A tedious coynee vice, you put me in mind
Of my old principles, in my Grand-mother's time.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: That's according to a new account,
Three hundred years before the world begun.

sp.speaker: Caeca.
sp.l: And as I was aying in her time
Matters were quickly ended, I am till
Of the old fahion.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: In hort, then, ince you ee I love you,
I mut beg your aitance; for thee rogues
That hurt us, as I hear, are now hard by.
Your Tenants, and a few ervants would with eae
Defend us from thee wanderers, that I may
Enjoy my happinee with afety. This your Commands
With eae may finih, and I blee
The fate that brought me hither.

sp.speaker: Caeca.
sp.l: I pray your elfe command them,
You hall have full power, that in time
Mut be my husband.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Plague on your nimblenee, how he mumps,—

sp.speaker: Caeca.
sp.l: When my lat husband Sir Percivall died,
I little thought to have had another uiter;
But you men have the power to winn us,
And I can tell you, uch a tempting Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: For ought he knows, a Sign-pot
With Friar Bacon's brazen head upon't,—
—If you pleae Madam, I will attend you,
When your Commands have etled us in afety,
I hall preume to tell you my Love's tory.

sp.speaker: Caeca.
sp.l: I hall be glad to hear it, pray lead on,
What you Command, hall be a law.—

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Yet Hyppaus, we breathe; and afety now
Begins to wear an eaie hape.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: The rogue has work't them finely.—

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: By Heaven, he is the bet compoed man,
I e're yet knew, for in the wort extreams,
His cheerfulnee, and judgment is the ame;
We are prepared; if they find us now,
Phylanter's bold to bring them on to action,
Fortune but guide, an equall word to mine,
And borrow frowns from all the detinies
To hang upon thy then contemned brows.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: But I believe, they never will attempt us
But econded with more, for they will fear
What may proceed from Court.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Never believe, he would attempt this action,
But with ome feigned tory to my prejudice.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: But the Princee, Sir, eem'd to reent the injury,
She is too noble, meanly to upect.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Alas, Hyppaus, they before corrupted
His goodnee that hould incline to her,
Thee flatterers beet the thoughts of Kings,
As an ill enemy beieges Towns,
Firt poions the fair prings.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: Thee are the wort of fears, we may as well
Hope, that his judgment corns unlikely tories.
But let the wort that fortune can prepare
Fall unregarded on us, the leat defence
Will help us to the noblet fare.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Nobly reolved.—
sp.l: And when we fall o brave,
The world will find more loe, then we can have.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: NAy, you had bet teach her to beat a drum,
Do you think to make her now an old blind Amazon.
We hall have the Sheriff to end warrants for u • ,

sp.speaker: Quin.
sp.l: Lord, how wie you are good Peter, at leat
You would fain • em o, I can tell, I'me ure,
Where you have all your wienee.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Where, good Quinever?

sp.speaker: Quin.
sp.l: All your law, out of the two old leaves
That lye behind the parlour-cupbord;
Piece, they ay, of an old Stature book,
Which has been rotting there thee twenty years.
And for your other talk, 'tis taken out
Of your old Erra-pater; and you, forcoth,
Mut eem to be more wie then all of us.
I'me ure, when you made love to me,
And once were out of thee two trodden roades,
You could not peak a word, but jut, How do you.
And that repeated over with variety,
Of curvy tones, nay.—

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Why, art thou mad, or dot thou think it fit,
My Lady, hould defend all wandring trangers,
And enter into warres? I am reolved
To change my tation, they are digging up earth
Before the Gates, I can't pae by,
But I mut think of graves, men too brought in,
I think, to fill them.

sp.speaker: Quin.
sp.l: Hang your heep's face, I ee that now 'tis fear,
That your wie worhip with your wonted eae,
Should not at leiure drink your morning draught,
And at the Alehoue for two pots
Hear your elfe praied,
And bribe a man to come to you for counell
That never had need of any, you have worn your Gloves out
With biting your thumbs ends, to appear wie.
All this put together, got from my Lady's pure,
Thou hat been as chargeable as a Regiment.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Why, Mrs. Quinever, ure you once had
Better opinions of me, though you now
Wah every day your bet handkerchief
With yellow tarch, and your lac'd quoiff,
Till it now hangs as if the devill
Had righted you through quicketts, not a pot
But mut be beaten for the rotten powder
To make your hair it well, and all in hopes
That ome of thee hould fall in love with you.
I vas once thought worthy, then I was honet Peter.

sp.speaker: Quin.
sp.l: Marry come up, what, love that tranparent noe of thine
That gives the Serenades when thou leepet?
Or thy wide mouth like a dead Lobter's claws,
Or thy tarcht ruff like a new Pigeon-houe,
Your garters tied above your boots; as if you feard
Your leg o well provided would be gone.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Why I thank you weet Mitree Quin • ver go on
And be all mad whiles I lament you ober:
Nay you hall fight by your elves for Peter,
You'le make an excellent ammunition-Girle
Get a bottle to carry hot water in, in time
You may arie to be a Sutler's wife.

sp.speaker: Quin.
sp.l: I'le have your wie head fitted for all this
And heer comes one hall do it.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: O weet Mitree Quinever

sp.speaker: Quin.
sp.l: No fawning now you whelp.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Mrs. Quinever well met, I was eeking you.

sp.speaker: Quin.
sp.l: I am happy I have found you.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: How go matters? we have got ome 50. men.

sp.speaker: Quin.
sp.l: All goes well: but this wie Gentleman
(Whoe wit lies in his breeches, for 'tis all
He has to know when he has need)
Is much dipleaed at our preparations,
And asks me if you mean to make
My Lady a blind drummer

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: And cannot you convert him?

sp.speaker: Quin.
sp.l: No indeed.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: VVhy thou ingratefull piece of wie formality,
How oft hat thou had warning to be wie?
I have threatned thee thou hould't never go
Without a rime-pind at thy back
Which hould be thy own grievous Chronicle.
I told thee too that I would have thee painted
Riding upon an Ae and reading Seneca,
I thought this might have tyed thy tongue.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Good Sir:

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Nay hear and mark me, if thou dot • r'e again
Seem to be wier than thou art, and croe
What now is done, nay if thou dos't not help
And put thy aiting hand to't, thou halt ride
In a hot day upon a well lined adle
With oap in thy new grogram-breeches, till it work
Like new tunnd beer, and every day
When thou itt down to dinner one or other
Shall pull away thy tool, I'le poil thy gravity,
Or noint thy feet with butter, whilt a dog
Shall lick and tickle thee, and if any comes
Here to oppoe us thou halt eem a tratagem:
For on the walls we'le et thee, like a thing
Stuft up with traw, onely to make them pend
Their hot upon thee, and in thy turn
Thou halt do duty too, and every night,
Be ure to have alarmes. Speak what you'le do.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: I did but utter my opinion: I hall conform.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: It's well aid, and I forgive you,
But take heed you erre no more.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: You need not doubt me.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Come wench, now we breathe in afety,
And thou proud Peter's conquerour.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: The Devill go with you; he has conjured me.
Did ever Turk think of o many torments,
And in what order too he marhal'd them?
I am not yet out of a chilling weat;
Nor hall I get now of enchanted Quinever
One drop of good hot water, God deliver me
From this trange hurly-burly; and yet I dare not fancy
A good trong halter and a handom beam
I'le go to leep, for I am now
Afraid of all things.

sp.speaker: Phyl.
sp.l: THe intelligence is certain they are here,
At an old Ladies, and all hurt; we cannot mie them.

sp.speaker: Lyc.
sp.l: Thoe that I left preparing now come up
Make us 400. trong, your father too
Follows with more.

sp.speaker: Phy.
sp.l: We mut attempt them (though) before relief
Can poibly arrive from any place,
And if we take him we are ure to make
Our own conditions, the bet we can expect:
Our reolutions arm us for the ret.

sp.speaker: Lyc.
sp.l: We are prepared and I believe there's few,
That erve you, quetion policy or danger.

sp.speaker: Phy.
sp.l: Ye nobly all oblige me, and for your akes
I could even wih I never had attempted
What I mut corn now meanly to repent of
But ill intents when they leat proper
Then mu • t be mot perued, to reach again
Our firt condition,

sp.speaker: Lyc.
sp.l: Nay Sir, I think it were no harm,
To wih us fairly off.

sp.speaker: Phyl.
sp.l: I would we were, but I am arm'd;
To dye I fear not, and yet I would
Fall with ome pretty character about me,
At leat I'le make the Kingdom joy
It had o brave a pirit, and like Rome glory
(In pight of fame) in Catiline who died
At once men's envie, and her pride,

sp.speaker: Lyc.
sp.l: VVe mut looe no time Sir, the night
Conceales us, and as yet perhaps
They have had no intelligence,
The houe is neer at hand—hall we parly?

sp.speaker: Phyl.
sp.l: 'Tis the bet way to find their confidence
Nor can it be a prejudice to us; we traffick now
Onely for what we'ave lot: "If we urvive
"We'le find at leat a nobler way to thrive.

div.head: ACT 3. SCEN. 4.
div.stage: Enter Pyander, two or three with him.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: SO that work's now finih'd.
Let all the guns be brought into the Hall,
'Tis to defend the good old Lady
From the rudenee of Rogues; 'twill be caie work.

sp.p: Yes, yes, wee'l tickle them.
I'le weep 'em with my father's old Fouling-piece.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Bravely reolved; but perhaps.
There may be yet no need on't, however
'Tis wiet to reolve againt all dangers.
VVell, my good Lads, be in a readinee, if any come,
VVee'l ring 'em a peal hall make 'em forwear
Such Holi-daies: they all die rather than wrong
Sir Percivall's widow. Now all unto your places.

sp.p: Agreed, agreed.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Now could I hug my genius, that through all
Has brought me to this harbour; and yet to think
If we hould cape, what my engagements are,
Imprimis—To marry this old Lady Cow,
And play at Blindman-buff, 'tis as good lying
VVith Bulruhes or penny Faggots; he's mortality
Beyond a Death's head and Memento;
And yet he bridles as if he were but now
To be new-back'd and ridden; I have heard
Of a dead body that has long been o,
And yet retain its form, but when once toucht
Crumbles to dut; for ought I know he may do o too,
And I be hang'd for embracing Mummie.
But certainly I hall touch her gently,
For 'tis a remedy to ee her dret
Againt all carnall thoughts, beyond bathing
In Rivers in a froty night.
She follows me, and asks a thouand quetions
Among the ret
Enquired what I was making at the gate?
I anwered her, a Curtain: then he mumpt,
And ask'd, If 'twere not for her wedding-bed.
She made the truet Hieroglyphick
That ever blind Aegyptian hit upon,
For 'twas of earth, and I mot fairly hope
'Twill be her wedding-bed; bar death,
The devill cannot find another Rivall.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Pyander come, we mut to action.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: As how and how?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Phylanter's here hard by already,
And without doubt knows we are lodg'd.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Why—then—he'l knock us, or we hall knock him.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: It's worth no greater care, my brave Pyander.
Fortune and you have done your parts,
To give us omething to employ your valours,
They now hall buy us bravely.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Nay, I'le not ell my elf at any rate,
I begin to have a wondrous value
Of this mall compoure of Pyander, if you mark it
'Tis very lucky to ee an old blind Lady
—hould fall in love with't,
One that runs her noe againt pots.
But come, Sir, ince thee Lads will never leave us,
Let's in and provide for them, they may have
A better welcome than they dreamt of,
Unlee Gunpowder lay lat under their pillows.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: They hall hear us—
In lowder language then they do expect.
The gods but lent us life, and we till pay
Them interet, as caualties and icknee;
Death is the Principall, which when we retore,
VVe owe the world and gods no more.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: VVhy, its exceeding well; we hall be all
Clean out of debt in t'other world then;
Our Creditors are trangers there, o are they here
To me, I'me ure; and in the other world
If I hould want, and thither mut,
There's tore of faith, and I'le take up on trut.

sp.speaker: Phyl.
sp.l: THis is the houe ure it hould be
By the decription—How—VVorks thrown up?
All's quiet though; we mut be cautious,
There may be ele ome trick in't.
—Summon the walls—

sp.speaker: Lyc.
sp.l: VVithin there, ho—ho—
Sure they lie buried in ecurity.
As confident of power and uccee,
As if the Detinies lept with them too,
And wak't at their command.
Let's wake them all—and yet 'tis hard
To roue an innocence to diorder,
'Tis that I fear is their ecurity.

sp.speaker: Phyl.
sp.l: O Lycepes!
It is as great a crime (when pat) to think
Of things ill done, as 'tis unthought to act
The ill before; he that does one firt cheats himelf,
The other couins him: now to be nice
Is vain, for us that have been cheated twice.

sp.speaker: Lyc.
sp.l: VVithin there, ho—

sp.speaker: Phyl.
sp.l: They are dead.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: No, we live, Phylanter,
sp.stage: Mironault, Hyppaus, Lyander, and others, appear above.
sp.l: And far les fear that fate than you,
That have o many crimes to inck your thoughts.
Spare your pains of asking us to yield,
VVee'l ooner find the wort of all extremities;
Danger will loe its nature when you bring it.
—Nay do not tay—
In expectation to hear me ask
VVhy you have thus unworthily thrown off
The name of Honety: Some may fall
Not worth mens pitty, but their corn,
And o do you.

sp.speaker: Phyl.
sp.l: You'r very high, o let your actions be,
Your crimes will need it. But I ee words
Dipleae you, you hall have lowder Rhetorick.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Fear not, thy baenee has taught us to undertand
That language.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: You, Lycepes, you Treaon-hunter,
How, I wonder, did it happen, we did not meet
Your torming worhip at the gate?
Pox on you, you were untruing a point,
The old fighting looenee.

sp.speaker: Lyc.
sp.l: You'r merry till Pyander, and very brisk,
Are you o well already of your inlets.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Hang you, if you bleed as much
As a taid man would let out from a witch
To ave himelfe from enchanting,
The Phyitians, Pothecaries, and Surgeons
Mut tand about thee, like Penioners;
If Hyppaus and I, can but get a willing curre,
We are lick't whole, a dog's our only Mountebank.

sp.speaker: Lyc.
sp.l: Very well Sir, when I viit you,
I'le bring a paniell in my hand.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Hang the couple of currs, ay I,

sp.speaker: Phy.
sp.l: Your reolution's heard, I'le urge no more,
But leave you to your fates, only thus much,
By me the Princee ends this punihment.
The danger now growes bigger ure,—

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: This is mean Phylanter, and you till trifle honety,
And I time and honour: let the torm come,
—And he that eems to fear,
May he unpittied fall, without a tear.

sp.speaker: Phy.
sp.l: His Courage till is excellent, great power of love,
That made me give o much to her,
I left none for my elfe. Lycepes draw round the houe,
We • 'l torm it intantly, dye all you leer thoughts,
That at a ditance tell your formall tales,
Or ele come neerer, and wear noble hapes,
The ditance makes you mitier, the dice are cat,
Th' event will punih or reward what's pat,

div.head: SCEN. 1.
div.stage: Enter Caeca, as to dreing, a Table et out, and glae, Quinever attending, Pyander following.

sp.speaker: Caeca.
sp.l: IS my Captain here?

sp.speaker: Quin.
sp.l: Now enter'd, and like your Ladihip.

sp.speaker: Caeca.
sp.l: Very well, leave us then: Come neer good Captain.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Mercy defend me. A dreing, or etting up a Barber's hop,
Here the teeth lye, what's this an old head?
A lecture for the bet Anatomit; like a ruty Clock,
Taken a pieces to cleane all the devices,
Set them together ome engineer for me.

sp.speaker: Caeca.
sp.l: Pray it neer me, Captain,

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: I do.

sp.speaker: Caeca.
sp.l: O Captain, what a hideous noie
Was there ene now of bouncing, pray what i't?

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Only ome wandring Raskalls at the gate,
They'l have their errand uddenly.

sp.speaker: Caeca.
sp.l: I would they were gone, truly at the firt noie,
I brake one of my pots of Mit • ridate,
VVith Dragon-water, good for the head and tomack.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Was there ever uch an old Almanack,
At the end of the year Medicines et down?

sp.speaker: Caec.
sp.l: Beides the great diturbance from your company.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Nay, you ee when I have freedom
I ue into my own advantage,
Viit you before you'r ready—

sp.speaker: Caec.
sp.l: I hall be ready preently, the time will come
You hall be welcome to me quite undret.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: The Devill of thy young bones
Lockt in thy old Cabinet.

sp.speaker: Caec.
sp.l: I hall unparrell then fater than now I dres me;
You'l help to pull out pins I'le warrant you.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Rather drive in wedges—
Why you know we men mut court,
You would be bahfull ele, and it were pitty
To looe that time which hould be better pent.

sp.speaker: Caec.
sp.l: You ay true indeed.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Come Madam, pray dree your elf
I'le erve you intead of a better chambermaid
S'death would he were once furnih'd
One may dree and undree Long-lane as oon.
VVhat want you now, Madam?

sp.speaker: Caec.
sp.l: My night-rale, good Captain.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: I hall give her a heet intead on't,
It lies about her like a cating net
'Slid I have given her never a wacoat,
And now will he call for her farthingale,
I mut make hate but cannot go without her;
For her wie tenant's now before they fight
VVill ee their Land-Lady

sp.speaker: Caec.
sp.l: My farthingale, good Captain.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: I thought o, now is he like an old Camel
VVith that hideous mount on her unfurniht body.
Mercy how have I et her out! he may make
Good harmony; for hee's compoed of different notes
She would yield a man more money to hew
Than an outlandih beat; my weet Quinever
I have employ'd to tave off formall Peter
From making tenants eem as wie as he.
VVhat want you now, Madam?

sp.speaker: Caec.
sp.l: My Perriwig, good Captain.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: VVhich way to et this on now, is the quetion:
'Tis no matter I can't mitake now
More than I have done.

sp.speaker: Caec.
sp.l: I thank you Captain, I hope you and I
Shall live happily and comfortably together.
I was told, my eventh husband
Should be a wondrous honet and an able man.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: That, experience will let you know: I hall tell you
A merry tale towards bed time that will cure
The cough of th'lungs.

sp.speaker: Caec.
sp.l: And make one dream huge pleaantly
And that's a ign of youth I can aure you.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: That and your toothlee Chap's are main ones.
If urious Medea had thrown thee
Into her age-renuing Kettle, thoud't have lept out
With a medley of years upon thee.
Hark, a noie! by heaven it increaes till, hark

sp.speaker: Caec.
sp.l: O Captain, a noie!

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Nay there's two now in the Devill's name:
It till encreaes, come Madam you mut down.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: 'Sdeath, Pyander, they'r falling on
The men tand all at gaze
And wear they'le ee their Land-Lady,
We are all lot without ome help.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Madam, you mut needs walk
And encourage your tenants, to end thee fools away
'Twill defer our Marriage.

sp.speaker: Caec.
sp.l: Pray lead and I will follow.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Come Hyppaus, how fares the noble Mironault?

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: As a brave Ship hemm'd by a raging torm
Reolves to throw the ballance ore,
Loe all and perih carelesly:
But come, we trifle time.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Along then, and for your blind Ladyhip
If you had no tongue
You hould make igns to your tenants.

sp.speaker: Phyl.
sp.l: COme Lycepes, is the alarme given
To amue them on t'other ide?

sp.speaker: Lyc.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Phyl.
sp.l: What reitance does appear?

sp.speaker: Lyc.
sp.l: As yet all's wrapt in ilence.

sp.speaker: Phyl.
sp.l: Where did the meenger ay my Father was?

sp.speaker: Lyc.
sp.l: At hand Sir with 5000 men; wer't not bet
We hould defer the torm till then?

sp.speaker: Phyl.
sp.l: By no means; we will attempt it firt,
For by that time they may have relief
Come from the Court, my father's uddain flight
Confirm'd the leat upition, helpt by the Princee too.

sp.speaker: Lyc.
sp.l: It could not chue, you have thrut your elf
Into a troubled Ocean.

sp.speaker: Phyl.
sp.l: I know it, and now mut ink or ele go on,
There is no choice in Crimes but of our Fate,
The affrighting freedom of a wretched tate.
We cannot hope ere to return again
Back on our fancies to our firt conditions,
What tob'd us of the afety we enjoyd
Firt made us to contemne it;
'Tis a tayd gameter too, that would give o're
Upon the loing-hand; the mot metl'd, or let it be
The maddet one, would take on all his wealth,
Venter to tire Fortune or himelf.
We have bargain'd now, and chopt a Peace for War
For that will change our acts, or others natures:
The vanquih'd wear the crimes, and all will fear
To judge or quetion what they too mut bear.
This lender gloe I know mut tartle thee
That has o much of honety and courage;
And if we fail I'le quarrell with my elf
That couend thee to follow what thou once
Didt love with'honour: fearing to be unjut
To friendhip, made thee more unto thy elf:
I have ued thee as ome that have educed
Young men into bad company, thou hat found
Things much unworthy of thee—

sp.speaker: Lyc.
sp.l: Tis true, dear Sir, I will not face a lye:
Our acts have given me both amaze and trouble,
The lat I threw behind me, may the VVorld
Forget the ret, there is a Fate hangs over all
That hews it's force when it reolves to trike
VVhen we can act at once, at once dilike,
And t'is the ad neceity that we mut
Perit in crimes again to reach the good
That you intend; this nobly does deerve
My friendhip now, and if we fail
—The world may yet believe
Our thought's were better, let them chue to grieve.

sp.speaker: Phyl.
sp.l: Set on then, brave Lycepes, danger not found
VVomen frig tchildren with, and perills met
Uncheat us of our lives, that render'd us
But an unhappy treaurie for our cares,
Made montrous by our joys, the hopes and fears
That pring from them, onely the tock we pend on.
This cannot add, I know, to thee; and I hould bluh
If it could ought to me. But 'tis mens pleaure
To undervalue what they think will go,
And they mut looe—the world's fond nature's o;
And 'tis the bravet corn ill men can have,
To change this world, as freely for a grave.

div.head: ACT. 4. SCEN. 3.
div.stage: Enter Pyander hatily, the Blind Lady following, Peter directing.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: NOw the Devill raie a Barricado, I am torm'd too;
I have pepper'd the Rogues on my ide,
I mut go ee how the other fares.

sp.speaker: Caec.
sp.l: Is he here, Peter?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Straight on, an't like your Ladihip.

sp.speaker: Caec.
sp.l: Pray tay, weet Captain; Oh, oh,
All my corn's a-fire, good Captain.
Straight before till, Peter?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Yes Madam.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: By this light, Sir, I'le direct your noe to the wall,

sp.speaker: Caec.
sp.l: Good Captain, all, all, my corn, oh, oh;
The great Barn's on fire, look how it burns.
Is this your kindnee? pray, your hand.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Pray take this for interpoition.
sp.stage: he laies omething in the way.
sp.l: It will not do, he'l run her head
Againt omething or other, and beat her brains out.
—I mut place her in here—
VVhat's this, a Corn-houe—Here Madam.
Give me your hand, ret your elf a little,
And I'le be with you preently: and for you, wie Sir,
sp.stage: he places her in the Vault.
sp.l: Let her alone, til I, like a good Midwife,
Come and deliver her: This, Sir, you had bet oberve.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: VVhy its very well, I thought at leat I might have given her
A hot fire-hovell to have bak'd a cake upon.
Nothing troubles me—
But that the Rats and Mice may play with her noe.
I thought he would be brought to this, Mrs. Quinever
Is employ'd in cating bullets with a face
Like fiery Sol in Leo, if this hurry hold long,
My poor old Lady may wih he had lot
All enes as well as eeing; for god knows
The employment for the ret are mierable.
Hark, a noie, they are at it, much good may't do them;
To run away it is impoible, and from my chamber
I can ee all the hooting; it has made me wih a thouand times
I were as blind as my old Lady, I'le to her in the Vault,
I never thought my elf too afe, he that did,
Let him leap Towers for Peter.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: BRave Hyppaus, how to forgive my elf I cannot tell,
For all that you have uffered.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: Still on that train, Sir!
VVe could not erve you thus if we repined,
Or feared to uffer for you; wrong not our honety
And courage both.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: They are too excellent, I wear it were a pleaure
To hare in danger with you, were't not a pain
To ee you there—Gallant Pyander,
You brought us timely aid, and from our inking fates
Raied us again; but you had quickly done
On t'other ide.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: O mine were pittifull racalls,
Yours came to their buinee handomly.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: They did indeed, Phylanter firt
Advanc'd before his men, bold in depight
Of all his crimes, and carelee both alike
Of honety and danger.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: He was the wier; To what purpoe
Should any one be thrifty of, that the world
So little cares for, this trifle Honety.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: Come Pyander, you mut get the Soldiers dret,
That have been hurt, we may have more need of them.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Yes, yes, as far as her Smocks will extend in Lint.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: I find I need a little dreing too.
—Let's in, and there—
Provide for after-claps of treacherous Fortune.
We mut not fear a Frown, or court a Smile;
One may the VVie, t'other the Brave beguile.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: HOw far is't to his Quarters now?
A little way, Sir.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Be ure that all the Soldiers march in order,
And on their lives no outrage to the Country.
Let all be done in ilence. No Scouts return'd yet?
Not any, Sir.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: I am jealous of this Court, the King enclined
But little, upition could not mingle with his nature,
The Princee has confirm'd him ure; we act
On the uncertain't Stage, the tranget parts
That ever yet were play'd, I would the world
VVould take it o. VVe have now tept
Beyond the power of Retreat or Fortune,
The one's too poor for us, and we for t'other.
VVe are like tired Gameters with ill Cards
VVeary to hold the game, and yet play on
To ave if not to win; perhaps
If we prevailed, Ambition would as well
Play on the game as now we do,
Though from a modeter deigne.
How little ought man to be truted then
With power in this world, when even the things
He aims to thrive by are the crimes of Kings,
Good Princes, like bet Juglers, till find firt
The leer leights of others. How now,
What news?

sp.speaker: Me.
sp.l: As we were couting on the way,
Which leads unto Cracovia, we epied
The Body of an Army moving within
Two hours march.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Ha, it mut be o—he has don't.
Bid intantly Boticay march with hate,
For fear we are hindred joyning with my on.
Amidt thee crimes a little policy does well,
It mut be o, all we can hope for now will be to make
But good conditions—
—To put it to the venture of a day were madnee,
We can have no upplies, they may have more.
And yet—I know not what to think,
Ditractions mingle with my thoughts,
And we till loe our judgments with uccee.
Our reolutions waited on us then
Like ervants wanting wages. All Mankind
Is one of thoe two Cowards,
—Either to wih to die
When we hould live, or live when we hould die.
Some fear, ome wih, too early, or too late
Mot fall, yet none mut chue his Fate;
Thoe that prepare for every torm, do eldom cat
Themelves away,
It is but bravely inking at the lat.

div.head: ACT. 4. SCEN. 6.
div.stage: Enter Princee, Amione, Phylena, and others.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: No news yet?
1. Not any Madam.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: Leave us, and give notice when any comes.
I hall—

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: We have not now ure far,
And yet me thinks 'tis along while
Ere we are there, time is thought
The fatet undicerned flying thing
That is, but yet Love's wings are wifter,
Swift wihes impe his ragged plumes
And pull the feathers from the wings of Time,
—And every houer bears
Double proportion from our hopes and fears.

sp.speaker: Phyl.
sp.l: This pretty way of account Madam, will rie
Unto a um of ages, added
To what now Mironault's a heaping,
'Twill make a new Chronologie,
But we till reckon on the old account.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: You'r merry till, Phylena, when your day comes
You'le give me leave to do the ame.

sp.speaker: Phyl.
sp.l: Yes Madam, we both agree,
And yet you hrewdly once upected it
Of this fair maid,

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: You make me bluh, he way forgive me though
For he deerved it,

sp.speaker: Amio.
sp.l: O Madam,—
Could you fall o much below
The power of all your beauties in uch fears
That you could jutly let upition dwell
Where you pretend an interet? The Roe as well
May drooping hang it's fragrant head
Jealous of meaner Flowers, and the Sun
Supect his light when mortalls kindle fires.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: Nay Amione you court me now
I will not call it flattery, whil't it comes
From thee, for that's a crime
That dwells with crooked natures, yet it was
Mitaken kindnee.

sp.speaker: Amio.
sp.l: 'Twas you mitook it ure, for none will find
Themelves deceived that love you,

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: How now, what news?

sp.speaker: Me.
sp.l: Jut now for certain, Madam
The Lord Albertus joyned unto his on
With a great Body,

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: They have not yet attempted ought.

sp.speaker: Me.
sp.l: Yes Madam, before his Father's coming,

l.hi: Phylanter

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: Ha: hat thou learnt no particulars?

sp.speaker: Me.
sp.l: Yes all, for before the Lord Albertus coming
The mallnee of their numbers gave us freedom
To enquire near the place of all particulars,
—And thus it was,
Soon as Phylanter had found out
The houe they tayed at, preently he ghet
That wounds had caued their tay, by reaon
They trove to reach no place of more ecurity
And o indeed it was; gheing beides,
They hould have mal reitance: upon thee thoughts
Phylanter draws about it, then ummons them.
But in the midt the gallant Mironault
Hinders the parly with a haty corn,
As if he meant to drive no bargain,
But ell at his own rate, at which
The bravely bad Phylanter weld with rage
Prepar'd to give th'aault, and in the head
Of all his men advanc't (ome ditance) firt,
To bring on ruine great as was his crimes,
Or ele to perih with them, and eem'd half willing
To be forgotten on a noble core;
So equally divided, or to hide
His michiefs in their Fates, or in his own.
The torm grew hot, yet till Phylanter urged
Beyond belief, now out of Love with afety,
Becaue his foes in pight of him enjoyd it
(With an unlookt for power to reit him)
Branded the name of Fortune with a whore,
As if they had begot upplies upon her;
On t'other ide his men ees hrinking from him,
When mad with rage he eaily retires
With uch a look as longing Lovers end
When they mut part, o much he coutted danger,
And now retreating with his drooping forces,
The gallant Mironault like a bright Sun
Broke from the moakie torm, and iues forth,
Acting new Tragedies, till, being jealous
More forces might come in,
In order they retreated, and for certain
Phylanter both and Mironault are hurt.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: O me!

sp.speaker: Phyl.
sp.l: Madam end off the meenger, Let not him ee
The leat diorder.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: Go intanly, and bid Symathocles
Let all the Army march in readinee to fight.

sp.speaker: Me.
sp.l: I hall.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: And acquaint him with all you know
Nay do not hide thy tears Amione
They can't dipleae me, wench, nor hall I think
That there is grief enough for him,
Though I am fully tor'd.

sp.speaker: Amio.
sp.l: Alas, what a condition Fortune throws him in?
Did he but know by whom he were lamented
He could not have o much of joy,
As grief to think how he was raviht
From the lov'd mourner;

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: I prethee peace; not that I fear
To have more grief for him, for I have that
Within me has made that impoibility,
But to inlarge thy own, 'tis true too
That I hould give thee counell not to grieve,
But I hall grieve the while, yet if thou thinket
I wrong thy kindnee then wee'le mourn together
And joyn our tock of tears, for no one tore
Is worthy of him.

sp.speaker: Amio.
sp.l: Though nature made me partiall, it robd me not
Of o much reaon, to be o impudent,
The Fates perhaps, or ome great power
That has a peciall care for you, or kindnee,
Preerved you for themelves, and lent you to the world
As the S • n was, not for the happinee
Of one alone but all.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: May we not yet amidt our greatet grief
Believe it is not dangerous; for after he was hurt
They leiurely retired.

sp.speaker: Amio.
sp.l: Would I could o be atisfied—
And yet that clearly jutifies we wih
Our own contents, then when we raie
Our fears to equall power in our thoughts
Of what we doubt, yet what we wih to have;
None e're yet wih'd a life, but fear'd a grave.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: 'Tis true Amione, thoe torturing • ivalls
Hope and fear are ever whipering,
And they that have mot need of one,
Have ever mot of t'other. When I think this,
Though I would willingly pretend to counell,
Or any thing would eae thy grief, I mut
Believe it both impoible and needlee.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Were it not jut to linger then no longer
In all thee doubts, ince we might give them eae.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: As how can it be done?

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: I would attempt to ee him, I onely want your leave.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: It is impoible, the ways are all hut up.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: I do not mean to go concealed.
They ay Phylanter is o much a Gentleman,
He will not certainly deny a woman.
Fear not, Madam, 'tis but two hours time,
And I am there, or here again.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: I can deny thee nothing, not this I'me ure;
If thou eet him, tell him, that Love and Contancy's rewarded
In t'other world, and will be o in this.
Tell him, I wih his happinee
And mine own together. And be ure
You take a Chirurgeon with you.

sp.speaker: Phyl.
sp.l: My ervice, Madam.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: I will not fail, Heaven keep you.
May I return with uch a bleing
As I now bear to him.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: Farewell, dear Maid. Phylena, now
The time draws near of joy or miery,
—We live at an uncertain rate,
Or flatter'd til, or ele dipleas'd with fate.

div.head: ACT 4. SCEN. 7.
div.stage: Enter at one dore Albertus and Others, at another Phylanter, Lycepes, and Others.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: I Should chide now, but the condition of your fortunes
Cannot be that way helpt, nor are you fit
For a diturbance, I hear you have ucceles
Storm'd the houe; Why tai'd you not till I arriv'd?
'Twas folly to attempt it with o few.

sp.speaker: Phyl.
sp.l: But that has hapned now which I then feared,
For I did ghee upplies would come to them
As oon as you to us. Beides, who would have ghet,
Or now can think, how they come by their aid?
Had we proved fortunate, we might have made
Our own conditions.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: In that you have hit my thoughts, for now we mut
Not loe our elves by fear or folly;
The one's too mean, the other but a madnee.
And we mut look on thee we have
Without a hope of more, and on them
As an encreaing body; by this we are contrain'd
Upon the nick to make our compoitions,
Or put it to the venture of a Day;
The firt's the better, were the lat the likelier.
For I believe that, paion laid aide
That firt incited thee rah thoughts and actions,
You look upon't as not to be puru'd,
But fairly to be le • t. Men may erre,
It is the influence of Chance and Nature,
But to purue it, is their own—Lycepes—
There is much due to you, you were till honet,
And mot a friend in danger,
Who are in afety onely are their own.

sp.speaker: Lyc.
sp.l: My Lord, I always owed your on as much,
And did reolve to pay it, till I had caue
To leave, or feared to avow it.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: You are till noble. But Phylanter,
VVhat certain intelligence have you?

sp.speaker: Phyl.
sp.l: VVe know, Sir, the Army of the King
Is hard at hand, they ay the Princee too
Is with them.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: I ghes'd as much, and for that reaon
I left the Court, for I heard
That he was big with rage—VVell,
The time's now hort, and omething mut be done:
Let all be in a readinee, and prepare
Nobly to reach uccee, or ill to hare.
In the mean time wee'l preently advie
The honorablet way for compoition.
For to be afe and good is better far,
Than trut our crimes unto the chance of War.

sp.speaker: Phyl.
sp.l: HOw have I thus been couened! how montrous too
It eems, till to purue the crimes I lov'd before:
To be uncouened, though 'tis jut, eems poor,
When danger gives the widom: how low we inck
When we once fall below our elves!
We till mut fear what others ought to do.
In crimes none can be wie and gallant too.
All this beides for an uncertain Beauty,
Nor yet poet or gain'd, the Perian o
Spends all his wealth and prayers on the Sun,
That equally dipences unto thoe
Which ne're ador'd him, his warm comforts too.
Farewell to all your Sex, that cannot be
Belov'd, but with unthrifty miery.
The Lover that's unlov'd, like me, mut wate
His tore of Love, the Lov'd may longer lat.
They that joyn Stocks, with eae our-pends
Him that runs on unpaid and lends.
Farewell: I will uncheat my elf and you,
For when I lov'd you firt I couen'd two.

sp.speaker: Sould.
sp.l: My Lord!

sp.speaker: Phyl.
sp.l: How now?

sp.speaker: Sould.
sp.l: A woman at the dore
Deires admittance to your Lordhip.

sp.speaker: Phyl.
sp.l: Thou ravet! a woman?

sp.speaker: Sould.
sp.l: So I told you.

sp.speaker: Phyl.
sp.l: Nay, I might wonder, for uch and I
Have now o little buinee with each other,
That by my troth 'tis trange.
Seems he a peron of any quality?

sp.speaker: Sould.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Phyl.
sp.l: Handome?

sp.speaker: Sould.
sp.l: To a miracle.

sp.speaker: Phyl.
sp.l: The Devil on the wonder! buinee with me?

sp.speaker: Soul.
sp.l: So he earnetly expret.

sp.speaker: Phyl.
sp.l: Bring her in.
Cure on the Sex, Civility mut wait upon 'em,
Their weaknee makes us fools, or ele their beau • ies.
Ha! 'tis that indeed that charms us from our elves,
And all the handome actions that we do
Seem offerings to their powers, as if the Sea
Should end a tribute to the little Brooks,
Such a prepoterous thing is Love, 'tis like
The folly and the crime to make a god
One's elfe to worhip—Now for a trap
I hall be hy of thee fair baits.
—What ubtle trick—
Mut this fair Intrument bring about?—
—I will be deaf to charms—She comes.
Ha—extreamly fair—
Come perhaps for to revenge
The candall of her ex upon me—Is it on me
Fair maid, that you would lay commands?

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.l: A comely man, pitty that form
Should harbour o much baenee.
It is you, Sir, I mut petition; for commands,
Though they might eem fair attributes to our ex,
Yet when you know, to whoe much hated name,
Nature has made my Love a debt,
You will believe, Thardly hould petition.

sp.speaker: Phyl.
sp.l: I rather hall conider this fair thing,
To whom a hated name can owe an interet,
—But you have heard—
Stories perhaps, not much becomming me,
Made up of others envies and my crimes,
Nor can I tell a good one of my elfe,
But that I love an innocence like yours,
And only that, for you to have a confidence,
I hardly hall deny you.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.l: The world has ure belied him,
—Nay, Sir,
Nature commands, that I hould ask,
Your fair encouragement has given me hopes
Not to be quite denied, and I am orry
That I mut now beg a civility,
And dare not own requitall; 'tis the firt time,
That jutice and ingratitude were friends.

sp.speaker: Phyl.
sp.l: You till believe me too unworthy: they that do
An act that does deerve requitall,
Pay firt themelves the tock of uch content,
Nature has given to every worthy mind,
If others hould be bankrupt—
Pray torture me no more but aske.

sp.speaker: Amio.
sp.l: He would deceive me trangely,
Know then, the iter to wrong'd-Mironault mut ask:
Does it not tartle you?

sp.speaker: Phyl.
sp.l: You ee it does not.
He that has injured Mironault, will grant it,
Trifle no more.

sp.speaker: Amio.
sp.l: Tis only then your leave that I may ee him,

sp.speaker: Phyl.
sp.l: And happinee attend you, you hall have
A conduct with you;—I did not think
That I hould find o much of joy,
In that mall time I have to butle here,
As your lov'd power has given me,
Pardon me, if I dare attempt
To have a little peace within me,
Still to remember you, I fear I mut,
Though both hould be unwilling.

sp.speaker: Amio.
sp.l: I hall promie Sir, I carry no intelligence.

sp.speaker: Phyl.
sp.l: Urge it no more, I do not fear,
Nor am I ignorant, of what a torm
Is falling now upon me, only grieved
That I durt bring it to't, and yet now pleaed,
That I dare bear it: choie in crimes,
Is the wort part in man, and good from fear,
The meanet. But I have aid to much, only thus,
The lat of all my thoughts, hall be of you,
They may be good: Nay, do not wonder,
Nor be o much concerned for one o lot,
To frame an anwer from a mile or frown,
I will conduct you on your way, as you come back,
Others hall waite you, for your eyes
Shall not be injured with an hated object.
Here in this world, my fate, the quarrell ends,
—In t'other ure, we may meet friends.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: NAy, for certain, Sir,
We aw a body marching, which cannot poibly
Belong to t'other Army.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Why, I did alwayes believe,
My dancing daies were not quite done.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: I know not what to ghee, nor do I wih;
For in extreams, lee cares give noblet thoughts,
Deignes of wihing, are the cheating joyes
Of fearfull men, t'were foolihnee beide;
A carelee hope looks handomely.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: We hall o jutifie our elves, but I believe,
'Tis not unreaonable, to think our innocence
Should merit ome protection, the Princee ure
Will not be lat in jutice.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Urge it no more, nothing is worth her care,
'Tis ome as bad as thoe, come to ait them.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: There's one without, Sir, that would deire
Admittance to you.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Who i't.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: A woman.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: A woman? I cannot ghee,—
—Let her come in.
What hould this mean, deceive me not too much,
Fond hope, nor puzzle me, for if you do,—at lat,
I hall grow carelee of my joyes and you;
Ha! Amione,—welcome,
Welcome, above all joyes but one.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.l: Perhaps, welcome as that, I have much to ay,
But I mut firt be civill. Brave Hyppaus,
May you nere know extremities, but if you hould,
May you find uch a friend, as you have been.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: Were I not nobly paid in his deert,
I were in this?

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.l: The ame to you Pyander, for to thank you
In any other Language, were too poor,
And much unjut, for to divide,
What you o nobly joyn'd in.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Now have I forgot, what Hyppaus aid,
Pray take his anwer in good part for us both.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.l: You'ar merry till, Pyander.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: I confee, nothing went ever neer my heart,
Unlee it were your Love, but what availeth ighes and tears?

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.l: Very well, Sir.
Dear Brother, pardon this injury of gratitude,
That kept me o long from you; forgive me too,
If joy diorders me, I have enough
To ee you afe.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Dear Amione, how long we hall be o,
Heaven knows, yet 'twas a great advantage
To live thus long to ee thee: but how wat poible
You could get hither, or from whence now come you?

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.l: Why, Phylanter's great civility,
Brought me afe hither.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: But from whence?

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.l: From the Army.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: From whoe Army?

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.l: The Princee.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Ha!—

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.l: I will defer your joyes no longer
From the Princee, who bid me tell you,
That faith and contancie's rewarded
In t'other world, and will be o in this?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Thou would't not mock me ure.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.l: I do not.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: O Amione, Didt thou but know the joy of every heart,
That at this hour, has its wihes crown'd,
Thou might't then ghee at mine.
And is he there in peron?

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.l: Yes, attended with a gallant Army,
Much tronger then the enemy, you might
Dicern them ure; and reolved as oon as I return
To offer battell. Is Phylanter,
Prepar'd to fight?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: With any thing in pight of all his crimes,
Reolves to perih bravely, o great a villain
Ne're bore o brave a mind,—tis a quetion,
Whether he thinks, there's uch a thing as danger.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.l: We heard indeed, he torm'd it bravely,
And that your hurts were of more danger
Then I perceive they are; 'twas the report
Of that which brought me hither.
Nor mut I tay, the Princee layed commands
Of my immediate coming back; at more leiure,
You hall have all my tory, in the mean time,
I mut needs tell you, you are like to be
Extreamly happy; O Brother, never was o much weetnes
Guarded o ure from crimes, if ever breat
Were Sanctuary for vertues, it is her's:
She will deerve your love I fear much more,
Unlee its poible, men hould be contant.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: This is not kind Amione, her valew
Will make me wie till to preerve my riches;
And benefit is mans deigne.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.l: Man eldome though purues his owne advantage,
Women like Towns, once wonne are lighted:
VVhat we already have within our powers,
Has lee eteem then unatchieved things.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Urge it no more, one may as well be weary
Of the Sun's contant hining, as her influence:
He never ries, but he eems to bring
Freh glory from the Eat and every day
VVill adde a new dicovery of her vertues,
That he will never eem enjoy'd enough.
Beides, though man's compos'd of faithlee matter,
The Soul of one may be of nobler ue
Than others are, and with that Soul
Man had not been o nobly put in trut
Had he not means left free to be unjut.
Come, o much eternitie as my love mut have,
Mut not be told in uch a little moment
As you have now to pare, nor will I injure
The little time I have with thee,
When we hall meet again heaven knows:
For friends once pawn'd to ditance there is a danger
To bankrupt hopes.
You mut expect but poor beieged welcome
—Who uch relief as Anchorets have
At leat hall find in an expected grave.

sp.speaker: Phyl.
sp.l: WHat is the next thing how that mut be done?
How weary all the World and I
Am grown of one another? I hould be friends
With this diguie, could it but hide my crimes:
But night it elf that great diguifer,
Wants power to conceal the leat of crimes
From any troubled breat, when man would fain
Be unacquainted with himelf again:
'Tis jut too, when we have our elves betraid
That we hould be then of our elves afraid
Ambition onely is our nature's folly,
That robs us of that little tock of reaon,
We have at temperate and idle hours.
If we but take the inventory of our elves,
There we hall find uch periht tuff
By rage and paion, that 'tis jut
We hould be once forgotten in the dut;
—But for my new deign—ha—'tis odd
To throw my elf into the power of them—
As if 'twere meannee, or omething poorer; fear—
—Yet—let it dye
Ha—he comes—
—A Perian's cold devotion thus,
Receives new warmnes from the riing Sun
—It mut be o—
He that would hide Love kindled once within,
Rakes but his fire up to keep it in.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: We take our leaves now Madam, for we ee
There's one attends you from the
Lord Phylanter,

sp.speaker: Phyl.
sp.l: Madam, my Lord Phylanter ent me hither
In his own language to preent you Safety
Great as you merit.

sp.speaker: Amio.
sp.l: I thank you Sir, he has obliged me nobly:
Had he forgot his crimes, I hould forget
He were an enemy.

sp.speaker: Phyl.
sp.l: He bid me tell you farther,
That he had waited on you here himelf,
But that he fear'd to injure your fair eyes,
That hould be onely pleas'd with welcom objects.

sp.speaker: Amio.
sp.l: Ha: perih you eaie thoughts, that tart
At hearing of that name, yet when you think of him
I may forgive you, if you then
Frighten your elves,—
And yet it may be Love; ruines of Love
And lightning are alike—
For, what would willingly reit
They both conume; I hall attend you Sir,
If you pleae to lead the way—

sp.speaker: Albert.
sp.l: COntinue till worthy Lycepes,
To let him know repentance needs no bluhes.
Or that 'tis neceary for Fate or us,
To perue cruell actions, yet with a gentle hand
That no ditraction mingle with his nature;
For he is young, and youth's unetled furie
Is ready till to act,

sp.speaker: Lyc.
sp.l: I have Sir, with a gentle hand
Toucht all the torie of this madnee,
And find him too, like an experienc't gamter,
Aham'd to have been cheated, but reolv'd
Wiely no more to venture at that game:
Our whole deigns mut needs therefore now
Aime, but to bring us off, and yet prepare
Not to want courage in the meanet Fortune.

sp.speaker: Albert.
sp.l: 'Tis all that can be aid in our Conditions,
In order therefore to our ad affairs,
Wee'le intantly dipatch a Trumpet
To offer fair conditions, or any thing
That may not ound like mercy from another:
That's an unworthy way to adde
To other's fames, in ruining our own;
And yet our whole deires hall be low,
Indeed they mut, for the extremity
Of every unreited Fate makes poor
Their thoughts that were as rich before.

sp.speaker: Amio.
sp.l: YOu have now, Sir, performed that civill part,
That alwies hall enforce me to eteem
The Lord Phylanter, and may this Sir
Tell you my thanks.

sp.speaker: Phyl.
sp.l: Madam, reward can not be due
To this mall ervice, though I may do
What may perhaps eem to deerve
Something of that nature, but I mut firt
Deire you to prepare for to believe
Not ill of him, that thinks your wrongs
Deerve devotions, greater than his trut.

sp.speaker: Amio.
sp.l: What mean you Sir?

sp.speaker: Phyl.
sp.l: Would it not be worth a reward at leat?
That you might have within your power
The eae of all your hard misfortunes?

sp.speaker: Amio.
sp.l: Certainly 'twere; the ound bears greater joy
Than poibility.

sp.speaker: Phyl.
sp.l: I know ometimes, that Treaon eems
But ugly in the jutet caue;
Though I believe that never yet,
A power like yours commanded it.

sp.speaker: Amio.
sp.l: Still I undertand you not, pray to the matter.

sp.speaker: Phyl.
sp.l: To be hort then, know Phylanter loves you,
Your eeming kindnee will have power
To draw him where you pleae, for to my breat
He has committed all his thoughts,
And bid me judge when I hould ee you,
Whether he had not caue for all his paions,
(Indeed he has) o much his crimes are greater;
Nor is it more injutice to his trut
Than due to you to tell you, if you pleae,
That I may bear ome feigned kindnee from you,
I'me ure 'twill bring him any where,
That you may eaily urprie him.

sp.speaker: Amio.
sp.l: But do you think he has lot his reaon o?
To trut himelf without his guards,
And his urprifall then will not be eaie.

sp.speaker: Phyla.
sp.l: Alas, his reaon's like an helplee friend,
Left and foraken, and nothing but your name
Mut be forgiven, that would attempt to leen
His thoughts from what he has done, you need not fear
He can be over-wie that loves o much,
Nor will his reaon tell him that 'tis due
To all his kindnee.

sp.speaker: Amio.
sp.l: Nor is it ure.

sp.speaker: Phyl.
sp.l: But to his former torie 'tis, and preent actions;
For though repentance onely at your name
Has power in his thoughts, yet he contemns
