To have that Virtue on a meaner core,
His crimes to all the world beides continue.

sp.speaker: Amio.
sp.l: And they may better be the punihers.

sp.speaker: Phyl.
sp.l: I grant you, were it in their power
As 'tis in yours, and they would then
Do ure as much for you.
'Tis but the leat command from you,
My life on't, I bring him where you think bet
He may be with mot eae urpris'd.

sp.speaker: Amio.
sp.l: But hould not you conider?
That though this punihment be due from me,
The treacherie's unjut in you.
How much it is the buinee of mankind
sp.stage: [aide Whilet he turns away and peaks, he throws off his diguie, and lays his word drawn, with the hilt towards her.
sp.l: To make a bargain for their honety,
And yet not think how little that will yield
To others, which they make o cheap,
Man's like a barren and ingratefull oil,
That eldom pays the labour of manuring.
How has Philanter injured him, or I obliged him?
That I could at firt upon a leer core
Share with his crimes, and on a meaner now
Baely dilike, as if his choice were jut,
Whoe equall eae accepts and forfeits trut.
• 'le tell him too 'tis bae, how fain would Love
Tell his own tory, through a nobler caue,
And bluhes ure as well as I.
—It hould be for Phylanter—
Ha! Deceive me not fond eyes, it cannot be
I owe amazement now o much—
—It mut arret me.

sp.speaker: Phyl.
sp.l: Wonder not, fair Amione, nor fear
I'le beg your pitty, that contemn my own,
And yet for many reaons think I love you;
Though I believe my time will hardly give
Me leave to reckon them—Onely conider,
That I durt here avow it, I could have faln,
Its true, as nobly with my fellows,
But much more happier here; I would have weigh'd it too
More leiurely in reaon's cales, till a thought
Of you broke in, and ended the dipute.
I have at my own rate procured my happinee,
Nor have I done lee ure for you; 'tis the firt ervice,
And likely too to be the lat I e're hall do you.

sp.speaker: Amio.
sp.l: O Phylanter, you hould not trut
Revenge, and all your crimes at once
In any power, though I perhaps
Shall fear to be a murtherer, o to make
My elf as bad as you.

sp.speaker: Phyl.
sp.l: Why I confee, I willingly
Would be as good as you, but that's a leon
Hardly to be learn'd, and yet it looks
Much like the way to read it often;
As I have done your vertues.
I ay not this to tempt a mercy,
I have deerved a great deal of unkindnee;
But not o much as now to fall
A acrifice to any but your wrongs.

sp.speaker: Amio.
sp.l: I know not what to ay—
You may repent, perhaps grow good;
Pray try.

sp.speaker: Phyl.
sp.l: 'Tis true, I think I might;
But 'tis a quetion till, whe're you'd grow kind.
And indeed, the fear of that great danger
Made me contemn the ret. But I trifle time,
By all that's charitable, let me not fall
By meaner hands. Hark, ome Souldiers.
Ue this for pitty's ake.

sp.speaker: Amio.
sp.l: Alas! ah me!
How now? who have we hear, Philanter?
Treaon!
Treaon, treaon!

sp.speaker: Phyl.
sp.l: Nay, then I mut ue it.
Villains, I have a little buinee here,
I might have pared the reaon though to you
They have raied the alarm; yet, Amione,
Free me from this mean ruine.

sp.speaker: Amio.
sp.l: Pray put on your diguie again,
You may yet cape.

sp.speaker: Phyl.
sp.l: I'me glad it is impoible, you ee it is,
O Amione; had I but loved you at a leer rate,
I might have found a oberer expreion.
But yet remember, a mad-man eldom loes
His kindnee with his judgment.
A noie again! hell on their yellings!

sp.speaker: Amio.
sp.l: By that love you bear me,
Put on your diguie.

sp.speaker: Phyl.
sp.l: Never, till my afety be worth your care.

sp.speaker: Amio.
sp.l: O Phylanter, though your condition needs it,
'Tis too oon for me to ay it, yet I will tempt my
To tell you, I would have you afe.

sp.speaker: Phyl.
sp.l: That now my fate is unavoidable, the gods bluhes
Perhaps provided, let I hould urfeit
Of joys in this world; yet I hall have
Enough, if you believe, no dying mind
Can have more joy, or living love.
'Twas my grief at firt to love you, and now
My fear at lat you hould not know it.
'Twas all my buinee too before my end.
I could wih one thing more, to be reolved,
Whether in t'other world (where wie-men tell us,
There is uch tore of love) our joy hall be
Greatet, to meet thoe friends we lov'd bet here.
—but I hall be reolved. In the mean time,
What e're becomes of me,
Let your kind thoughts
—admit ometimes this minute's memory.

sp.speaker: Amio.
sp.l: Alas, think of your afety; Hark! they come! yet
Let your diguie and me protect you.

sp.speaker: Phyl.
sp.l: When I have your protection—I need need not this diguie,
Nor will I wear it. They come.
My dear Amione,
For ever live as happy as I die.

sp.p: Here! here! on! on! on!

sp.speaker: Phyl.
sp.l: Villains, you hall buy me bravely.

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.l: Hold, on your lives; how, Phylanter?

sp.speaker: Phyl.
sp.l: The ame, you need not bid me welcome,
Nor tempt me much, Symathocles.

sp.speaker: Amio.
sp.l: O Phylanter, be yet more temperate;
Pray, Sir, let me obtain a little hearing.

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.l: You may command it. The Princes!

sp.speaker: Amio.
sp.l: O Madam, let me beg
That no amazement dwell upon your eyes,
Nor any thing but mercy.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: I have both ready for thy ake—How—
—Phylanter—VVhat Riddle's this—?

sp.speaker: Phyl.
sp.l: I owe that name indeed, but with les bluhes
Than I did once.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: I promied not to wonder, my Amione;
But this is trange.

sp.speaker: Amio.
sp.l: You promied mercy too.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: Have you an interet in his pardon then?
Bluh not,
I'le ask no more—Phylanter—
This tory hall be perfect at more leiure,
And all things ele hall be deferr'd
But my forgivnee. I do believe
(You came to fetch your pardon in o much danger)
You can repent or any thing, but deerve
The happinee preparing for you.
Come, Amione, thou hat brought back
An unexpected friend. May this uccee
To every one bring equall happinee.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: HAs no one yet brought any news?

sp.speaker: Lyc.
sp.l: Not any, Sir, O miery!
Betraid by ome leight. How now?
From whence com't thou?

sp.speaker: Me.
sp.l: My Lord, your on deires to meet you;
And withall you would not wonder,
That with the Princee he waits your comming.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Stranger yet! ome farther michiefe ure!
Lycepes Draw up the Army intantly.
We mut not be thus couened.
Came you from my on?

sp.speaker: Me.
sp.l: But now, Sir.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: And is he with the Princee?

sp.speaker: Me.
sp.l: Yes, Sir.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Where?

sp.speaker: Me.
sp.l: Now comming to the Houe.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: With all her Army?

sp.speaker: Me.
sp.l: Onely with a mall Guard.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: There may be omething then.
Fortune I'le think if now thou hew't thy care,
Thou cant redeem as wel as bring depair.

div.head: ACT 5. SCEN. 7.
div.stage: Enter Princes, Phylanter, Amione, Phylena, and Others.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: IS this the houe, Phylanter?

sp.speaker: Phyl.
sp.l: Yes, Madam.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: Pray ummon it.

sp.speaker: Phyl.
sp.l: 'Twill now be yielded, Madam,
Far eaier than 'twould once. Within there, ho!

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: How now, what news, O Phylanter?
Is your troubleome Worhip there again?
—how now, the Princee too?

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: The ame, Pyander.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Now truly Madam, do I think
I had bet call Mironault to unriddle this.
—The labour's av'd.

l.hi: Mironault.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Ha.—

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: Do you not know me?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Yes, and others too there.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: This is injutice Mironault,
Can you let wonder keep you thus from me?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: I had forgot, it's true, 'tis Mirramente,
And erupulous thoughts were ins unpardonable,

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: If I hould tay to conider what this means,
I hould be the lat hould know it;
I'le e'ne decend too.

sp.speaker: Prin.

l.hi: Mironault,

sp.l: —Though thee trange objects might deerve a torie,
'T would take up time, and I hall think it crueltie
To rob thee of one minute's joy, if I can give it.

sp.speaker: Miro.
sp.l: If you can give it? have I thus long
Lov'd you, and lov'd you religiouly, now to have
All my devotion quetion'd?
Can ick men joy in health? or liberty
Be pleaing unto captives? In your kindnee
Lies all my health and liberty.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: Nor will I fear to avow it, dearet Mironault,
No thoughts of croing danger e're hall fright
My Love or me.

sp.speaker: Miro.
sp.l: It's true, I am unworthy of you; but o are all,
And he that parts me from you,
Mut joyn me to a colder Bride.

sp.speaker: Phyl.
sp.l: And more than you, gallant Mironault,
Wonder no more, nor think on tories pat,
But that to come, Phylanter will appear
As worthy of your friendhip,
—As he was once of hate—but tay
I had forgot to ask your pardon. Indeed
sp.stage: He takes Amione by the hand.
sp.l: Heer's one may better do it, whoe fair opinion
—Will promie for me.—

sp.speaker: Miro.
sp.l: Brave Sir, I hated till your crimes not you, o did he,
And if he love your Virtues, pray believe
I am her brother too.

sp.speaker: Phyl.
sp.l: Madam, I ee
A little honety will make one impudent
That I mut now beg pardon for others,
That carly hould have hop't if for my elf.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: Rie my Lord, you need not now
Of any doubt your pardon.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Excellent Princee, I hall deerve hereafter
What an unjut neceity made me hun to tetifie.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: Hyppaus and Pyander, I mut not now
Forget your hare in thanks,
That did receive your part in danger.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Nay your Highnee cannot be better pleaed than we
That all the danger's pat, to ay truth,
Hypaus and I were clearly your Platonicks,
And made up the Romance.

div.stage: The blind Lady hearing his voice, calls from under the vault where he put her.

sp.speaker: Caec.
sp.l: Captain.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: How now, what's that?

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Why nothing Madam,
Onely an honet fellow kill'd in the torm,
And now his ghot walks; in his life time
He was a talking fellow, Hyppaus you know it.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: Hang you, what do I know?

sp.speaker: Caec.
sp.l: Why, Captain, Captain?

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Plague on you, would you were gagg'd.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: This is trange!

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Nay your Highnee need not be troubled,
I'le have a Schollar hall lay it at my own charge.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: Well Sir, if you'le be at that cot, I'le be the Scholar,
To raie it at my own.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Pox on your conjuring fools-head,
sp.stage: Hyppaus takes her out of the vau't with corn upon her farthingale, Peter following.
sp.l: By this light he ries—
Like Ceres with Plenty about her,
Lord, how Peter tares!

sp.speaker: Caec.
sp.l: Captain, Pray, your hand

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Here forooth.
Now have at the Princes, la, ra, ra, ra
Your Highnee may be pleas'd,
To pardon her uuall exercie,
She was the bet tilter in her time
That ever ran.

sp.speaker: Caec.
sp.l: O Captain, pray your hand,

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Now have I ague: what tends
This whiperig to?

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: Come Pyander,
The god of Love himelf is blind,
She, or her etate (I hear) is very fair.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Why, is your Highnee in earnet?
And pleae you hee's ome ourcore,
A dog were as good a husband for her
To lead her up and down.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: Madam, Will you conent to have this Gentleman?

sp.speaker: Caec.
sp.l: I have already yielded.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: And be hang'd 'twas before you were torm'd.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: Come it hall be a match, hee'l make you her Executor.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Well, wee'l all be marri'd then. Hypaus
If you pleae, you hall have Quinever.

sp.speaker: Pin.
sp.l: We are all happy then; we need not fear,
Unlee my Father frown.

sp.speaker: Phyl.
sp.l: We hall unwillingly throw off again
Our Loyalty to him, and yet we hall
Be very ready to embrace a witnee,
That we dare dye for Mironault.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: You nobly all oblige me, and I mut tell you
My dearet Princee that I cannot fear,
Whilt I enjoy your Love, for that has rais'd me
Above the power of Fate or danger,
Nor have I leiure to think on any thing,
But of thoe joys are falling now upon me,
Which neither time or age can ever leen;
For till your Virtues like Medea's charms
Shall bring freh beauties to my happy arms.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: We Bridegrooms diagree, for every day
Will oblige mot that adds to your decay.

div.head: The Fourth Book of VIRGILL. Of the Loves of DIDO and AENEAS.

argument.head: The Argument.
argument.l: In Love's ungentle Flames Dido Eliza fries,
With her Reolves a guilty Storm complies.
Aeneas, warn'd by Joves Mercurie Cyllenian Mate,
Prepares for flight, and Dido for her fate.
A Funerall Pile he raies, and betows
At once a Fate upon her elf and woes.

lg.l: BUT, long before, the Queen had in her veins
Nourih'd Love's wounds, and fed concealed flames.
Much on his peron, and his generous kind
She thought, much on the vertues of his mind.
His charming Image fixes in her breat,
And cares now banih once-enjoyed ret.
Th'enuing day, when Phoebus newly pread
His beams, and moit hades from Aurora fled;
The Love-ick Queen thus to her Siter aid:
My Anna, of what dreams am I afraid?
What guet is this with unaccutom'd charms?
How noble in his Soul? how brave in Arms?
I'think (nor vainly) he's of heavenly kind;
'Tis fear that argues a degenerate mind.
What various fates he told, with Battles mixt!
VVere it not in my breat for ever fix'd,
Never the Marriage Fetters more to prove,
Since o deceiv'd by fate of my firt Love;
Did I not loath thoe Rites a econd time,
I might perhaps yield to this tempting crime.
For I confes, ince (lain by fratricide)
Sichaeus fell, whoe blood the Altars di'd, Her husband lain by her own brother Pigmalion.
This onely has enclin'd my thoughts; again
I feel impreions of an antient flame.
But may the earth firt natch me to her womb,
And to the hades Jove's Thunder whirle me down;
To Hell's dark hades whoe night admits no fate,
E're hame and vertues rites I violate.
He who firt made my heart Love's acrifice,
Still has it, in his grave it buried lies.
This aid, a hower of falling tears appear.
Anna replies, Dear iter, and more dear
Then Light it elf, hall grief thy youth detroy,
VVithout the Crown of children, or the joy
VVhich Venus for her Votaries prepares?
Can dut hut up in graves, or Ghots have cares?
Grant you were he, whoe cold breat did didain,
The Lybians and the great King of the Numidians. Hiarba's flame,
And Africans made rich by vanquih'd foes;
VVill you as well, all Love's oft charms oppoe?
Think where we now inhabit, who dwells round;
Getulians here with conquet alwaies crown'd,
Here avage dearts your Dominions bound,
There the wild Barceans; what need I relate
The VVars, that on thy Brother's furie wait?
Sure the kind gods upon our hores at lat,
By an obliging torm thee Trojans cat.
VVhat Citie halt thouee? thy Kingdom too
Shall to this match enlarged fortune owe,
VVhen Trojans with our Arms their Swords hall joyn,
In what rich glories hall the Punicks shine!
Go, and oblige the gods by acrifice,
Thy guet by kindnee; all delays devie,
Whilt Winter rages, and the tormy Star
Their Navy hakes, the sky dipos'd to war.
"Thee words the parks of love now kindled more,
"And enthron'd hope where bluhes dwelt before.
Firt, at the Altars heaven's peace they ought,
With Sheep elected, lain as cutom taught,
To Ceres, Phoebus, Bacchus, above all,
To Juno, carefull of the Marriage thrall.
The fair Queen's hand a full-crown'd Bowl adorns,
Who pours the Wine 'twixt a white Heifer's horns.
Still on the fatted Shrine an Offering lies,
And day eems young renew'd with Sacrifice;
Conulting carce the life-foraken breat,
Which panting entralls faintly yet expret.
"Unknowing minds of Priets! alas, what eae
"Can Temples bring? Can frantick Vows appeae
"A flame, which life and blood till fuell gives,
"And in whoe breat the wound in ilence lives?
Unhappy Dido burns, and wanders round
The City, frantick, as a Hind, whoe wound
From a far off the unupected Swain
Gives ignorantly, who trives to flie her pain,
Through the Dictaean Forrets, wing'd with fears,
Yet till her ide the fatall Arrow bears.
Now with Aeneas round the walls he goes,
Her City and Sidonian-treaure hows.
About to peak, her words tick in the way;
Now Feats prepares to end the wating day.
Again (ditracted) asks to hears Troy's fate,
And on his moving lips her eyes till wait.
All now take leave, and the Moon's paler light
Shines out, declining Stars oft leeps invite;
Whilt he alone her orrows entertains,
And flung, on his foraken bed remains;
Thinks till he hears him peak, and in depight
Of abence, alwaies fancies him in ight;
Or in her arms his on and likenee takes,
To try if Love could leen by mitakes.
Now the late-riing Towers neglected tand,
The youth and fortrees alike unman'd.
All great beginnings interrupted lye,
And walls before which promis'd to be high.
When Juno aw her languih in a flame,
Whoe fury hrunk not at oppoing fame,
Venus with hate he finds; and thus then aies,
You, and your Boy, will purchae glorious praie,
And poils as ample as your powers, when fame
Shall tell; Two gods one woman overcame.
Nor am I blinded o, but it appears,
The walls of riing Carthage caue your fears.
But why thee quarrells? rather let them ceae
In Hymen's bonds, wrapt in eternal peace.
Your wihes all are crown'd in Dido's flames,
Which fill, intead of bloud, her burning veins;
With equall power and kindnee let us way,
Thee everall Nations, let her too obey
A Phrygian Lord, and unto thy deire,
Submit the Tyrians, and the wealth of Tyre;
To her, (for he perceiv'd a crafty mind
Sent all thee words, by which he had deign'd
To Lybian hores th' Italian crown to joyne)
Venus replies, Who is it will decline
What you propoe? or is o void of ene,
To chue to have with you a difference?
If the fates yield to your propos'd intents,
(But varying fates I fear) if Jove conents;
That Troy and Carthage hould as one be joyn'd,
The mingled Nations too by leagues combind;
You that enjoy his breat, 'tis jut that you
Attempt his mind, I'le econd what you do.
The Queen of Heaven then replies, That toil
And labour hall be mine; A little while,
I aske you now to hear, whilt I lay down
The means; which our deignes at lat may crown.
Aeneas, with the wretched Queen prepares,
In woods and hunting to divert their cares;
When the next riing Sun gives day a birth,
And with his raies hews the unvailed earth;
Upon the Hunters, whilt the game's puru'd,
A torm, weld big with hail, in blacknee brew'd,
Its fury hall dicharge; at the ame time,
The Heavens to the torm hall Thunder joyn.
Th' affrighted Hunters all hall take their flight,
Confus'd in darknee, as if lot in night.
The Prince and Queen hall flye for helter too
Into one Cave, if we receive from you
Your promis'd aid, there Hymen being by,
Wee'l make her thy perpetuall Votary.
Fair Cytherea, finding her deignes,
Smiles, and, in hew, to what he ask't inclines.
In the mean time, the Sun the briny treams
Of Neptune leav's, the youth rie with his beams.
And forth the toyl's, and well-nos'd hounds are brought,
With pears, whoe tops were round with Iron wrought.
Next marching forth, Maylian troops are een,
The Punick Princes all expect their Queen.
Who, lower than the ret, forakes her bed,
Whilt her proud hore tands r • chly furnihed
In purple; on which Gold in windings flow's,
Champing his bitt, in foam his mettall how's.
At length, attended by a noble train,
Clad in a rich Sydonian robe he came.
Her quiver gold, her hair too weaved lies
In gold, and gold her purple garments ties.
The Phrygians next advance, and before thee
Acanius came, whom youthfull hopes did pleae
Of promis'd port; with thee Aeneas joyns,
And all the troop in charming looks out-hines.
As when cold Lycia, and where Xanthus flowes,
Apollo leav's, his viits now betowes
Upon his native Delos, where again,
The Driopes and Cretans fill his train.
With Agathyrians, whom trange colours dye,
And in wild motions round the Altars flye,
VVhilt he upon the top of Cynthus goes,
His flowing hair, oft laurell-wreaths incloe;
Through which the weaved gold its lutre flung,
And at his back, his ratling Quiver hung.
"Nor did Aeneas looks admit an odds,
"But with his lutre equalled the gods?
VVhen new thee troops unto the hills arrive,
And beat the unfrequented hades, they drive
VVild goats from their high holds, and wing'd with fear,
On t'other ide ruh down vat heards of Deer.
But young Acanius in the vales employes
Himelfe, and in his hore's fiercenee joyes.
Now vi • s with thee, now others leaves behind,
And wanting beats to chae, wihes to find
A chaing Boar o're-pread with rage and foam,
Or from the hills to ee a Lion come.
Whilt thus he wih't, lowd murmurs fill the skie,
Follow'd by torms of hail, the hunters flie
For everall helters, whilt amazed ight
From mountains tops ees Rivers take their flight.
The Queen and Trojan Prince, eeking to ave
Themelves from torms, meet in one fatall cave,
The earth firt hook, and Juno gave the igne,
And at uch rites ungentle flahes hine.
While, through the concious aire, the Marriageong,
VVas howls of Nymphs, which from the mountains rung.
This day firt uher'd death, and from this day,
Misfortunes took their birth, nor did he weigh
Her preent act, or think of future fame,
Nor could this amorous theft beget a hame;
She cal'd it marriage, with a fond deigne,
Believing in the name to hide the crime.
But quickly now that lighted fame took wings,
And all the newes through Lybian Cities flings.
Unto ill fame compar'd, wift things are loath,
For as it flies, it gathers trength and growth;
Fear keeps it low at firt, but free from dread,
Quickly in clouds, hides its apiring head.
To Caeus, and Enceladus, the earth
Brooded on by the rage of gods gave birth
Unto this iter lat, than winds more fleet;
Swift in her wings, and not lee wift in feet.
A horrid and trange monter as he flyes,
Under her feathers hides an hundred eyes,
As many mouths, nor furniht lee with ears,
As many tongues to tell the tales he hears.
When night has pread her hades through heaven he flies,
Nor has oft leep the power to cloe her eyes,
By day; where poor and great men live he its,
And with her tales gives Citties haking fits:
The fale and true alike to people brings,
With equall joy things done and undone ings.
Of Troy's great Prince he quickly did report,
How entertaind in Dido's breat and court,
Unmindfull of their Crowns, ruld now by lut,
The winter pent in paions too unjut.
Among the ret to whom he pread this Fame,
It quickly unto King Hiarbas came.
The torie rais'd his furie, who was on
To Jove, from raviht Garamantis prung.
An hundred Temples he to Jove had rais'd,
As many hrines where contant fires till blaz'd.
The Gods perpetuall watch, th'enriched ground,
With blood, th'entrances with garlands crown'd,
The bitter news rage and ditraction brings;
To fill his breat, who in his fur • e flings
Before the Altars of the gods, and there
With raied hands ends this diputing pray'r;
Great Jove, to whom, on beds that richly hine,
We Moors indulge our feats with parkling wine,
Seet thou thee things? or hall we free from fright
See the dark air with udden flahes bright?
And dreadlee at thy winged lightnings flame
Or lighted Thunders, find our fears were vain?
A wandring woman on our hores that pay'd
For leave and place to live on, and obey'd
Our laws, dares now depie our marriage bed,
For one Aeneas to her Kingdom fled.
This Paris with his troope that carly are
Like men, in their oft robes and perfum'd hair,
Enjoys my paion's object, whilt we raie
In vain to thee our offerings and our praie.
Whilt thus expotulating-pray'rs he fent,
Holding the Altars till, th' Omnipotent
To Carthage turns his eyes, where paion's flame
Had in the Lovers burnt the thoughts of Fame.
Then calling Mercurie he thus begins,
Go on, call Zephyrus and on thy wings,
Hate to the Trojan Prince, who idly • ays
In Carthage, and contemns in his delays
Crowns which were promis'd him by Fate and Time,
Swift as a thought bear him thee thoughts of mine.
His beauteous mother never promis'd me
Such things as thee, nor for this caue was he
Twice from the Grecians free'd, but that there may
One pring from Teucer, Italy to way
So big with War and Empires; and to give
Laws, under which th'obliged World hould live.
But if uch praie cannot his mind enflame,
Nor toils be pois'd with weight of endlee Fame,
Why does he hinder from Acanius brows
The Roman Crown? What is it hope allows,
Whilt thus with foes (delaying) he remains?
Neglects Auonia, and Lavinian plains?
Bid him to ea, go tell him what I ay.
The ready god prepares treight to obey
His mighty Father's will, and firt he ties
Wings to his feet; born upon which he flies
Through air, and o're the earth, and liquid plain,
Swift as the motion of a rapid flame.
Then takes his rod; whoe call ghots from below
Obey, by the ame power others go
Unto thoe dimall hades, leep comes and flies
As he appoints; and cloes dying eyes.
Th'enraged winds well as he dyes along,
And drive the troubled clouds into a throng.
Now Atlas views, as on his wings he fled,
Approaching heaven with his apiring head,
Batter'd with winds and torms, with tall Pines crown'd,
And till with able clowds envellop'd round:
His houlders pret with undiolved now,
And from the old man's Chin wift rivers flow
In ruhing cataracts, in frozen ties
His horrid beard bound up everely, lies.
Here firt with equally unmoving wings

l.hi: Cyllenius

lg.l: Along the hores a bird thus wiftly glides
Cloe on the urface of the welling tides;
So from high Atlas-top Cyllenius flies
'Twixt heaven and earth, where andie Lybia lies.
When firt on Carthage-plains his winged feet
Took ret, his eyes as oon Aeneas meet
Raiing new Towers; on his thigh there hung
A hining word, a Tyrian garment flung
Over his houlders, where the gold did wave
In glittering rings, which Dido made and gave.
When with thee words the god invades his car,
Dot thou for Carthage lay foundations here,
And rai • et Cities, now uxorious grown,
Seeking trange Crowns, unmindfull of thine own?
He who o're all th'immortall gods bears way,
And whom the people of the earth obey,
Commanded me to ask, What vain deign
Stays thee in Lybia, idly loing time?
If o much glory cann't thy mind inflame,
Nor toils be pois'd with weight of endles fame;
Let not Acartus uffer by thy crime,
To whom the Fates th'I • alian Crown deign.
Thus having poke Cyllenius takes his flight,
And in the air lides from enquiring ight.
Amaz'd Aeneas tands, in h • rror ti'd,
VVith tifned hair, his voice and words deni'd,
Now burns to leave the place but lately priz'd,
So by the god commanded and advis'd,
VVhat hould he do? how venture to relate
This change to her that was o paionate?
His mind travails through-thoughts as in a trance,
And natch'd with every various circumtance,
Till every thought to this ubmiion gave.
Then Mnetheus and Sergetus, with the brave
Cloanthus, he does call; with ilent care
Bids them the Navy and their Arms prepare,
And draw their Forces to the Ocean ide;
But with a feigned caue the true to hide.
In the mean pace (whilt Dido little thought
Their loves were to o near a period brought)
He pays his viits, and neglects no time,
All his addrees fits for his deigne,
VVith all the art of oftet words, whilt they
VVith gladnee do their Princes will obey.
But the fair Queen (for who can long deceive
A Lover?) quickly did the fraud perceive,
And from the preent makes her future ghee;
VVhat ever eems mot afe, fears not the lee.
The ame ungentle Fame the news now brings
To ad Eliza, who now madly flings
Thorough the City, paion o excites
The wretched Queen, like Thyas at thoe Rites
VVhen firt the Orgyes tir, and Bacchus name
Cythaeron loudly does in night proclaim.
At length unto Aeneas thus he aies,
Hat thou deign'd all thee diembling ways?
Could there, fale man, be o much ill in thee,
In ilence to have fled this place and me?
Cannot my love, that love, which I o late
Plighted to thee, nor my approaching fate,
Oblige thy tay; but among Winter-waves
To thrut thy Navy, whilt the North-wind raves.
What if you never ought an unknown Land,
And antient Troy did in its lutre tand;
Mut needs that Troy, through Billows welling high,
Be ought with Navies? Is't not me you flie?
By thy receiv'd right hand, and by thee tears,
(Now nothing ele at my command appears)
By our young Loves, if ever I was thought
To merit, or to thee a pleaure brought:
Pitty a falling tate, change thy hard mind,
I beg, if prayers yet a place can find.
For thee, the Lybians, and Numidian King,
With Tyrians, will on me their malice fling.
For thee, my early and unpotted fame
Is lot, which once to Heaven bore my name.
To what am I now dying left? Ah guet,
In that, all Hymen's Titles now mut ret.
But why do I delay? Is it to ee
My Brother ruine all? or till I be
Led captive by Hyarbas? If I might
Have had a young Aeneas ere thy flight,
That onely might to me preent thy look,
I hould not fancy I were quite forlook.
This aid, forewarn'd by Jove within his breat,
With eyes till fix'd his troubles he uppret.
At length replies, Fair Queen, I cann't deny
Your words or merits, nor hall ever I
Unwillingly admit Eliza's name
Unto my thoughts, whilt life inpires this frame.
Thus much I onely ay, I never tri'd,
Or hop'd diemblingly my flight to hide.
Nor did I promie ever to be thine,
Or hither came with uch a fond deigne.
Would Fate permit, my will should now dipoe
My life, and as I pleas'd my cares and woes;
Troy and its Princely Palaces hould hine,
As once it did, rais'd by this hand of mine.
But Phoebus now and Lycian Lots decree,
That I hould fix my love on Italy.
If you, that from Phoenicia took your birth,
Affect this Carthage, and the Lybian earth;
VVhy hould it now appear more trange, that we,
Though Trojans born, hould eek for Italy?
The jutice is the ame. As often too,
As the dark night its humid shades does throw,
O're the hid world, and Stars begin to rie,
My Father's Ghot does threaten and advie.
Unjut to dear Acanius too I prove,
He wants a Crown, whilt here I idly love.
Now Mercury from Jove was ent (I wear
By both our heads) who through the yielding air
Brought his commands, apparent light and clear,
Shew'd me the god, and I his voice did hear.
Ceae then to wound with thee complaints of thine,
Since, though I go, 'twas not my own deign.
This aid, she turn'd her long averted ight,
Fix'd upon him, her eyes then took their flight,
And ilently on every object gaz'd;
At length she poke, to height of paion rais'd.
Per • idious man! Nor Dardan could begin
Thy race, or couldt thou from a goddee pring;
But bred on rocky Caucaus, thou firt
Wat by Hir • anian Tygers udders nurt.
For why hould I diemble? hould belief
Betray me to more woe? See if my grief
Has rais'd one igh, or does his eyes encline
To be o're-come in tears to pitty mine.
Where hould I firt complain? my mieries,
Nor Jove nor Juno ees with equall eyes.
Faith is untedfat till, fond woman's hate!
In want I found what I in plenty plac'd.
His Friends and Navy did by me return
From d • ath to life, Ah in what flames I burn?
Now Lot's, Apollo now, now from above
Cyllenius brings the harh commands of Jove.
'Tis likely that the gods hould from our cares,
Receive uch trouble, and proportion theirs.
I neither tay you, nor your words deny,
Seek through the waves and wind for Italy.
I hope (if gods be great as well as good)
That thou halt drink (drown'd in the rocky Flood)
Revenge's draught, and calling till on me,
Though abent, yet in flames I'le follow thee.
And when cold death hall ceae this vitall heat,
My ghot unwelcome viits hall repeat.
And all thy woes obliging Fame hall tell,
To my pleas'd ears when I with hadows dwell.
At this abruptly tops her words, and flies,
Sick of the light, and weary of mens eyes,
Leaving him fix'd with fears, and in delay,
Confus'd in all, preparing much to ay.
Whilt he inks to the earth on which he fled,
Carried by ervants to a Marble-bed.
Though the jut Prince enclin'd to give relief,
And to divert with words her powerfull grief,
Shook in his breat, where ighs and love did meet;
Yet he obeys the gods, and views his Fleet.
The Trojans throng, while launch'd from the hore's ide,
The 'nointed Veells now on Billows ride;
Carrying their Oars aboard, and Oak not quite
Brought into form, o carefull in their flight.
All from the City throng, as toyling Ants,
Treaure a Heap, remembring Winter's wants.
The black Troop through the verdant grae makes way,
And in a narrow road their tores convay;
Some bear the corn, the laziet of the Swarm
Others excite, and every place grows warm.
What were thy thoughts now Dido at this ight,
And what ad ighs did from thy breat take flight?
Hearing uch noie, and eeing from above
The hores grow warm with crowds. (Ungentle Love!)
What is't thou cant not us compell to do?
Again hee's forc'd in tears and prayers to woe.
No thought to Love obedience now deni'd,
Left dying, he had left a way untri'd.
Seet thou not, Siter, how they all repair
Down to the hores, and the ungentle air
Seems too to court their ails, the joys reound
From Sea-men, all their Veells ready crown'd.
Had I but thought that uch a woe could be,
I might have born it then; for, wretched me,
This one thing do, (for that fale man alone
Seem'd kind to thee, to thee his thoughts made known
The time, & how to often words you know,
Go and petition this inulting foe.
I never wore the Trojans to detroy,
Or did ait, or ent my hips to Tray;
Or yet diturb'd his Father's dut and ghot,
Why are my words to his clos'dears thus lot?
Ah! whither does he flie? let his hard breat
Grant but a wretched Lover's lat requet.
Let him but tay till he may afely flye,
Till neither winds grow lowd, or waves grow high.
I beg not now again his broken vows,
Or of the Latium Crown to rob his Brows:
I beg but time my paions to reprieve,
Till my hard fate has taught me how to grieve.
This lat requet I make, if pitty find
A power in your breat; my gratefull mind
Shall onely loe the memory in death.
Whilt tears he pent with this imploring breath,
To him, and back again, the wofull tales
Her Siter bears, but nothing now prevails;
Soft charming words had lot their power, oppos'd
By Fate, the god his gentler ears had clos'd.
An aged Oak o long had tood the blat
Of Alpine Boreas, now is this way cat,
Now that, whilt with the clamoring winds he trives,
Which to the earth th'aaulted branches drives;
The root yet fix'd, for what above appears,
So much below the earth's embraces bears.
So every way her words the Hero pret,
Shook by her cares within his mighty breat.
But his firm mind unhaken till appears,
And he, in vain, now pends her tock of tears.
Th' unhappy Queen, whom all thee fates affright,
Now wihes death, and hates to ee the light.
That too which added to thee ad deires,
VVhilt on the Altars in perfumed fires,
She paies her gifts, the acred wine no more,
Retains its looks, but turns black clotted gore.
This horrid change was to no eye reveal'd,
And from the truted iter too conceal'd.
Beides, there tood a marble Temple, made
To her firt love, to which he alwayes paid
An honour'd kindnee, alwayes too deck't round
VVith verdant wreaths, and nowie fleeces crown'd;
From whence he thought, he heard Sichaeus call.
And when the night had pre'd her vaile o're all,
The fatall Owle that perching place till eeks,
And ends out long and death-preaging hreeks.
The Priets before had threatned ad extreams,
The cruell Prince till viits her in dreams.
Alwayes he eems alone, and wandring trayes,
Seeking her ubjects in foraken wayes.
So Pentheus aw with his ditracted ight,
Furies in troops, at once two Suns gave light.
One Thebes two Cities hew'd, or on the tage,
As wild Oretes flyes his mothers rage.
VVith blazing brands, and with black erpents arm'd,
VVhilt in the gate, revenging furies warm'd?
Vanquih't with grief and paion in extreams,
She now reolves to dye, the time and means
Cloely deignes, nor could her thoughts appear,
Her looks were all compos'd erene and clear.
To her afflicted Siter then he goes,
And with thee words, her mind eems to dicloe.
Come hare with me the joy of my deigne,
That hall retore his love or banih mine.
Neer to the etting Sun and Oceans end,
A part of Aethiopia does extend.
VVhere mighty Atlas on his houlders bears
The glittering load of all the tarry phears.
Thence, (a Maylian born) a Prietee came,
That kept the Dragon and th'Heperian Fane;
Who alo did the acred branches keep,
With hony and with poppy cauing leep.
She could with charms enthralled minds et free,
And others bind with the ame cruelty.
Stars would retire, wift treams no longer run,
And from the graves, the cal'd up pirits come,
The earth mens frighted ears with howlings fills,
And the tall Oks eem walking from the hills.
VVitnee you gods, and my dear life, that now
Unwillingly to Magick arts I bow.
Go, in the inner Court erect a pyle,
Bring the man's word, and garments, now his poile.
Lay all the Impious left upon that bed,
VVhere I to ruine was by paion led.
For o the Prietee every thing deign'd,
Of a fale man hould diolution find.
This aid, on her till lips a palenee roe,
And yet her iter did not then uppoe
Under pretence of charms he meant to find
Her fate, or that uch fury rul'd her mind;
Or fear'd a crueller effect, or croe,
From any caue, than from her Husbands loe.
She therefore hatens to obey; the while,
The Queen within the Court doth raie a pile
Of pines and cloven Oaks, adorned round
VVith lights; with wreaths and funerall Cypree crown'd.
And on this pile the fatall bed convaid,
On which his garments and his word he laid.
With thee, plac't his effigies too, Alas,
Too knowing now of what would come to pae!
All this begirt with Altars, with looe hair,
The Prietee ends to many gods her pray'r
To Spirits, and inhabitants below,
To Cynthia, and to triple Hecate too.
Sprinkling feign'd dew, as from Avernus brought,
Herbs cut with brazen Sythes, by Moon-hine ought.
With poyon brew'd, from the Colts brow they tare
The much lov'd bit of the prevented mare.
The Queen with gifts, hard by the Altar tands,
Her garments looe, one foot releat from bands.
And dying now, her lat appeal does end,
To Gods and Planets, concious of her end.
If any Power mot with care urvaies
Loves too unequall bonds, to them he prayes.
T'was night, and wearied limbs with toils oppret,
Did in becalming leep's embraces ret.
The winds were huh't, the waves no longer weld,
And time the equall cales of midnight held.
The earth's and air's inhabitants, in dreams
VVere lock't, and caly troops affecting treams.
All in obliging leep receiv'd their hares,
Their hearts inenible of toils or cares.
But the unhappy Queen leep's charms denies,
Paion poet her breat, and tears her eyes.
Her cares increae, her love to fury grows,
And torms of anger with her paion roe.
Then to her elfe, raies this ad dicoure;
What hall I do? hall I go eek remore
Of lighted lovers? or beg to be priz'd,
By that Hiarbas whom I once depis'd?
Or hall I flye after the Trojan ails,
With whom the ene of kindnee o prevails?
Or were I willing, would they give me leave;
Or a corn'd thing in their proud hips receive?
Lot wretch! ee't thou not falenee fix't upon
The perjur'd race of fale Laomedon?
What then, hall I alone thee men purue,
Or let the armed Tyrians follow too?
And thoe which hardly once from Tyrus came,
Shall I perwade to go to Sea again?
No, no, 'tis only death is fit for thee,
Let his word end thy life and miery.
Thou iter, firt (yet with my weeping pret)
Didt help this enemy into my bret.
Why might not we like wild beats alwayes live,
And know no cares that love and paion give?
Then, not oblig'd, I had not been unjut,
In forgot-kindnee to Sichaeus dut.
Such great and ad complaints denied her ret,
In troops aaulting now her broken bret.
Sleep then did on the Trojan Prince prevail,
Who in his tall hip lay prepar'd to ail.
To whom, Jove's meenger appears once more,
Repeates the warnings that he gave before;
(In voice and every thing like Hermes how'd,
His youth the ame, his hining hair o flow'd.)
Thou heavenly-born, Cant thou oft leep admit,
Not enible what dangers threaten yet?
Nor yet dicernet how the properous gales,
With gentle invitations court thy ails?
She now, ince death is her reolv'd deigne,
Guided by rage, tops at no fraud or crime.
Fly whilt thou may't, left thou eet veells warm,
On troubled waves, and hores with flames grow warm
If by this Land, you wait approaching day,
Then put an end unto this dull delay.
The minds of women never yet were fix't:
This aid, with nights dark hades himelf he mixt.
No ooner now this mighty Viion ends,
But traight Aeneas, rows'd himelfe and friends;
Urging them on, to haten from thoe hores,
VVith hate to pread their ails, and ply their Oars.
A God ent from above came to exile,
And with Commands, to haten too our flight.
VVhich of the gods o e're thou art, we flye
As thou direct't, ob • ying chearfully.
Be thou till pleas'd to guide us and protect,
And every tar propitiouly direct.
This aid, his hining word draws from his ide,
And cuts the Cable which his veell ty'd,
The ret with equall hate repeat his deed,
And quickly from the hores their veells freed.
Much of the Sea with hips was cover'd now,
Forcing white furrows on its blewih brow.
Now on the earth, the firt bright meage fled
Of fair Aurora's leaving Tithon's bed.
VVhen firt the Queen aw the approaching light,
VVith it the empty port, the hips in flight:
Her breat, where yet o many beauties were,
She fills with troaks, and tears her hining hair.
Then cries, O Jupiter, hall he thus flye,
And fix on us o great a mockery?
Are none yet arm'd, no Ships yet thrut from hores?
Purue with flames, bring ails, employ your Oars;
VVhat do I talk of, or where am I now?
VVhat rage, and impious fancies I allow?
Unhappy Queen, thee thoughts hould have born way,
Before thy Scepter thou hadt it flung away.
Behold his faith, who yet they ay before,
His Countries gods through all his travails bore!
VVho on his houlders bore his fathers weight,
Pret too with age, declining to his fate.
Cannot I throw his catter'd limbs to waves,
And give his friends too uch unpittied graves?
Might not Acanius perih by my word,
Then dih the Boy up to his fathers board?
Th' event of War is doubtfull: be it o,
The dying ure never needs fear a foe.
Swift flames among their hips I hould have flung,
In which at once, the father and the on
Should have been lot, and in the ame deigne,
With their ad fates, I would have mingled mine.
Thou Sun that eet all things, that mortalls do!
Thou Juno, concious of my paions too:
And Hecate, whoe howls fills night and wayes,
You furies too, hear what Eliza pray's
The lat her dying lips ever deignes!
Let your revenge be great, as are their crimes.
If uch an impious man, mut afely find
Through eas, places and Lands for him deign'd,
If this be fates unalterable doom,
Let him among a warlike people come
Vext till with uch, driven from place to place,
And natch't from his Acanius lov'd embrace.
Still begging aid, let objects for his eyes
Be till his wretched friends ad obe • uies.
And when dihonour'd peace hall all unite;
Let him enjoy neither his Crown nor Light:
But fall before his day, the and his grave,
The god's thee prayers with my blood hall have.
And you, O Tyrians, in your hate be jut,
Let that be till a tribute to my dut.
Never let Love oblige, nor League make tyes,
And from our loyns may ome revenger rie,
That on the Dardan race, may pay thee cor's,
With fire & word; may hores contend with hores,
Billow's with waves, and armies againt arms,
And all his race parih in civill harms.
This aid, her crowdes of thoughts were now at trife,
Which way to rid her elfe of hated life.
Then to Sichaeus nure her elfe addret,
(Her's in her native grave enjoyed ret)
Thus aid, Dear nure, my iter hither bring,
Firt having hath'd her body in a pring,
And with her bring the Sacrifice deign'd,
And you your head with acred fillers bind.
For Pluto's rites I'le end, with them my woe,
Whilt on the Dardans funerall pile I throw
His Image, to the flames ungentle rage.
This aid, the nure's gate hew'd hate and age.
But wing'd with horrid fancies Dido flyes.
Unto her fate, rolling her bloody eyes.
In her air cheeks, ad looks poet the room.
And palenee of that death that was to come.
Thorough the Inner Court her tops he bends,
And furiouly the funerall Pile acends.
Then draws the Dardan' word, never deign'd
For uch a horrid ue; her eyes next find
His bed, which only now his garments bears.
A little while he paus'd, by thoughts and tears
Shar • rs in time delay'd, her elfe then cat
Upon the bed, and thus he poke her lat.
Dear poils, whilt gods and fate did o agree!
Receive my life, from cares now et me free.
Here I have liv'd the lave of Fortune till,
Now under earth my shade ome place mut fill.
A City I have built, reveng'd the fate
Of a lot Husband, and a Brother's hate.
Happy, ah too much happy I had been,
Had never Trojan-Sails my Carthage een.
This aid, she kis'd the bed, then cries, Mut I
Thus poorly fall, and unrevenged die?
But die I mut, death onely can give eae,
The thoughts oft'other world alone can pleae.
Let my lat flame blaze in his cruell eyes,
Shook at the Omen, whilt Eliza dies.
This aid, he thrut the word into her breat,
And flowing blood the wretched act expret.
The lofty Pallace ecehoes now with cries,
And fame through all the shaken City flies:
The roofs reound with womens houls and moans,
And ecchoing aire affected eems with groans.
So it had been, if to an armed Hot
The antient Tyre or Carthage had been lot.
And the impartiall flames shewing no odds,
On inking dwellings both of men and gods.
Her Siter hears, who with a haking pace,
Beating her breat, arrives unto the place;
Thorough encreaing crowds he ruhing came,
Still calling on her dying Siter's name.
Was this thy cruell fraud, was I o pret
For uch a Pile? for this were Altars dret?
What should a wretch o much foraken do?
Did you corn, Siter, I should die with you?
Death should have had on both an equall power,
We should have shar'd one grief, one word, one hour.
Thee with my hands I rais'd, my prayers fled
To gods, did I compoe thee for the dead
To live behind? Thy fate now ruines all,
Thy Siter inks, and Kingdom in thy fall.
Some water bring that I may bathe the wound,
If any wandring breath may yet befound.
To hers my lips o cloely hall be laid,
That it hall find no way but me. This aid,
She mounts the Pile, and in her boom took
Her Siter, yet by breath not quite forook.
She grieves, yet till attempting all he cou'd,
And with her garments dries away the bloud.
She trives to raie her eyes, by weaknee pret,
Her eye-lids inck, the wound gapes on her breat.
Thrice he attempted from the bed to rie,
Thrice roles upon the bed with wandring eyes.
She makes aint • arches now for heavens light,
And groanes, when found by her impairing ight.
But Juno pittying the punihment
Of trugling life, from heaven Iris ent,
To et at freedom he¯r delaying breath,
Since neither fate, nor a deerved death
Had cau'd her end, but fell before her time:
Love's paion was alone her fate and crime.
Nor yet had Proerpine took from her head
Her hair, and enter'd her among the dead.
From heaven then, Iris with dewie wings,
On which the Sun a thouand glories flings,
Flies to her head, This to the dark abode
I bear, and free thee from thy body's load.
She aid; then with her right hand cuts her hair,
And her enlarged breath lides into aire.

div.head: P. PAPINIUS STATIUS, His ACHILLEIS; The First Book.

argument.head: The Argument.
argument.l: The Rape's committed. Thetis begs in vain
Of Neptune a rough torm to well the Main.
Then to Aemonia through the Sea he goes, Thealy
And viits the lov'd caue of all her woes.

lg.l:
THe great Achilles, called Aeacides, from Aeac ••
his Grandfather. Aeacides, my Mue, now ing;
An Iue fear'd by Heavens thundring King.
Much of his acts, though in admired trains,
Great Homer ung; yet much untold remains.
We his firt deeds relate, and how conceal'd,
In Scyros by a Trumpet's ound reveal'd.
Not of dragg'd Hector to his Chariot ty'd,
I ing, but how the Youth to Troy arriv'd.
Thou, Phoebus, (if deerv'd in former layes)
Give me freh treams, and now with econd Bayes
Adorn my brows. For I the hallowed ground
Have known before, with acred Fillets crown'd:
Witnee thoe Theban fields, for which my fame
Shall lat, whilt Thebes records Amphion's name.
But Domitian the Emperor, to whom the Poet addreeth this Complement. Thou by Greeks and Romans all renown'd,
Both with the wreaths of Mars and Phoebus crown'd.
(Who lately griev'dt from thy contended brow
To lay the gentler one) permit me now
To guide my fearfull pen a little while,
And on the great Achilles acts to toyl,
Till I ing Thine, yet wanting confidence,
And for thy Prelude with his name dipence.
The Trojan Swain, from the Laconian Shoar
Sail'd, and from unupecting Sparta bore
A prey, and in his guilty journey howes
His mother's dream fulfill'd, preaging woes.
Upon thoe treams they ayl, where Helle found
Her fate, yet now among the Sea-gods crown'd.
When Thetis (never yet, alas! in vain
Were parents propheies) through the clear Main,
Affrighted aw the Phrygian Oars, he fled,
Withall the Sea-Nymphs, from her watry bed.
The almot-meeting Shores heat with the warm,
And from the throng the crowded waves grew warm.
When Thetis through the parting Billows roe,
To me he cry'd, This Navy threatneth woes.
What Proteus told, alas! appears too true.
See Priam's kindled flames; the daughter too
Bellona brings! a thouand Ships appear,
Which Ionian and Aegean Billows bear.
All the worn Greeks whom the Atrides got
Mut not uffice: Land, Ocean mut be ought
For my Achilles. To what purpoe then
Was he on Pelion bred, in Chiron's den?
There with the Lapithites (unlee I fear
In vain) he fights, and tries his father's Spear.
Ah me! this fear upon my heart prevails
Too late. Why could not I, when firt thee Sails
Swell'd on my Streams, act what I now would do,
And make a torm the lutfull Thief purue,
With all the Sea-Nymphs help'd? Storms now will come
Too late; the Rape and Injury is done.
Yet I will go, and all the remedy,
That's left, attempt; I'le move each deity
That rules in Flouds, and beg the Ocean's King
By Tethys, on the waves one torm to fling.
No ooner aid, but he the god epy'd,
Who from Oceanus crown'd boards arriv'd.
The chearing Nectar in his looks yet hin'd:
At whoe approach, the torms, with every wind,
Were all in ilence huh'd; and round by him,
Sounding their wreathed hells, the Tritons wim:
The hoals of Whales, like moving Rocks, make way,
And round their King, the crooked Dolphines play.
He, rais'd above the quiet Ocean, rides,
And with his Trident his yok'd Hores guides:
They with their crooked tails the Chariot row,
And from their breats the foaming urges throw.
To whom ad Thetis aid, Great Ocean's King,
Dot thou not ee thy waves aitance bring
To trange deignes? The guilty afely go,
Since Sea's reerved rights were leighted o
By the bold Jaon: His example left
See by thee follow'd, both in crime and theft:
And from the friendly hores an unjut prey
By the rah Judge of Ida's born away.
Ah me! what mournings hall this caue to be
In heaven and earth! and what, alas, to me!
Is this a Foter-child's return? This way
Will Venus for her Phrygian Garland pay?
At leat o're-whelm thee hips, (for in the throng,
No Heroes, nor our Theeus goes along)
If any jutice yet in waves can be;
Or ele commit the power of torms to me.
Nor is't ungentle, while 'tis jut that I
Fear for a child. Let the mad waves well high:
Nor uffer me from Flouds to take my leave,
Onely by his affected Tomb to grieve.
Thus begging, he before the Chariot tood,
With cattered hair. The Ruler of the Flood
Invites her up, and trives uch words to find,
As might appeae her ad afflicted mind.
Ask not their ruine, Thetis: 'tis in vain,
The gods and Fates do otherwie ordain.
Sad years to come with laughters are decreed
By Jove, Europe and Aia both mut bleed.
What triumphs halt thou have in Phrygian plains,
To ee thy on there feed the funerall flames?
When he the Trojan fields hall tain with blood,
And with like laughters cram the bluhing Flood?
Great Hector's weight hall make his Chariot low,
Thoe walls we rais'd his hand hall overthrow.
Nor grieve that thou hat toop'd to Peleus love,
The Son thou hat by him is worthy Jove.
Nor halt thou unreveng'd for ever mourn,
When they return thy pow'r hall raie a torm:
Fale flames by night, hall Caphareus then how,
And joynt-revenge wee'l on Ulyes throw;
At this, he hung thoe looks that did incline,
To raie a torm; and changing the deigne
With labouring arms to Thealy he wims,
And on thoe hores he rets her nowy limbs.
The mountains joy, with that much loved place,
Where Peleus did the goddee firt embrace;
Above his banks the wel'd Sperchios roe,
Joy'd whilt his tream about the goddee flows.
She took no joy in all, but till oppres'd
With the ad fancies of her carefull breat.
Thus fill'd with buie thoughts the goddee then,
Approacheth to the aged Chirons den;
Under the rock, where Pelion doth encline
Like a bent bow: o wrought by Art and Time.
Still here the igns remain'd, where, at their feats,
The beds were pres'd by the immortall guets,
Which in the tables of the Centaur tood,
Not like the ret of the prodigious brood.
His darts untain'd with human cruelties,
Never did he with vat ubverted trees.
Or may bowls, diturb the geniall crue,
Only at Beats, his guiltlee arrows flew.
But now by age diarm'd, with herbs he tries
To retore life her tired faculties:
Or to Achilles, all the glorious things,
Farn'd Heroes did, upon his harp he ings.
'Gaint whoe return from his purued game,
The boards are crown'd; and with the kindled flame
The cave growes bright, whilt thus he did provide,
Looking for him, his Mother he epy'd.
To her he hats, (while trength his gladnee yields)
And trots upon the long unued fields.
To her he bowes his aged Limbs, and then,
Leads the ad goddee to his humble den.
Her buie eye, that would not be delay'd,
Quickly views all, as oon to Chiron aid;
Where is my pledge! or why do you thus trut,
My child alone? Are my ad dreams then jut?
Thoe dreadfull viions which the gods have et
Before mine eyes, I wih as vain as great.
My breat eems wounded now; my hands, to bear
The ignes of trokes; wild beat's, my boome tear.
And many times I fancy in my dreams,
Again I dip my child in Stygian treams.
With Magick art, at lat a way I've got,
To cure my fears, by the kind Proteus taught:
The Youth mut be to thoe fit parts convay'd,
For uch deig •• s, in ecret billows laid.
Where horrid acrifices are to th' hid,
And unknown gods, But more I am forbid.
Thee rites demand him now: Thus Thetis aid:
The aged Chiron ele had not obey'd,
If he had known what garments once hould hide
The youth. But ignorant he thus repli'd;
Purue, kind goddee, this unknown deigne:
With humble vows th' ungentle powers encline.
Not thy ambitious prayers can ucceed,
To pleae the envious gods, nor would I breed
New fears in thee; but I confee my hare,
Nor yet deceived by a Father's care:
'Tis his vat trength, that thus procures my fears,
Which hews too early for his tender years.
At firt, my threatning words he would obey,
Nor would too farre about the mountains tray.
Not Oa now, nor Pelion can contain
His wandrings, nor Thealian feather'd rain.
To me the Centaurs often make their moan,
Forc't from their Heards, puru'd by him alone,
Who ingly dares with all their troops engage,
Whilt force and fraud they threaten in their rage.
Lately I aw Alcides on this hore,
And Jheeus, whom the Argive hip then bore.
But ee, he comes,—At this abruptly taid,
Th' expecting goddee chilling fears invade.
The Youth arriv'd, loaded with dut and weat,
And wearied with his arms and labours; yet.
His nowy looks, the roy bluhes tain'd;
His hair the hining Gold with glittering ham'd.
Upon his cheelis no Down yet eem'd to rie:
A gentle lutre in his parkling eyes
Still hin'd; his face thoe charming beauties wore,
VVhich his admired Mother had before.
So hews young Phaebus, when he doth retire
From Lycia, and for hafts aumes his lyre.
By chance he came in pleas'd, (O how much more
It added to what was o well before!)
For under Pholoe in a Cave he lew
A Lionee, and took the young ones too,
Which in his arms he bore. But the lov'd prey,
At his dear mother's ight he threw away;
By Chiron now embrac'd, and then again
Doth in his mother's jealous arms remain;
When treight his dearet friend Patroclus came,
In love and age his equall; and the ame
Aay'd in generous Arts to imitate,
Yet hort in trength, but har'd an equall fate.
The next adjacent tream Achilles eeks,
And with the River cleans'd his ullied cheeks.
So tired Cator in Eurota's treams
Retores his looks, bright as his new Star's beams.
Plea'd Chiron on his fair proportion tares.
The joy that Thetis took made great her cares.
The Centaur then invites them to his Feat,
And fills Lyaeus to his troubled guet.
His Harp to welcome Thetis he prepares,
Whoe charming notes leen the weight of cares.
And having gently tri'd the warbling trings,
He gives it to Aeacides, who ings.
The acts of Heroes; how great Juno's pleen
Vanquih'd o oft by Hercules had been;
The Victories of Pollux; and how too
The montrous Minotaur fam'd Theeus lew.
Latly, great Peleus, and his Mother's love
He ung, the Marriage grac'd by thoe above.
At this, ad Thetis eem'd to force a a mile.
Night now laid on her heavy charms the while.
Achilles the kind Centaur's houlder took,
And his affecting Mother's breat forook.

div.head: ANNOTATIONS On the firt Book of STATIUS his ACHILLEIS.
div.p: 2. AN iue fear'd by heaven's thundring King.] When Jove ought the marriage of Thetis, he was told by Proteus, that the iue that came from Thetis hould exceed the father who begot it: At which, mitruting his own Omnipotency, he left his Love to keep Heaven. The Fable is thus rendred by the incomparable Sandys, Metamorph. 11.

q.l: For aged Proteus thus foretold the truth,
To wave-wet Thetis, thou halt bear a Youth,
Greater then him from whom he took his birth
In Arms and Fame. Let any thing on earth
Should be more great than Jove, Jove huns the bed
Of Sea-thron'd Thetis, though her beauty led
His strong deires: Who bids Aeacides
Succeed his Love, and wed the Queen of Seas.

div.p: 6. Scyros.] An Iland of the Aegean Sea, one of the Cyclades, over againt Peloponneus, (as Strabo, l. 10. relateth) having a Town of the ame name; famous mot, in being the place where Achilles lived diguied. See Servius and Sabinus on Virgil's Aen. 2.

7. Not of dragg'd Hector, &c.] Statius here propoeth his deigne, to ing the acts of Achilles onely from his infancy, which Homer had omitted, jutly preenting the death of Hector for all his Victories; whoe fate was Troy's ruine. Senec. Troad. v. 185.

q.l: Aut cùm uperbo victor in curru tetit,
Egitque habenas, Hectorem & Trojam trahens.
Or when the Conqueror did his Hores guide,
And Troy which Hector at his Chariot ty'd.

div.p: For Achilles having killed him, tied him to his Chariot, and dragged him thrice round the walls of Troy, as Homer, Iliad 22. Which unwelcome ight Aeneas aw painted at Carthage, Virg. Aen. 2. 487.

q.l: Ter circum Iliacos raptaver at Hectora muros,
Examinumque auro corpus vendebat Achilles.
Tum verò ingentem gemitum dat pectore ab imo,
t polia, ut currus, utque ipum corpus amici,
Tendentemque manus Priamum conpexit inermes.
About Troy's walls Hector's dead body thrice
Achilles dragg'd, and old it for a price.
Then from the bottom of his breat he drew
A grief-expreing igh, his friend to view,
His Spoils and Charior, and how Priam tands
Begging with his erected aged hands.

div.p: 12. With acred fillets bound.] Thee were Ornaments for the Priets heads; in Latine, Vittae. Hence Juvenal Sat. 4. of the Vetall Virgin, Vittat • Sacerdos. And Virgil thus preenteth Anius, Aen. 3. 80.

q.l: Rex Anius, Rex idem hominum Phoebique Sacerdos,
Vittis & acra redimitus tempora lauro.
Anius a King and Priet, his Temples bound
With acred Fillets, and with Lawrel crown'd.

div.p:
The Title of Priest was antiently conferr'd on Kings, as Caaubon, on Su • tonius in Augusto, delivereth from Aritotle, Polit. 3. and Syneius, Epit. 121. by reaon that the Government of all Commonwealths conited in Eccleiaticall Ceremonies, and Politicall Laws; the care of both which belonged to Kings. Hence Augustus was created chief Priet, that all kinds of power might be in him. And as Servius oberveth (on Aen. 3. 80.) the tyle of Pontifex Max.
was till aumed by the ucceeding Emperors; as may alo be een in the Incriptions of the Caears at the end of Suetonius, et forth by Schildius 1651. Poets called themelves Phoebus Priets; o Tibullus and Protertius frequently. Hereupon Statius here dreeth himelf with Prietly Ornaments.

13. Witnee thoe Theban fields, &c.] Our Poet here intimateth his Poem of the Theban-War: So that hence, and by the enuing Complement to Domitius it is clear, that this was Statius his econd Work, and his Silvae the lat. To his Thebans, with confidence enough, he here prom • eth as lating a fame, as Thebes could give Amphion the on of Jupiter and Antiope, who having (as Plinie aith, l 7. c. 56.) found out the ue of the Harp, handled it o harmoniouly, that he made tones come of their own accord to raie the Walls of Thebes. Senec. Theb. act. 4.

q.l: —nulla quas truxit manus,
Sed convocatus vocis & citharae ono
Per e ipe turres venit in ummas lapis.
Rais'd by no labouring workman's hands, but brings
With his harmonious voice and charming trings
The willing tones together, which compoe
Themelves, and into lofty Towers • oe.

div.p: Some joyne his brother Zethus with him in the buinee. So Palaephatus, who reducing the Fable to a eeming truth, aith, The two Brothers admitted their Auditors to their Muick, on condition, that every one hould afford his aitance to the Building. A far truer Mythologie is glanced at by Horace, De arte Poet. v. 391.

q.l: Silvestres homines acer interpreque Deorum
Caedibus & victu foedo deterruit Orpheus,
Dictus ob hoc lenire Tigres rabidoque Leones.
Dictus & Amphion Thebanae conditor arcis
Saxa movere ono retu • inis, & prece blandâ
Ducere quò vellet.
Orpheus inpir'd from gods, firt rude men brought
From loving blood and laughters; hence was thought
Fierce Lions and wild Tigers to have tam'd.
And o Amphion with his Harp was fam'd
To raie the Theban walls, and at his choice
To move deaf tones with his admired voice.

div.p:
So perhaps the Fable aroe, from his reducing a avage people to
live under a form of Government; and for their afety (than which, no argument can be more prevalent) perwading them to compae in their City with a Wall. And herein, in my opinion, he was much more judicious than Lycurgus and Ageilaus, who believed the breats of valiant Citizens defence enough. And o alo thinketh Plato, l. 6. De leg. For thee reaons, Orpheus was aid to have made wild beats gentle, and Amphionto have moved tones, that is, men of avage lives and obdurat natures. Macrobius in Somn. Scip. l. 2. c. 3. keepeth cloer to the Fable; for etting f • rth the excellencies of Muick, he aith, That from it, the Univer • all Soul of the world took its originall; and that by it therefore all men, not onely the civill, but the barbarous alo, are either animated to ver • ue, or diolved into pleaure; quia anima in corpus defert memoriam Muicae, cujus in caelo fuit concia; Becaue the oul, though in the body, till retaineth a memory of that harmony which it enjoyed in heaven. And hence he conceiveth the Fables of Orpheus and Amphion had their Originall. See Clemens Alexandr. Admonit. ad Gentes, p. 2. Amphion's excellency proved his ruine: For contemning Latena, by her revenge he aw all his children lain, and at the lat added himelf to the number. Sandys Ovid's Metam. l. 6.

q.l: For ad Amphion wounding his own breat,
Had now his orrow with his oul releast.

div.p: 13. Trojan Swain] This title is uually given to Paris, by reaon he was brought up among the hepheards. The tory is thus, Hecuba being great with Paris, dreamed, he hould bring forth a flame that hould conume Troy, Cic. l, 1. de divinat. Whereupon Priam conulted the Oracle; and being told, his Queen hould bear a on, who hould be the Incendiary of his Country, he gave order the child hould be detroyed. But Hecuba deirous to preerve her Infant, conveyed him to mount Ida to be bred up among the hepheards. Where at length, being grown up, he pretended love to Oenone, and made every Tree witnee of his Amours; as the Nymph is made to complain by Ovid in her Epitle to Paris.

lg.l: Inciae ervant à te mea nomina fagi;
Et legor OENONE falce notata tuâ.
Et quantum trunci, tantùm mea nomina crecunt:
Crecite, & in titulos urgite ritè meos.
Populus et (memini) fluviali confita ripâ,
Et in qua notrî litera cripta memor
Popule, vive, • recor, quae conita margine ripae
Hoc in rugoo cortice carm • n habes.
CUM PARIS OENONE POTERIT SPIRARE RELICTA,
AD FONTEM XANTHI VERSA RECURRET AQUA.
Xanthe, retre propera, veraeque recurrite Lymphae:
Sutinet Oenonen deeruie Paris.
My name's preerv'd on every wounded Tree:
Their bark OENONE bears engrav'd by thee.
Whilt they encreae, my names enlarged grow;
To bear thoe titles may they till do o.
A Poplar grows, where crytall billows glide,
And hews thoe Letters carved on its ide.
Long may it live unprejudic'd by years,
Whoe rugged rind this fale Incription bears,
If Paris leave Oenone, yet not die,
Xanthus hall backward to his fountain flie.
Hate back, ye charged Streams, for Paris flies
His lov'd Oenone once, and yet not dies.

div.p:
His cating off this Nymph was occaioned by the three goddees repairing to him, about determining their controverie, as Oenone in the following Veres complaineth. Each goddee endeavoured to bribe the Judge, Juno, by promiing him Empire, Pallas, Wicom; enus, Pleaure. This lat was pronounced the fairet, and went away with the golden Apple: And in requitall, he directeth her Umpire to receive his promied reward in the fair Helen: Whom having een he loved, and ravihed from Sparta, where he had been kindly entertained. Coluthus and others ay, He had her conent; b • t Seneca, Troad. v. 917. bringeth her on the Stage excuing her elf, by pleading Enforcement: And Gorgias, in his defence of Helen, aith, Venus commanded her to uter the Trojan to enjoy her. Others ay, that Paris being ent to demand Heione, the daughter of Laomedon, whom Hercules had carried from Troy, had order given him. That, in cae the Greeks refued to deliver her, he hould ravih from them whatoever coniderable Lady he could light on. So Dares Phrygius, who reporteth alo, That Antenor was firt ent to fetch home Heione, but returned without her; and that all the Grecian Princes deny'd to make any atisfaction. Yet that Hector's advice was not to revenge the Rape, by warring againt their potent Confederates. And that afterwards Paris having received that encouragement from Venus, undertook the Voyage; and, by chance, arrived at the Iland Cythera, at a time when Helen was there, in a Town bearing her name: Who had no ooner heard of the Trojan
Prince's arrivall, but he had a deire to ee him: And o they being both enamoured of one another, Paris took her that night after his arrivall, out of Venus Temple, and brought her with him to Troy. And thus he proved that Fire-brand his mother dreamed of, kindling a flame that burnt Troy to ahes.

24. Laeonian.] The Poets word is Oebalio, from Oebalus a King of
• aconia, a region of Peloponneus, bordering on Meenia, Argia, and Arcadia, Strabo lib. 8. Pauanias, in Arcadicis, aith, it is divided from part of Arcadia, by the River Alpbeus In this Country, tood Lacedaemon, on the Wet ide of Eurotas, beneath the Mountain Taygetus: Strabo, l. 8. Polybius, lib. 5. But the proper name of the City was Sparta; Lacedaemon being more commonly ued for the Province, o called from a King of that name, who ometimes reigned there, and married Sparta the daughter of Eurotas, whoe name the City received. To the Lacedaemonians, Jonathan High Priet of the Jews wrote a Letter; aying, It was found in writing, that the Lacedaemonians and the Jewes were brethren, and that they were of the stock of Abraham, 1 Macc. 12. 21. Joeph, Antiq. l. 13. c. 8.

27. pon thoe streams, &c.] i. e. the Hellepont, which is not pat eight furlongs over, as Pliny tetifieth; About thirty miles below Gallipoli, it is not above half a mile over, as Sir Henry Blunt in his Travels relateth. This Strait parteth Europe from Aia: On Europe's ide, tandeth Sestus; on Aia's, Abydus, Towns famous by the Loves of Hero and Leander, ung by that weet Poet, whom Virgil giveth the preminence to, in the Elyian fields, Aen. 6. Leander perihed in thee treams, yet having his wihes Crowned; as Martiall repreenteth him in this Epigram.

q.l: Cùm peteret dulces audax Leandrus amores,
Et feus tumidis jam premeretur aquis:
Sic mier instantes affatus dicitur undas,
Parcite dum propero, mergite dum <> .
When bold Leander through the billows ought,
Love's joyes, his arms now almot over-wrought
With waves, he cried, Now pare me gentle Main,
And let me ink as I return again.

div.p:
But his Hero urvived but a while; For the next morning, eeing his dead body floting on the Waves, from the top of her Tower, he threw her elf into them. Nor lee memorable is this narrow Sea, for the bridges of Boats, that Xerxes made over it: The former of
which being broken by a udden tempet, the vain King courged the diobedient waves, and cut off the heads of the Workmen; and then caued another to be made with tronger ties, Heredot. P • lymniâ. The ame Author reporteth of Xerxes, that taking a view of his Land forces, that filled the hores and the plains, and of his Navy, that covered the Hellepont; He adly wept to think, that within an hundred years, not a man of all that multitude hould be living. So many they were, that Juvenal coffingly aid, Sat. 10.

q.l: —Credimus altos
Defecie amnes, epotáque flumina Medo
Prandente, & madidis cantat quae Softratus alis.
Ille tamen qualis rediit Salamine relictâ,
In Corum atque Eurum olitus aevire flagellis
Barbarus, Aeolio nunquam hoc in carcere paos?
Sed qualis rediit? nempe unâ nave cruentis
Fluctibus, ac tardâ per dena cadavera prorâ.
We have believ'd deep Rivers could not find,
Liquor for Xerxes army, while they din'd;
Things ung by Softratus, well drench'd with wine.
Yet he that o return'd from Salamine,
Once courg'd the winds, becaue they rudely blew:
Which in th' Aeolian caves they never knew.
But how was his return? In one mall boat,
Which could but lowly for dead bodies float.

div.p: So Jutine, lib. 2. Erat res pectaculo digna, & aetimatione ortis humanae, rerum varietate, miranda; in exiguo latentem videre navigio quem paulò antè vix aequor <> capiebat. Thus the Hellepont hath the greatet part of its fame, from the misfortunes of two kind Lovers, and one proud Prince; It received its name from Helle, daughter of Athamas, King of Thebes, who fearing the treacheries of her Mother in Law, fled with Phryxus her Brother, and with him was, here drowned. Lucian, Dialogo Neptuni & Nereidum, aith, he fell into the water by reaon of a Vertigo that took her on the uddain: And Heiod, troubled with uch another, aith, he was married to Neptune, of whom he begat Paeon.

37. What Proreus told] This was a Sea-God, famous for his prophecying, and for the power he had to change his hape at his pleaure; Ovid Metamorph, l. 2. v. 9. and lib. 8. v. 737. Virgil, Georg. 4.
388. Hygin. fab. 118. He fore-told Thetis, that her Son hould be killed in the Trojan War: Which prophecy gave the argument to the enuing tory. This Proteus was King of Aegypt, Serv. in Aeneid. 11. and, perhaps, got this fame of transforming himelfe by his uing, till to alter his temper and dipoition, uitably to his affairs and occaions; From the like ground, prung the fame of Herculeae labours, atchieved with unimitable trength and valour. Proteus was alo called Hercules, as Servius affirmeth on that of Virgil, Aen. 11. 262.
div.q: Atreides Protei Menelaus ad uque columnas, Exulat.
div.p: Thoe Columnes having been wholly attributed to Hercules, are there et for the bounds of Aegypt.

40. Ionian] Over the Ionian ea, many auxiliaries came to ait the Greeks againt Troy. This Sea took its name from Ion on of Dyrrhachius, whom Hercules having by michance lain, that he might make him ome amends by perpetuating his memory, threw him into this Sea; Others alledge different reaons, but none worth etting down: Formerly, as Pauanias aith, it was accounted part of the Adriatick. But Ptolomy, in his decription of Macedon, attributeth that part of the Adriatick which waheth Macedonia on the Eat, to the Ionian. But Pliny, lib. 3. c. 6. more rightly divideth thee two Seas, by the Ceraunian, or (as Horace, lib. 1. Carm. Od. 3. v. 20. calleth them) Acroceraunian mountains: From which the Ionian Sea reacheth to the promontory of Malea.

¶ Aegean billows] A Sea between Aia and Greece, full of Ilands called Cyclades and Sporades; of as uncertain Etymology, as the Ionian. Mot ay, it had its name from Aegeus, the father of Theeus: Who going to fight the Minotaur, was charged, if he got the victory, to give notice thereof at his return by a white ail; But he forgetting o to do, his Father, from his Tower eeing the hip coming without the token of uccee, gave his Son for lot, and for grief cat himelfe into the Sea. But ome derive the name from Aege, a Queen of the Amazons; Strabo, from Aegae, a Sea-Town in Eubaea, Servius in Aen. 3. calleth that the Aegean, which is between the Hellepont and the Adriatick; others, that between the Hellepont, and Tenedus. It is now named the Archipelago.

41. All the worn Greeks, which the Atrides got] i. e. Menelaus and Agamemnon, called Atridae, from Atreus, their uppoed father. But they were indeed the ons of Philithenes, and onely bred by Atreus
their Uncle; Thee two Brethren, to revenge the injury done by Paris, having aembled the whole trength of Greece at Aulis, bound them all by an Oath, to ee Troy ruined, or never to return, Serv. in Aen. 4. as will alo appear in the third book of this Poem. Thucydides, lib. 1. glanceth at the reaon of the unanimous conent of the Greeks, to punih the rape of Helen, viz. an Oath by which Tyndarus had obliged all that came Suitors to his daugher, that they hould revenge whatoever wrong hould be done to him that hould enjoy her; But he rather believeth, that Agamemnon being heir to the houes of Pereus and Pelops, and (as Homer tyleth him) King of many Ilands, was the chief caue of the Expedition. The account of the hips in this Fleet, is various in everall Authors; D • ctys Cretenis maketh them, 1138. Dares, 1140. Homer, 1193. our Author here, with a Poeticall careleenee, reckoneth them but 1000. So Seneca, in Agamemnon, and Virgil, Aen. 2.

q.l: Talibus inidiis, perjurique arte Sinonis,
Credita res: captique dolis lacrimique coactis,
Quos neque Tydides, nec Lariaeus Achilles;
Non anni domuêre decem, non mille carinae.
Thus they themelves, made captives by belief
Of Sinon's perjur'd fraud and feigned grief.
Not Diomed, nor Aeacides prevails,
Nor ten years War, nor yet their thouand fails.

p.U:
aith, the number of the Souldiers was not great: But by an indifferent judgement on his own words, the 1200 hips, as he numbreth them, carried 102000 men; a number in my opinion, not to be made o light of. Some, as Dion Chryostomus, have made a quetion, whether there ever was uch a War; although it hath employed the pens of Homer, Dares Phrygius, Dyctis Cretenis, Lycephron with his Scholiat, and Joephus Icanius, and hath been believed by o many Authors in ucceeding ages. That a iege hould continue ten whole years, eemed ridiculous to ome; but Thucydides, lib. 1. initio, giveth a reaon for it: Others have conceived, and our late Travellers have alo oberved, that a potent King could not reign in o inconiderable a place. Neither do the ruines give tetimony of an ample and famous City; And though there never were uch a War, yet is it not to be wondred at, that o many have reported it, and that more have believed it: ince the report of fale-hoods, epecially, when favoured by an antient penne,
gaineth belief, either becaue it cannot be diproved, or becaue the crediting of it aveth pains. Beides, things are eldome examined or diputed, where interet is not concerned.

div.p:
44. On Pelion bred, in Chiron's den] Pelion is a mountain of Thealy, in the Territory of Magneia, joyning to the mountain Osa: Herodot. lib. 7. In mount Pelion, was the Cave of Chiron; who (as the ret of the Centaurs) was like an Hore behind, but forward like a Man: S. Ifidore, lib. 4. holdeth that he was o repreented, quia medicinam jumentorum quidam Chiron Graecus invenit, becaue he found out medicines for beats. And he was named Chiron,
< in non-Latin alphabet > , becaue he was a Chirurgion; Suidas aith, he was the on of Ixion, and the Cloud, as the others Centaurs alo were: whom Virgil, Aen. 6. placeth in Stables in hell. But he is generally aid, to have been the on of Saturn, and Phillyra: So Pindar, Pyth. od. 4. And Virgil, lib. 3. Georg v 550. Phillyrides Chiron. according to the cutom of the Greeks, who were wont to give the Parent's names to the children; Servins, on the place affirmeth the ame: This Chiron, the jutet of all the Centaurs, as Statius repreenteth him, was Mater not onely to Achilles, but to Hercules alo, Jaon, Aeculapius, Cator, and others, (Apollon. Argonaut. lib. 3.) Hermippus tyleth him, < in non-Latin alphabet >
Centaurum apientem, in Clemens Alexandrinus, Strom. lib. 1. He firt taught men to love jutice, hewing the acred Rites of the gods, the figures and natures of the heavenly bodies; His reputation was o great, that ome of the Achaians acrificed to him, as Euebius writeth, lib. 4. Prepar. Evang. citing Monimus,
< in non-Latin alphabet > . A poyoned arrow of Hercules, by chance wounding Chiron's foot, he deired death, but could not obtain it, being the iue of immortall parents; At lat, Jupiter advanced him to be a igne in Heaven, called Sagittariks.

Virgil, de XII Signis. So Seneca, Thyet. act. 4: Lucian, in his Dialogue between Menippus and Chiron, maketh Chiron give another reaon, Why he was out of Love with immortality here; Becaue this life wanteth variety, and is nothing but the repetition, and doing again and again, of the ame things: And he promied himelfe in the other World, to be free from Thirt and Hunger, and whatoever begetteth care. And though Lucian maketh Menippus advie the Centaure, not to feed himelfe with hopes of that nature;
yet we may have a better opinion of his wihes, having more knowledge of the joys of the next life, and enough of this to be of Plutarch's mind, Conolat. ad Apollonium.

q.l: Terra malis catet, adveris pelaguque redundat.
O Mors, veni notris certus medicus malis,
Qui portus humanis es tempestatibus.
The Earth hath no uch plenty as her woes;
The Ocean too with miery o'reflows.
Come, Death, thou cure of all this miery,
The Port where all from torms ecurely lie.

div.p: 62. The Tritons wim.] Thee by the Poets are commonly called Neptune's Trumpeters, and were the iue of him and Salacia, Serv • us in Aeneid. 1. That excellent Trumpeter Mienus oweth his death to the malice of a Triton, Aen. 6. v. 170.

q.l: Se • tum forte cava dum peronat aequora concha
Demens, & cantu vocat in certamina Di • os,
Aemulus exceptum Triton (i credere dignum et)
Inter axa virum pumoa immererat unda.
But on a Rock whilt he by chance the charms
Of Mars rung out, and all the gods alarms
With the loud challenge from his wreathed hell,
(If it be worth belief what others tell)
Whirl'd by an envious Triton from that height,
Among the rocks and waves he found his fate.

div.p:
