So Virgil, Aen 10. v. 209. Ovid, Metam. l. 1. v. 333. and Claudian, de Nuptiis Honorii & Mariae, give Triton the character of Neptuue's Trumpeter, Seneca Troad. act. 2. Triton cecinit hymenaeum; that is, with his hell or trumpet; for none acribe human voice to a Triton. Plinie, lib. 9. c. 5. aith, The Emperor Tib • rius was told, That a Triton was een in a cave winding a hell. Gillius, in Additionib. ad Aelian, and Alexander ab Alex. lib. 3. cap. 8. relate, That there was a Fountain near the Sea-hore, frequently ued by the Inhabitants, whence women and virgins fetched water daily; which a Triton, that lay hid on the hore, epying, on a udden ravihed
one of them, which his hot fancy had mot liking to: And that afterwards, he being caught in a nare and imprioned, died for grief. The ame Author reporteth, that one Trap • zuntius, to whom he affordeth a fair character, told ome friends, That he had een a Maid of an exceeding beauty playing in the Sea, and ever and anon from the middle upward appearing above the water, till at length perceiving he was dicovered, he plunged her elf into the Deep. Claudius the Emperor, by a device, made a Triton appear in the middle of a Lake, riing out of the water, and ounding a Trumpet, Sueton. in Claudio, c. 21. Which pectacle was afteward commonly hewed in the Theaters, as Caaubon on that place relateth.

73. By the bold Jaon.] Statius here glanceth at the tory of Jaon's ravihing Medea with the golden Fleece, comparing that act of his with this of Paris. Jaon was the firt who violated the Sea's reerved rights, as Seneca Medea, act. 3. chor. ult. It was the opinion formerly, that Seas were et as bounds, to confine every man within his own Country, and that no man's ambition hould aim at more than the higher powers had placed him in. This among others Seneca Hippol. act. 2. maketh an argument of the innocency of the Antients.

q.l: Nondum ecabant credulae pontum rates:
Sua quique nôrat maria.
No ventrous hip, truted the waves or wind:
But all men were with their own Seas confin'd.

div.p: 76. By the rah Judge of Ida.] Paris, whoe judgment is accus'd of rahnee, becaue he preferred Pleaure before Widom or Empire; and becaue his fond choice was his Countrie's ruine, Horat. lib. 3. Carm. Od. 3.

q.l: —Ilion, Ilion
Fatal is incestuque judex
Et mulier peregrina verti •
In pulverem.
Troy by a fatall Judge's lut,
And a trange Woman, turn'd to dut.

div.p:
So Seneca, Troad. act. 1. calleth him, The fatall Judge. Wherefore our Poet jutly giveth him here the title of a rah one. For any
thing that is fatall, is hardly to be freed from the imputation of Rahnee.

79. A Foter-child.] Venus: who was bred of the Ocean, as Heiod in Theog. and Pauanias in Corinthiacis, relate. By Seneca, Hippol. act. 1. he is called Diva generata ponto. This was the greatet reaon that Leander encouraged himelf withall, to wim over the Hellepont. Muoeus ver. 248.
— < in non-Latin alphabet > ;
< in non-Latin alphabet > ,
< in non-Latin alphabet > .
—why dot thou fear the waves?
Know't thou not Venus from the Sea firt came,
Mitree both of the Ocean and my flame?
Servius in Aen. 5. writeth, that Venus was therefore aid to be born of the Sea, quia dicunt Phyici udorem alum ee, quem emper elicit coitus Hence the Myrtle was conecrated to Venus, becaue that Tree propereth bet on the Sea-hore. Like this is that of Coelius Rhodiginus, lib. 14. c 4. Lacivos Graeci
< in non-Latin alphabet >
vocant i. e. humidos, &c. becaue venereall appetites proceed from moiture. Hence Poets took occaion to feign, that enus prung from the Ocean. Capar Bartholinus Adverar. l. 21. c. 22. giveth this Mythologie, Eam Fabulam aliquando arbitratus um exinde venire, quòd Venus prima questûs faciendi cauâ corpus protituit, velut inatiabile pelagus omnes ad e trahens. I was ometimes of opinion, aith he, that the Fable aroe from hence, Becaue Venus was the firt who protituted her body for hire, like an inatiable Sea attracting all to her. More of Venus is to be een in Gyraldus, Hitor. Deor. Syntagm. 13. Turnebus 9. Adverar. c. 2. Natalis Comes, Mytholog lib. 4. c. 13. Fulgentius, Mythol. l. 2. But above all, I prefer the Interpretation of the Fable which Macrobius giveth, Saturnal. lib. 1. c. 8. That by the ecret parts of Coelus, which were cut off by his on Saturn, and thrown into the Sea, and of the froth whereof Venus was engendred, were meant the eeds of things falling from Heaven, as oon as there was uch a thing as Time; which Saturn is always held-to ignifie. And by Coelus nothing can be undertood but COELUM, Heaven; Servius in Aen. 5. denying, that the proper name of any god can be of the Neuter Gender. Cicero lib. 3. De nat. Deor. telleth us of four Venus's; one the daughter of Coelus and Light; another of the Froth of the Sea, of whom, and Mercurie, Cupid was begotten; a third of Jupiter
and Dione the wife of Vulcan; the fourth of Syrus and Syria. This lat was married to Adonis, and her the Syrians named < in non-Latin alphabet > , the Hebrews Ahteroth, 1 King. 11. 5. Judg. 2. 13. And as Tully reckoneth many Venus's, o, as Mr. Selden aith, De Diis Syris yntagm. 2. c 2. St. Augustine interpreteth < in non-Latin alphabet > , as if there were many Astartes. This goddee had many acrifices offered to her, Alexand. ab Alexandro, l. 3. c. 12. and from thence had her name, Ahtaroth ignifying greges: Supiceris (aith Scaliger in Conjectaneis) dictam eam à Victimarum multitudine. She was entituled alo, The goddese of Love, or rather of Laciviounee. Clemens Alexandrinus telleth us, that once all her pictures were made after the likenee of Phryne, a famous Whore, and that the man who, like another Pygmelton, could embrace the tatue of the goddee, conceited himelf religious, Admon. ad Gentes: where he alo etteth down her lacivious Ceremonies. Mr. Gregorie writing of the Ayrian Monarchie, relateth, that there was a cutom, that every woman hould once in her life repair to the Temple of Venus, and there protitute her body to any one that would throw her down a piece of mony, which was to be given to the Temple, and to the honor of the goddee. The manner was for the women to it down in the Temple, ditinguihed by little lines or cords, which he that had a mind might take away, or break, if the woman eemed coy, and o take the trumpet out of the Temple into a by corner. This is expreed in the Epitle acribed to Jeremie, at the end of Ba • uch, v. 43. The woman alo with cords about them fitting in the ways, burn bran for perfume; but if any of them, drawn by ome that paseth by, lie with him, he reproacheth her fellow, that he was not thought as worthy as her elf, nor her cord broken. Such attendants this goddee had as we read, 2 King. 23. 7. And he broke down the houes of the S • domites that were by the houe of the Lord, where the women wove hangings for the Grove. This place Mr. Selden interpreteth thus, Diruit quoque domos cortatorum—ubi mulieres texebant cortinas pro Aerah, eu luco. Of which, ee his De Diis Syris, Synt. 2. c. 2. & 4. pag. 237. & 283. Thus far I have digreed, to hew the antiquity of this lacivious goddee; which was not the production onely of fictious brains. Nor is it to be wondred at, that a thing o loathome and ridiculous hould meet with adoration; for the whole Religion of the Gentiles is o contrived, as to agree with licentious appetites. Which eaie way to propagate a novelty, Mahomet well undertood; nor is it now wholly unpractied.

88. By his affected tomb to grieve] Thetis here expreeth a paion, o great for her Son, that if his fate, as ore-told, hould be to perih
in the Trojan War, he would leave the Ocean, and ever mourn in thoe waves, that hould wah the place of his Sepulchre: And that was the Sigean promontory. There Alexander the Great performed ceremonies in his memory, declaring him happy, who in his life enjoyed uch a friend as Patroclus, and after death, doth till live by Homer: Plu • arch, in Alexandro. Cicero Epist. ad famil. l. 5. cp. 12.

107. Caphareus.] Neptune being forced by the croe decrees of the Fates to deny Thetis petitioning for a torm againt the Greeks, to appeae her omewhat, telleth her, that the Trojans hould be ruined by the valour of her on, and herelfe be revenged on the Greeks at Caphareus, who hould there uffer hip-wrack. Whereof the Tragedian thus.

q.l: —Hanc arcem occupat
Palamedis ille genitor, & clarum manu
Lumen nefanda vertice è ummo efferens,
In axa ducit perfidâ claem face.
Haerent acutis rupibus fixae rates.
Upon whoe ummit Nauplius tood, and rais'd
In his revenging hand a Light that blaz'd.
Whoe treacherous flame the navy guides betwixt
The wracking Rocks, whoe points the veels fix't.

div.p: Nauplius's grudge againt the Greeks, aroe from this occaion; lyes having charged Palamedes, for holding correpondence with Priam, and writing letters to him, dicovered, as a proof of his Treachery, an heap of Gold in his Tent, which he before hand had cloely conveyed thither. Whereupon, innocent Palamedes was toned to death, Serv. in Aen. 2. Dictys Cretenis, and Dares Phrygius, give other accounts of him: Dares, that he was killed by Paris, lib. oe excidio Trojano; Dictys, that Diomedes and lyes, over-whelmed him with tones in a well, whither he, upecting no foul play, went down to fetch up Treaure, which they told him was hid there, and he hould have his hare of it, lib. 2. Caphareus is an high Hill in Eubaea, over-looking the Hellepont: On the top of this, Nauplius caued fi • es to be made by night, to allure the weather-beaten Greeks to fall upon the Rocks, that o he might revenge his on's death upon them.

108. Joynt-revenge] Neptune promieth Thetis to joyn with her
againt lyes. His quarrell with him, was upon the account of his on Polypheme, whoe eye lyes had bored out: Which tory is thus related by Achaemenides, to Aeneas, Aen. 3.

q.l: —Domus anie dapibúque cruentis,
Intus opaca, ingens. Ipe arduus, altáque pulat
Sidera (Dii talem terris avertite petem!)
Nec viu facilis, nec dictu affabilis ulli;
Viceribus mierorum & anguine vecitur atro,
Vidi egomet, duo de numero cùm corpora notro,
Pr'ena manu magna, medio reupinus in antro
Frangeret ad axum, anieque adpera natarent
Limina: vidi, atro cùm membra fluentia tabo
Mandere • , & trepidi tremerent ub dentibus artus.
Haud impunè quidem: nec talia paus lyes,
Oblit • sve uî et Ithacus dicrimine tanto.
Nam imul expletus dapibus, vinóque epultus,
Cervicem inflexam pouit, jacuitque per ant • um
Immenum, aniem eructans & fruta cruento
Per omnum commixta mero; nos magna precati
Numina, ortitique vices, unà undique circum
Fundimur, & telo lumen tenebramus acuto
Ingens, quod torva olum ub fronte latebat.
—Slaughters and bloody feat,
With hades the vatnee fill'd. He high and tall
The tarres aaults. (The gods uch plagues from all
Avert!) His voice and viage tern: his food,
Bowels of laughtred wretches and black blood.
As in his den he lay along, I aw
Two of our men, grap'd by his cured paw,
And dah'd againt the rock: the blood all ore,
With purple drops drenched the prinkled floor.
Limbs flowing with black gore I aw him eat,
And in his teeth the trembling inews beat.
Nor unreveng'd their fates lyes bears,
But mindfull of himelf in all appears.
For now ore-charg'd with wine and bloody feats,
His head bent down, as in his Cave he rets,
Wine mix'd with clotty gore returning flows,
Which belch'd up from his grave-like breat he throws.
Burl'd in leep: We all the gods implore,
Spreading o • r elves round on the bloody floor,
And with a harp pear fix'd eternall night.
Upon his brow, rob'd of its onely light.

div.p:
Servius, on this place, aith, That Polyphemus was ome wie man, and therefore feigned to have his eye in his forehead, that is, near the brain, which
• yses, being wier than he, put out. But by the Cyclopes generally are undertood the Vapors of the Sea or Earth: and hence, perhaps, Polyphemus, the chief of them, was aid to be the on of Neptune, by whom was meant, according to Ch • yippus, the pirit that moved the waters. Cic. lib. 1. de Nat. Deor. And lyses was therefore eigned to overcome Polypheme, becaue he found out thee naturall caues.

111. Thesalie.] A R • gion of Greece, girt about with Mountains, Olympus, Osa, a • d Pelion, on the North; Othrys and Oeta Southward; and Pindus on the Wet. Its bounds are exactly et down by Herodotus, lib. 7. It was antiently called Pyrrhaea, from Pyrrha the wife of Deucalion, Strabo lib. 10. Afterward Aemonia, from Aemon; from whoe on Thealus, at lat it was called Thealie.
115. Sperchios.] A River in Thealie, iuing from Mount Pelion, and falling into the Malian Bay, ten furlongs from Thermopylae, Strab. lib. 9.

129. Diturb the geniall crue] Our Poet glanceth at the fray between the Centaurs and the Lapithae, which hapned at the marriage of Pirithous, o excellently decribed by Ovid, and after him by the enjoyer of his Genius, Mr. San • ys. Genius (from which Genial is derived) et nacendt atque nature deus, à gignendo d • ctus. Hence the four Elements, whereof all Inferior bodies are generated, were called Dii geniales; and the Nuptiall-bed, Lectus genialis. See Turnebus Adverar l. 16. c. 19. & l. 26. c. 14. Ge • ii were accounted the moderators and dipoers of the Planets, and their Influences, at mens Nativities. Horace lib. 2 epit. 2.
div.q: Scit Genius, natale comes qui temperat afirum.
div.p:
Thoe Doemons alo whom, the Heathen attribute o much the dependancie of our reolutions unto, were called Genii, as begetting the thoughts of men, and working on them. And perhaps the frequency of thee Spirits and opinions, before our Saviour's time, was the occaion of that more aburd conceit, et down by coffi • g
• ucian in his Menippus, That the hadows which our bodies cat in
the Sun-hine will be witnee againt us in the other world. With reference to thee Genii mut that of the Poet. Aen. 6. v. 643. be interpreted, Quique uos patimur manes. i. e. Every one in the next life mut receive either punihment for the crimes he committed, by hearkning to his woe • r Genius, or rewards for the good he wrought, by the aitance of his better. For two Genii, they ay, one good, (the other bad,) attend every man from his birth. This the Heathen were taught by their gods; the Devil herein, as in many other things, playing the Ape, and imitating the true God; who indeed giveth his Angels charge over us, (ee Clemens Alexandrinus, lib. 5. S • r • m) that we be not overcome by the power of evill Spirits. For we wretle not, aith the Apotle, Ephe. 6. 12. againt fleh and blood, but againt principalities, against powers, againt the rulers of the darknee of this world, againt pirituall wickednee:
< in non-Latin alphabet > , here tranlated, in high places; which is not at all aiting, if not prejudiciall to the meaning of the vere. Beza rendreth it, Quae unt in ublimi, omething nearer, But I ee not why the words hould not be rendred, in the lower Heavens, that is, the Aire, the habitation of thee Daemons, as Mr. Mede, on 2 Pet. 2. 4. and Jude 6. doth prove. And it is oberved, that for the Heaven of Heavens, or upernaturall Heaven, the word < in non-Latin alphabet >
is always ued. In relation to this ene, Origen ueth the Vere in his writings againt Gelus. Moreover, judicious Calvin on the place, intimateth as much, where the Interpretation he ueth, is, Incoeletibus. Diodate alo undertandeth, The region of the aire, in which evill pirits, driven cut of heaven, do wander. And by Principalities he undertandeth evill Angels; excellently adding, that in the quality of their nature, and in the power which God uffereth them to have over the world, they have alo omething common with the holy Angels, in the eminency of Titles. Yet he there retracteth this Interpretation, in my opinion for a wore.

153. with Magick art.] Thetis, deirous to conceal from Chiron the purpoe he had, to dig • ie his Schollar in woman's apparell, whom he by rigid principles had fitted for the hardet employments, beareth him in hand, that ominous dreams moved her to attempt the prevention of his fate by Magict Art. Such a deceit paionate Dido beguiled her iter withall, pretending to eek onely a remedy for her love, when indeed her plot was to couen her elf of life.

q.l: Ergo ubi concepit furi • s, evicta dolore,
Decrevitque mori, tempus ecum ipa modumque
Exigit, & maetam dictis aggrea ororem,
Conilium vultu tegit, ac pem fronte erenat.
Inveni, germana, viam (gratare orori)
Quae mihi reddat eum, vel eo me olvat, amantem.
Oceani finem iuxta olemque cadentem,

ltimus Aethiop ••
locus et, ubi maximus Atlas
Axem humero torquet stellis ardentibus aptum.
Hin • mihi Maylae gentis montrata acerdos,
He • eridum templi cutos, epulaque Draconi
Quae dabat, & acros ervabat in arbore ramos,
Spargens humida mella oporiferumque papaver.
Haec e carminibus promittit olvere mentes
Quos velit, ast aliis dur •• immittere curas:
S ••• ere • quam fluviis, & vertere idera retro:
Nocturnoque ciet-manes-Mugire videbis
Sub pedibus terram, & decendere montibus orn • s.
Vanquih'd with grief, and now reolv'd to die,
The means and time to act the Tragedy
She plots: And, with f • ign'd joy to hide her crime,
Thus to her iter aith Joy that the time
Is come, that I hall now procure my ret,
And gain his love, or freedom to my breat.
Near to the Ocean's bounds, where Phoebus flies
To end his coure, burnt Aethiopia lies:
Where on his loaden houlders Atlas bears
Heaven, which fill'd with glittering Starrs appears.
Hence a Maylian came, the Temple' • Priet
Of the Heperides, who there did feat
The watchfull Dragon, and preerved too
The Tree on which the acred branches grew,
With Hony and mix'd Poppy, which conveys.
A drouie dulnee: By her charms, he ays,
She can diolve a paion, and procure
A cornfull breat another to endure,
Stop in its peed the wiftet tream, and all
The Stars turn backward from their coure, and call
Ghots from the howling earth, and from the high
Tops of the Hills make tubborn Trees to flie.

div.p:
That Witches had uch a faculty as Dido here peaketh of, to quench or kindle love at their pleaure, former times believed.
Carmine Thealidum dura in praecordia fluxit
Non fatis adductus amor; flammique everi
Illicitis arêre enes.
Thealian charms, without aiting fate,
Can paion give to hearts til us'd to hate.
Severe old men are fetter'd with Love's chains,
And their chill breats burn with unlawfull flames.
Lucan lib. 6. ver. 452. And a little after,
—Quos non concordia miti
Alligat ulla tori, blandaeque potentia formae,
Traxerunt torti Magicâ vertigine fili.
—Thoe who ne're car'd to try
Love's joys, whom Hymen's knots could never tye;
Whom charming beauty never yet compell'd,
A lender thread, by Magick ty'd, hath held.
Their power alo in other things the ame noble Poet thus decribeth.

q.l: Ceavêre vices rerum: dilataque longâ
Haeit nocte dies: legi non paruit aether:
Torpuit & praeceps audito carmine mundus.
Axibus & rapidis impulos Jupiter urgens
Miratur non ire polos. Nunc omnia complent
Imbribus, & calido producunt nubila Phoebo:
Et tonat ignaro coelum Jove. Vocibus iidem
Humentes latè nebulas, nimboque olutis
Excuêre comis, ventis cesantibus aequor
Intumuit: rurum vetitum entire procellas
Conticuit, turbante Noto: puppimque ferentes
In ventum tumuêre in • s. De rupe pependit
Abciâ fixus torrens: amnique cucurrit
Non quà pronus erat. Nilum non extulit aetus.
The coure of things was topp'd: nor Heaven obey'd
Its Laws: the Day in Night's black Arms delay'd.
The tott'ring world thee potent charms benum,
And while the rapid Poles forget to run,

l.hi: Jove
l.U: tands amaz'd. A torm obeys, and hrowds,

q.l: Phoebus adorn'd with all his rays, in clowds.
Jove ignorant the Thunder hears. The ame
Dire voice, with looe dihevell'd hair again
Shattereth the dropping clowds: Seas well with waves,
The winds all huh'd; again, though Notus raves,
The Seas becalmed lie. Ships make their way
Againt the wind, and ruhing torrents tay
Thrown from a precipice. Streams backward run:
Nor Nile o're flows the plains corcht by the Sun.

div.p: Thee places I have produced, to hew what an opinion the antient Heathen had of Witches. I will onely add, that I find that the Tyrians had a cutom, to tie the Images of their gods with bands, let they hould be called from them by the charms of their enemies, Alexand. ab Alex l 4. c 12. And o ubject were thoe gods to the power of charms, that they were thereby compelled to come, nor could return back without licene obtained; Eueb de praepar. Evang. l. 5. c. 8, & 9. From this opinion aroe that quetion in Lucan, lib. 6. v. 492.

q.l: Quis labor hic uperis cantus herbaque equendi,
Spernedique timor? cujus commercia pacti
Ob rictos tenuêre Deos? parere necee et,
An juvat? ignota tantum pietate mere n'ur?.
What is it makes the fearfull gods forbear
To corn both herbs and charms? whence comes this fear?
Doth trong neceity, or their own deigne,
Or piety unknown, them thus incline?

div.p: I hall ay more of this ubject haply hereafter, when a more proper place hall afford opportunity. But thus much at preent, to hew, that Chiron had reaon to believe Thetis, when he told him, that he would make ue of Magick for her on's preervation.

166. The envious gods.] Our Poet is here thought to have no further aime, than to et forth the praies of his Achilles, as if he deerved the envy of the gods. But I have oberved Statius to be a great imitator of Virgil, who was till wont to omit no occaion of interweavning his Learning with his Poetry: wherein Macrobius
trongly jutifieth him. Since thee words therefore will afford it, hold it not amie to interpret them to the more learned ene.

There was a generall Tradition among the Heathen, That th • gods envied any perfection or happinee in Mankind. This proceeded from the Devill's policy, who from the beginning of th • world endeavoured to repreent God env • ous unto Man, in that h • denied him the knowledge of good and evill; as Junius and Dioda •
oberve on Gen. 3. Learned Merick Caaubon, in his Caue of tempora Evills, aith, that Aritotle ets down this opinion, That God i
< in non-Latin alphabet > , envious; but proteteth agai • t it, < in non-Latin alphabet > , It is not poible it hould be o; yet aith, That if it were o indeed, that the nature of God could be envious, that Envy mut needs conit in hidenying of men the happinee of certain knowledge and contemplation. That impious Philoopher Porphyrie, directly chargetl God with envy, for forbidding the Tree of Knowledge: Who is anwered by Greg. Nazianzen, Orat. 38. Such impious men perhaps take offence at Gen. 3. 22, 23. I forbear to produce further Tetimonies, to prove, there was uch an opinion among the Heathen, I do not think them needfull; ince it is certain, the Devill would let lip no occaion of raiing prejudice againt God, and charging him with his own c • ime. Through envy of the Devill came death into the world, Wid. 2. 24. It was the Devil's envy that made Man loe Paradie, and not God, who placed him in it. Another reaon why the gods were conceived to envy men, was, Becaue all their properity and happinee, is at length requited with croes and calamity. Examples of uch change are frequent in all times: Among all, carce is there any more notable then that of the once-Great Pompey, flying alone after his overthrow in Pharalia, Lucan. lib. 1. v. 28.

q.l: —Sed longi poenas Fortuna favor is
Exigit à miero, quae tanto pondere famae
Res premit adveras, fatique prioribus urget.
Nunc fetinatos nimiùm fibi entit honores,
Actaque lauriferae damnat Syllana juventae.
Nunc & Corycias claes & Pontica igna,
Dejectum, meminise piget. Sic longius aevum
Destruit ingentes an • mos, & vita upertes
Imperio. Nii umma dies cum fine bonorum
Affuit, & celeri praevertit tritia leto,
Dedecori et fortuna prior. Quiquámne ecundis
Tradere e fatis audet, nii morte paratâ
But Fortune with her favour till beguiles,
And with ad woes purues her former miles.
His fame mot preeth his declining tate,
And former glories add unto the weight.
Too haty now his early fame he found,
And blames thoe wreaths with which his Youth was crown'd.
Of Pontick or Corycian Victories
Now when he thinks, his flaming bluhes rie.
Thus greatet minds conuming Age detroys,
And Life urvives our Empires and our Joys.
Unlee life with thoe joys together flow,
And a wift fate prevent enuing woe,
To Fortune Shame ucceeds. In the bet tate
Let none confide, unlee prepar'd for Fate.

div.p:
Another intance of the mutability of Fortune, was that great Souldier, Hannibal; whoe prophetick pirit was enible of this, almot fatall, neceity: as we may ee in that incomparable peech, which Livy maketh him peak to Scipio; adviing not to trut the gods and Fortune too farre: telling him, that what Scipio was then, himelf had been after the battels at Tra • emen • and Cannae; and that Fortune had never yet deceived him. Thus he pake to move his enemy to accept peace, conceiving no argument of more force, then the conideration of the viciitude of human affairs. And his words, though then lighted, Scipio himelfe afterwards found true, and had ad experience, both of the incontancy of Fortune, and of the ingratitude of his Country. To thee, I might adde the examples of Marius, Caear, and infinite others, out of the tories of former times, with more prodigious ones of our own age; Habet has vices conditio mortalium, aith Pliny in his excellent Ranegyrick, ut advera ex ecundis, ex adveris ecunda nacantur. Occultat utrorumque emina Deus; & pletunque •• norum malor •• que cauae ub divera pecie latent: The condition of mortalls, hath thee changes, that adverity hould pring out of properity, and properity out of adverity. The eeds of both, God concealeth; and for the mot part, the caues of good and evill, things lie hid under a different pecies. Herodotus relateth, how Amais King of Aegypt, counelled his friend Polycrates, King of Samos, That he hould interrupt the coure of his felicity, by casting quite away omething that he held most dear, and the lose whereof would most afflict him. Plutarch, De conol. ad Apollonium, telleth us, that Theramenes, one of the thirty
Tyrants at Athens, being at Supper wi • h many friends, the houe where they were, uddenly fell down, and he onely ecaped. Many upon this, gave him the name of Happy: But he crying our, asked, For what adder death Fortune had reerved him? And indeed, the Torments he endured before his end, added him to the number of thoe examples, which erve to admonih properous perons, of the uncertainty of their Etate, Seneca, Troad. act. 2.

q.l: Violenta nemo imperia continuit diu:
Moderata durant. Quóque fortuna altius
Evexit ac levavit humanas opes,
Hoc e magis upprimere felicem decet,
Varióque caus tremere, metuentem Deos
Nimiùm faventes.
None violent Empires long enjoy ecure:
They 're moderate conditions that endur • .
When Fortune raieth to the greatet height,
The happy man hould mot uppree his tate,
Expecting till a change of things to find,
And fearing when the gods appear too kind.

div.p:
It is an excellent Character, that Macrobius giveth of Fortitude, Tolerare fortiter vel advera vel propera, To bear with courage, either advere or properous Fortune, in Somn. Scipionis, l. 1. c. 8. And perhaps, it may aime at our ene, In the bet condition, without ditemper, to expect the wort. This dreading invidiam Numinis, was the caue, why that mighty Emperour Augustus, ued once a year, Cavam manum aes porrigentibus praebere, as Su • tonius in his Life relateth, c. 91. To beg with his open, or hollow, hand; the mot opprobrious way of begging. On which place, ee learned Caaubon, giving reaons from the generally received opinion, thus elegantly expreed by Eramus, in his Philodoxus, Saepe mecum admirari ole • eu Fortunae eu Naturae invidentiam, quae nihil omnino commodi largitur mortalibus quod non aliquo temperet incommodo, i. e. I have often wondred with my elf at the envy, either of Fortune or Nature, who never dipene things convenient to mankind, which are not tempered with ome inconvenience. For this Philip of Macedon, kept a Youth, whoe office was, every Morning thrice to alute him thus, < in non-Latin alphabet > , Philip, thou art a man, Aelian. var, hit. l. 8. c. 15. I will end all with a paage of Diodorus Siculus, Biblioth. hist. lib. 3. Thus rendered by Merick Caaubon, in his Caue of evils,
Neverthelee, God ( < in non-Latin alphabet > ) hath not afforded unto men any entire happinee, without ome blemih or envy; but to thee his bleings he hath annexed omewhat that is hurtfull, which might erve to admonih them, who through continuance of worldly bleings, are wont to grow into a contempt of the Gods. Whether our Poet had an eye to this opinion, I cannot ay; Certainly, his words eem to look that way, and o my dicoure is excued from impertinency.
195. Pholoe] A woody mountain of Arcadia, having a Town of its own name, Plin. l. 4. c. 6.

207. So tired Cator.] Statius here compareth Achilles to Castor, whoe beauty he maketh as bright as his own tarre. He and Pollux were the ons of Tyndarus and Leda: And their amity was o great, that they never differed either in matter of Power or Counell. For which Hyginus aith, Jove tranlated them into Stars; Servius in Aeneid. 6. aith, that Helen and Pollux were begotten by Jupiter, in the hape of a Swan, and from him, drew immortality; but that Cator was the on of Tyndarus, and o mortall: but by the extream kindnee of his brother, and the conceion of Jupiter, mortality and immortality, was equally divided betwixt them, Virgil, Aen. 6.
div.q: Sic fratrem Pollux alterna morte redemit.
div.p: The fable aroe from the Stars, one whereof ever rieth at the etting of the other, as if the fate and fall of one redeemed his fellow; That thee brethren were ever watchfull for the Roman Common-wealth, Valerius Maximus proveth by many examples, lib 1. c. 8. Alo Plutarch in the Life of Paulus Aemylius relateth their meeting of L. Domitius, and how they gave him in charge to make known to the Senate and people of Rome, that they were victorious; which as yet they were uncertain of: And then, (as Suetonius, in the beginning of Nero's life writeth, though Plutarch mentioneth it not) to evidence their Divinity, they changed his hair from Black to Red. And thence came the name of Aenobarbus, which continued to one of the greatet families in Rome.

216.—Sings the acts of Heroes] Maturantius aith, it was a cutom among the Greeks, to ing the actions of famous perons; to the • nd, that others might be inflamed to a generous imitation of them. So Scipio was excited to great atchievements, by gazing on Statues, • rected to the memory of renowed men. Muick was ever much • onoured: Epaminondas, among other things was famous for it.
• acobus Crucins, in lib. Annot. relateth out of Polybius, that the Ardi • ns generally intructed their youths in Muick, and aith, It
was a cutom among the Grecians, to ing the praies of their Genii, Heroes, and Gods. So Alexander ab Alexand o, l. 4. c. 17. aith, They were wont to ing the praies of their gods, while the acrifice was in eating. And lib. 2. c. 25. having reckoned up many famous men that were excellent Muicians, he addeth that among the Greeks, Muici, Vates, and Sapientes were in equall etimation; And that, after Supper, the Harp was wont to be played on; Which when Themistocles refued to take in hand, he was for that very caue, held the lee learned. He there alo affirmeth, that the Ancienrs ued to chant out the Encomiums of renowned perons. Thus our Poet etteth forth Achilles, to have been intructed by Chiron, and now to give his Mother the uuall entertainment after their Feat; And Homer telleth us, that he oft practiced this art at the iege of Troy. Thus alo, Dido entertaineth her guets, Aeneas, Virg. Aen. 1.

q.l: —Cithara crinitus Iopas
Peronat aurata, docuit quae maximus Atlas.
Hic canit errantem Lunam, olique labores;
nde hominum genus & pecudes, unde imber, & ignes:
Arcturum, pluviáque Hyadas, geminóque Triones;
Quid tantum Oceano properent e tingere • oles
Hiberni, vel quae tardis mora noctibus obtet.
—Hai • y Iopas then begun,
And on his Harp what Atlas taught he ung;
The Moon's uncontant ways, and how the Sun
Performs his coure; whence men and beats firt prung;
The Bears, the Hyades, and Arcturus ings,
Why to the waves the Sun hould take his flight
Sooner in Winter, and prolong the night.

div.p:
219. The victories of Pollux.] The weapon by which Pollux was victorious, was much ued by the Antients, called Caeius; whoe decription J. C. Scaliger thus giveth: At firt, (aith he) the Greeks ued to fight with naked its. Pugnis addita lora ad munimentum, propterea quòd nudi cùm ferirent ape plus damni acciperent quàm facerent. Ea lora Graeco vocabulo CESTUS dicta ( < in non-Latin alphabet >
enim cinguluir.) Br •
via initio: mox, nè excua exuerentur in ictibus, tum cubito tum humero alligabantur. Potremò ferrum plumbumque autum est, aeviimo pectaculo. Cerebrum enim & gattur facillimè elidebant. Idcirco aurium munimenta
induebant,
< in non-Latin alphabet > . Thus he decribeth the Catus to be a piece of a Leather, for the afeguard of the hand, which, when naked, received oftentimes more damage by a blow, than it gave. Let this Caetus hould be haken off by triking, it was fatned, not to the arm onely, but alo to the houlder. At the end of it was ewed a mas of Iron or Lead, which rendred the combat a mot cruell pectacle. Their very brains were oft dahed out; for prevention whereof, they covered both their ears with defences. This character Fabricius alo confirmeth, relating, that the form of this Caestus was to be een in the houe of Peter • embus, when he lived at Padus. Fuerunt coria bubula, aith he, quibus plumbum ferrumque inutum et, articulis manûs in volam • lexae circundata; &, ut pondus ustinere ferientium manus valerent, brachi is alligata. And hence he believeth, the antient Germans took the ue of the Gantlet, which they wore in war. The reaon Fabricius giveth, why the Caetus were fatned to the arm, is, in my opinion, better then Scaliger's, That o the hand might be trengthned to bear the weight the better. This Fabricius writeth, on the Combat between Ente • lus and Dares, Aen. 5. This Exercie, as Scaliger aith, was at firt onely ued with bare fits, and prizes propounded for it in the Olympick Games, Thucyd lib. 1. The invention of Caetus is acribed to Amycus, Clem. Alex. lib. 1. Strom
< in non-Latin alphabet > Amycus the Bebrycian King firt found out
< in non-Latin alphabet > , lora pugilum, that is, the Caestus. Which very words, with others of
• lemens, Euebius ueth, De praep. Evang. l. 10. c. 5. Hence Statius here,
—crudo quo Bebryca caestu
Obruerit Pollux.
i. e. Amycus, o called from the place where he reigned, Bebrycia, which had its name from Bebryae, a King in the Pyrenaean Mountains, Sil. Ital. l. 3. Since, it was called Mygdonia; after that, Bithynia, from Bithynius, a King there, Strabo l. 7. &. 12. Arianus giveth one of the daughters of Danaus this name, who, as well as her iter Hyperinnestra, pared her husband, contrary to her father's command, and flying with him into this Country, gave name to it; till freher merits detroyed the memory of hers. There is a Village called Bebryacum, by Suetonius, in Othone, and by Tacitus, Anual. 18. eated between Verona and Cremona. In the Lipwick Edition it is called Bedriacum, by Joephus
< in non-Latin alphabet > , by Plutarch
< in non-Latin alphabet > . But by reaon of the authority of Tacitus and Oroius, Joeph Scaliger
aith, Eanihil aliud unt quám unum nomen multifariàm deprava • um. At this place Otho was ove • come by itollius; & tatim, aith Suetonius, moriendi impetum cepit. Yet then had he a reerved Army, competent enough to have attempted, in another Battle, the recovery of his Fortune; but he choe rather to let that be the certain advantage of his friends, to procure peace from itellius, than by hazarding them to pull on all their ruines together. For which caue, Tacitus jutly aith, Many enjoyed Empires longer, but none left them bravelier.

220. The monstrous Minotaur fam'd-Theeus lew.] The Fable is thus; The Adultery of Mars and enus being dicern'd by the Sun's all eeing eye, and by him dicovered to ulcan, in a Net that he had made for the purpoe, he caught the Lovers in their embraces. Hereat enus being enraged, ever after purued the race of Phoebus with revenge, infecting them with prodigious paions. The firt that uffered was Paiphae the wife of Minos; he, being in love with a Bull, was by Daedalus h • s art incloed in a Cow of wood, and o received the horrid atisfaction of her beatly Lover. And from that loathome embrace came the Minotaur. By this Queen, Minos had three children, Androgeos, Ariadne, and Phaedra. Androgeos, after many noble Victories, was at lat lain by the Athenians and Megarians. In revenge of his death, Minos having vanquihed the Athenians at Sea, impoed on them this punihment, that even Youths, and as many Virgins, hould every year be delivered to be devoured by the Minotaur. But Euebius, de praepar. Evang. l. 5. c. 19. layeth their death to Apollo's charge, whoe Oracle directed the Athenians, to end the Youths to be killed by Minos, that the plague might be averted from them, which they uffered for the death of Androgeos. In the third year of this impoition, Th • eus on of Aegeus was ent. He, no les powerfull in peron then in forces, firt obtained a conquet of the heart of Ariadne; and then, by her procurement, having got a thread from Daedalus to guide him, he found the way to the Minotaur in the Labyrinth, and lew him; and having o done, he fled away with Ariadne. Then Minos finding, or upecting, that Daedalus, who made the Labyrinth, had aited Theeus, encloed both him and his on Icarus therein. But Daedalus procuring wax and feathers, with other materialls, from his Keepers, under pretence of preenting omething rare to the King, made Wings, with which himelf and his on lew away. But the rah Youth, contrary to his Father's intructions, oaring too high, melted his wings againt the Sun, and fell into that Sea, which beareth his name, Ovid. de arte lib. 2. & Metam.
lib. 8. The place his father alighted firt upon, was Cumae; Where, <> the gates of Apollo's Temple, he engraved this torie, omitting • ot • ing but the rate of Icarus, irg. Aen. 6.

q.l: —Tu quoque magnam
Partem opere in tanto, ineret dolor, Icare, haberes.

l.hi: Bis conatus erat caus eDffingere in auro;

q.l: Bis patriae cecidere manus.
Thou alo, Icarus, hadt had a part
In this, had grief giv'n freedom to his art.
Twice he attempted thy hard fate to paint;
Twice thy concerned father's hand did faint.

div.p: Some hold, this Fable was invented to hadow a true torie, and hat Paiphae being in love with Taurus, Captain of the Guard to Minos, lay with him in Daedalus's houe; and he bringing forth • wins, the mockery made up the Minotaur. The Fable was more l • wdly preented by Nero: In relating whereof, Suetonius, as Beroaldus noteth, ueth words, that eem to credit Beats having copulation with Women; againt which we read a Law, Levit. 20. 16. which heweth the probability of it. Beides, if it be poible, we need no farther proof than the unatiable nature of ome women. Nor would any doubt, that Mealina the lacivious Empree would have crupled at uch an act, if her fancy had but directed her to it. Juvenal. Sat. 6.

q.l: —Claudius audi
Quae tulerit. Dormire virum cùm enerat uxor,
Aua Palatino tegetem praeferre cubi i,
Sumere nocturnos meretrix Auguta cucullos;
Linquebat comite ancilla non ampliùs una:
Sed nigrum flavo crinem abcondente galero,
Intravit calidum veteri centone lupanar,
Et c • llam vacuam, atque uam. tunc nuda papillis
Protitit a • ratis, titulum mentita Lycicae,
Otenditque tuum, generoe Britannice, ventrem.
Excepit blanda intrantes, atque aera popocit
Mox l • none uas jam dimittente puell • s,
Tritis abit: ed, quod potuit, tamen ultima cellam
Clauit, adhuc ardens rigidae tentigine vulvae,
Et laata viris, necdum atiata rec it.
—For hear what Claudius doth endure:
Whom whilt his wife believes in leep ecure,
She did prefer before a Princely Bed
The Bawdy-houe's moaky-coverlid.
Th' Emperiall Whore diguis'd from being known,
With Night and Scarfs goes with one Maid alone;
A yellow Periwig her warthy hairs
Conceals, and he to th' Bawdy-houe repairs;
Which from the new-employed bed a fume
Retains. Poeing the then emptied room
She rich adorn'd with naked breats appears.
Lycica's name the lying entrance bears.
There, great Britannicus, thy belly's hown.
With a lacivious kindnee every one
She meets, and asks her hire. When all the Whores.
The Bawd ends home, hers lat of all the doors
Was hut. She burning with unquenched fires,
And toil'd with men, not atisfi'd, retires.

argument.head: The Argument.
argument.l: Thetis at lat, though long delay'd by fears,
Through the calm waves her dear Achilles bears.
Love hews an object to enflame his eyes:
The King receives him hid in a diguie.

lg.l: BUt Thetis, in the night leaving the caves,
Stood where the Rocks ent Ecchoes from the waves.
And in her unreolved phancy weigh'd,
To what afe place her Son might be convey'd.
She fears, where Mars was born, th' adjacent Thrace;
And dreads the warlike Macedonian race.
Fam'd-Athens too her doubting phancies fear,
With Setos and Abydos, which appear
Too aptly plac'd for hips. For thoe lov'd Seas
She now reolves crown'd by the Cyclades.
Nor Myconos, nor Seriphos pleas'd her mind,
Delos, nor Lemnos unto men unkind.
By Lycomedes Court, he lately tay'd,
And heard the hores ound while the Virgins play'd.
As he was ent to view Aegaeon's bands,
Who trove to looe his hundred-fettered-hands.
This Land, where quarrels no diturbance wrought,
The much ditracted Thetis afet thought:
Like a poor Bird, with wavering phanies pret,
That dares not chooe a branch to build her net.
Let it her brood, hould unto torms, or nakes,
Or men expoe; at length he likes and takes.
So Thetis on the place reolv'd, prepares
To go, but is aaulted with new cares;
Whether her on hould in her breat be laid,
Or through the waves born by a Triton's aid.
Or to the winged winds, his waftage owe,
Or unto Iris Ocean-nourih'd bow;
At lat two Dolphines he was pleas'd to rain,
Which by great Tethys, in th' Atlantick main,
For her were bred. The vat unfathom'd flood,
Bore nothing ele in all its caly brood,
So wift, o kind to men; At her command
Thee taid in waves, leat injur'd by the Land.
The leepy Youth, (for youth may oundly leep)
She from th' Aemonian cave, bears to the Deep.
The waves and winds becalmed her deignes
Ait, and Cynthia in full lutre hines.
For his return the Centaur following pray'd;
Of wav • s he knew, he need not be afraid.
O're-flowing tears, fall from his gazing eyes,
Whilt they upon the rouling billows rie
Now almot out of ight; yet till he gaz'd:
And when with waves they unk, himelfe he rais'd
Upon his hinder parts, till the waves quite
Had wallow'd all impreions of their flight.
Him that to Thealy mut ne'er return,
Sad Pholoe, and the clouded Othrys mourn:

l.hi: Sperchios
l.U: treams, no more with joy well high;

lg.l: And Chirons den now wanteth harmony.
The Fauns ament his loe; the Nymphs begin
To mourn their paion's hope, ravih'd with him.
And now the Stars begin to take their flight,
At the approach of Titan's radiant light.
Which from the Ocean roe; whoe drops like dew,
Back to its waves the riing Chariot threw.
But Thetis long before, to Scyros came,
And gave her Dolphines liberty again;
When leep forook refreh'd Aeacides:
His eyes aluted by the light, and Seas.
To him unknown, for Pelion all amaz'd
He look'd, and on his doubted Mother gaz'd.
Who takes him by the hand, with words thus kind,

l.hi: Dear child, if he that ure was once deign'd,
Had har'd my marriage-bed, thou hadst been plac'd
With Stars, for ever there by me embrac'd:
Heav'n had been then thy due inheritance,
Nor had I fear'd the leer Yates or Chance.
But now thy Father's mortall, there can be
No way for thee to cape death but by me;
And now the ad and fat all time draws near,
Whoe dangers are the caue of all myfear.
Forget a while thy Sexe's honour then,
Nor this afe habit which I wear contemn.

lg.l: If Hercules thus learnt to pin, and round

l.hi: A javeline bore with winding Ivy crown'd;

lg.l: If Bacchus in thee Ornaments was dres'd,
And Jove himelf, nor Ceneus mind depres'd

l.hi: Thereby; then uffer thus at my deire,
Th' appointed time Fate threatneth to expire.
Then I'le restore thee to the Centaur's cave.
By all the joyes and glory youth can have,
I do conjure thee now. If I for thee
Shar'd with a Mortall my Divinity?
If by the Stygian arming waves I stood,
And dip'd (I wih, all o're) thee in the flood:
Suffer thyelfe thus now to be conceal'd,
The mind's not hurt with what the body's heal'd.
Why dot thou frown, and turn away thy face?
Needt thou to bluh? Is gentlenee digrace?
By our known treams, I do aure thee too,

lg.l: Chiron, nor doth, nor hall know what we doo.
His breat in vain he tries, where rougher eeds
Were own, and tories of his Father's deeds:
Thus a proud hore, with vigorous blood inflam'd,
And heat of youth, contemneth to be tam'd.
But doth through fields, and unto rivers flie,
O'rejoy'd with his affected liberty:
He corns to yield to the retraining Bitt,
And wondreth at his fellows that ubmit.
What God with craft inpir'd the Mother's mind,
And unto oftnee her rough Son inclin'd?
By chance to Pallas, on the hore that day,
The Syrians did their acred offerings pay.
Hither the King, with his fair daughters came,
(Though eldome een) unto the holy flame.
The image of the rigid Pallas. Pow'r they crown'd
With fragrant wreaths, her pear with garlands bound;
All wrondrous fair. Their youthfull blooms grew,
Now like ripe fruit, as fit for gathering too.
But as the Sea-nymphs are by Venus looks
Excell'd, by Cynthia's thoe of leer brooks;
So from her Siters, uch lov'd victories
Were challenged by bright Deidamia's eyes.
Her roy looks did vanquih'd Jewels hame,
And on her purple garments threw a flame;
She might compare with Pallas, when he takes
Her gentlet looks, and layes aide her nakes.
At this fair Object, the fierce Youth remains
Fix't like a Statue, and receiv'd Love's flames.
Nor would th' inulting paion be conceal'd:
His parkling eyes the inward fire reveal'd.
Like the Maagetans red liquor mixt
With milk, or purple tains on ivory fixt;
Such mixture his new kindled paions bred:
His cheeks now pale, but traight with bluhing red.
At length, not brooking to be o delay'd,
Th' advancing Youth was by his Mother tay'd:
Like a young Bull, to rule the herd deign'd,
His horns not yet with full perfection twin'd;
When Love firt kindleth in his avage breat,
Thoe ruder paions for ome nowy beat;
He omes at mouth, whilet th' expecting wains,
Joy at the certain witnee of his flames.
His knowing Mother, finding the fit time,
Was now, thus aid; Canst thou, dear Son, repine

l.hi: With this fair crue, to hare unknown delights?

lg.l: Can Pelion, or cold Oa, hew uch ights?

l.hi: Oh that my cares were thine! that thou would't give

lg.l: A young Achilles in mine arms to live!
At this, with bluhes gentler he remain'd:
And though he yielded, yet he till contrain'd.
A womans dree, doth now the youth encloe,
And his trong arms, he learns how to compoe.
His hair's not now neglected as before:
And on his neck, he hangs the chain he wore.
Within rich robes, his teps confined now
Move in a gentler pace; and he's taught how
To peak with a reerved modety,
Thus changing Wax, which nimble fingers plie,
Firt rendered oft by active heat, inclines
Unto that form the workman's hand deignes.
So Thetis to another hape convey'd
Her Son. Nor needed he to what he aid,
Have added more: For in his beauty too,
All things appear'd, which to the ex were due.
Yet as they went along, he till renews
Her words, and her intructions thus purues;
Dear Child, in gentle looks compoe thy face,
And imitate each motion, and each grace.
Thou eet thee beauties wear, or ele I fear,
Unto the King our cou'nage, may appear.
This aid, till as they go ome Ornament
Her buie fingers mend. Thus Cynthia went
From hunting with her Mother; toil'd with port,
And with her quiver, to her Father's Court;
Her arms now hid, her garments loely flow'd,
And in a better form her hair betow'd.
Then to the King, her Son the goddee brings,
And thus, the Altars witneing, begins.
Receive Achilles Siter, as thy guet,

l.hi: Are not her Brothers looks in hers expre'd?
She in her quiver, and her bow delights,
And, like the Amazons, corns marriage-rites.

lg.l: Achilles is enough to be enjoy'd

l.hi: By me: Let this in thee rites be employ'd.
Let thy bet care of her allay my fears,
Errors are incident to tender years.
Let her not rove the woods, nor Gymnick game
Frequent, let with her cloathes he put off hame.
Let her till live with this fair company,
Nor ever let thy hores unguarded lie.
Thou aw't the Trojans lately, without caue,
Did violate the world's oberved Laws.

lg.l: This aid, the unknown Youth the King receives,
(Who finds out fraud when 'tis a God deceives?)
And further, rendreth all his thanks as jut
To her, who thought him worthy uch a trut.
The pious troup, with fixed eyes amaz'd
Upon his beauty, and proportion gaz'd
So much excelling others, then invites
Their company unto their acred rites.
So the Idalian birds, that nimbly flye
Through yielding air, in a known company.
If to the flock, a tranger joyn his wings,
He with himelf an admiration brings:
At lat acquainted all with joy, receave
The tranger, and the aire together cleave.
The lingring Mother, till yet loth to part,
Now takes her leave, repeating all the art
She taught before, and what he more could tell,
And with her whipered wihes bids Farewell;
Then takes the waves: her looks till backward bends,
And to the hore, thee gentle wihes ends.

l.hi: Dear earth, which hold't my dearet joy, to thee
Committed with a fearfull ubtilty;
Be ever happy and in ilence jut

lg.l: To me, as Creet to Rhea in her trut:

l.hi: Long may thy glories lat, and may thy name

lg.l: Grow greater then the wandring Delos fame:
Lee hurt by torms, then all the Cyclades,

l.hi: That break the billows of th' Aegean eas.
Let thy name be the Sailer's acred vow:
Yet to thy hores no Grecian hips allow.
Tell Fame, with thee no warlike pears are found,
But headlee ones with Ivy-garlands Crown'd.

lg.l: Whilt Mars, the parted Worlds, uch rage doth give,
Here let Achilles like a Virgin live.

div.head: ANNOTATIONS on the II Book of STATIUS his ACHILLEIS.
div.p:
5. THrace.] Thetis conidering with her elf, whither he might with mot afety convey her Son, in the firt place feared Thrace, conceiving that it would be an hatening of his detiny, to commit him to that warlick people; Whoe Country received its name from the on of Mars; or, as Stephanus aith, à regionis aperitate, quam
< in non-Latin alphabet > , Graeci appellant. So Pomponius witneeth, that this Region is obliged neither by aire nor oil, epecially near the Sea. The roughnee of the place wrought a like dipoition in the Inhabitants: And hence haply it is aid, that Mars was here nourihed. It is confined on the Wet by Macedonia, and the River Neus, as Ptolomy; but by Strymon, as Plinie aith. See Thucydides, lib. 2.

6. The Warlick Macedonian race.] Macedonia bordereth on Thrace, Epirus Illyris, and Thealie; o called from Macedo, on of Oiris, or (as Stephanus and Solinus) of Jupiter and Thyria, daughter of Deucalion. Thucydides, lib. 2. praieth them for an hardy and warlick people: But Statius had more reaon to give them that character, as living after Alexander the Great's time, whoe Victories were that Nation's greatet glorie. In their Militia, the Phalanx had the pre-eminence. This Nero imitated, Sueton. Nerone, ubi vide Caaubonum.
This teady Band conited all of tall and able Souldiers, ix foot high, or thereabouts, and < in non-Latin alphabet > , as Suidas aith, of equall age. The like policy the Turk ueth in the choice of his Janizaries, and with no lee uccee.

7. Athens.] This place alo the goddee held not afe to trut Achilles in, by reaon perhaps of the great confluence of trangers thither, it being the mot famous City in all Greece, cated in Attica, about forty furlongs from the Sea, as Strabo, lib. 9. Thucydides, lib. 2 aith, It was at its greatet height in the time of Pericles. It was the Mother of many Philoophers, and Orators, and Poets, and (as Tullie tyleth it) the Mitree of all human Sciences. But in the time of Syneius, it retained no uch excellency, Epit. 135. It was called Cecropia, from Cecrops who firt built it, and reigned in it; afterwards Mopopia, from Mopus; latly, Athens, from Minerva, whom the Greeks call < in non-Latin alphabet > , quai
< in non-Latin alphabet > , becaue he never ucked the breat, nor had need to do it; at her firt pringing from Jove's brain, being not an Infant, but a mature Virago, of full tat • re and trength. To this derivation, Cael. Rhodiginus aenteth, lib. 14. c. 18. Macrobius, Saturnal. l. 1. c. 17. aith, It was the opinion of Porphyrie, that Minerva was the vertue of the Sun, which infueth prudence into the minds of men. For therefore is this goddee aid to have iued from the head of Jupiter; that is, Widom commeth from the highest part of Heaven, whence the Sun hath its Originall.
< in non-Latin alphabet > alo, which ignifyeth not- • ffeminate, or manly, doth not onely come near to the name, but alo agreeth with the nature of this goddee, who was till pictured in a warlick poture, with an Helmet, a Spear, and a Shield, and aid to have a great troke in all actions of War, which ever depend upon Widom. This was the chief plea that
• yes ued againt Ajax, when they trove for Achilles's Armour, That Ajax his valour had been ueles, without lyes's policy to direct it, Ovid. Metam. lib. 13.

11. Myconos.] One of the Cyclades, under which the Poets feign thoe Giants to have been buried, that were lain by Hercules. The Inhabitants are aid to have been o ubject to baldnee, that a bald man was wont proverbially to be called a Myconian: Plin. l. 11. c. 37.

¶ Seriphos.] The Poet giveth it the epithet humilis, haply by reaon of its mall compae, which is but twelve miles, as Plinie aith. So Juvenal,—parvâque Seripho, Sat. 10. The whole world, he aith, was not wide enough for the young man of Pella, (o he calleth Alexander the Great) but when he had it all to turn him in he found himelf pittifully traitned for want of room, like one
cooped up in little Seriphos. The people of this Ile Pereus tranformed into tones, by hewing them his Gorgon's head, to revenge his forced mother. Yet long before, Acriius having thrown his mother Danae and him into the Sea, they were cat upon this Iland, and taken up by a fiher-man, and here preerved.

12. Delos.] This was placed in the middle of the Cyclades, and mot famous of them all, by reaon of Apollo's Oracle there, conulted from mot parts of the world. The Fable of its firt becomming firm land, ee in Plinie, lib. 4. c. 12. Strabo, lib. 10. and Servius, in Virg. Aen. 3. who relate, that it firt appeared to receive the burden of Latona, who was here delivered of Apollo and Diana It hath its name from < in non-Latin alphabet > , manifetus, perpicuus, Macrob. Saturnal. l. 1. c. 17. being aid to have rien up on a udden above the waves. Some think it worthy of this name from its Oracles; I wonder why, for they were eldome manifet. But Servius, and Alexander ab Alex. l. 6. c. 2. ay, The Oracle here was clear, when all others were obcure. After this Iland had appeared, it continued for ome time looe, and floated up and down, untill at lat it was fixed by Diana. Seneca Agamemnone act. 2. Chor.
—Tu maternam
Sitere Delon, Lucina, jubes
Hue atque illuc priùs errantem
Cyclada ventis. Nunc jam stabilis
Fixa terras radice tenet.
Thou didt thy mother's Delos bind,
Wandring before, drove by the wind
Among the Cyclades: Now it tands
Fix'd to the earth with rooted bands.
Servius in Aen. 3. aith, The truth is, that Delos being haken by a contant Earth-quake, the Inhabitants petitioning Apollo that they might be freed from it, were enjoyned thence-forward to bury none in the Iland. And Alexander ab Alex. lib. 6. c. 2. writeth, That all uch as were near dying, and all women ready to be delivered, were carried over to the Iland Rhene. Thucydides lib. 3. aith, That when Delos was totally hallowed by the Athenians, (Piistratus the Tyrant having before hallowed as much as was within the propect of the Temple) they took away all the Sepulchers, and made an Edict, That none hould either be born or buried there for the future; but when any were near the time for either,
they hould be removed into Rhe • e. In the dipute between Pauanias and the Athenians, about Title to this Iland, the Athenians alledging this Edict of theirs, Pauanias wittily demanded, How it could be their Iland, eeing none of them had either been born or buried in it, Plutarch in Apophth. Rhene is o near to it, that when it was won by Polycrates, he dedicated it to Apollo, and tied it to Delos with a chain. Divers Games were here celebrated, as Thucydides affirmeth, and Homer, Hymno in Apollinem; who ending their praies, thus alo leaveth his own, ver. 165.

q.l: < in non-Latin alphabet > ,
< in non-Latin alphabet > ,
< in non-Latin alphabet > ;
< in non-Latin alphabet > ,
< in non-Latin alphabet > .
Let Phoebus and Diana's kindnee dwell
Still here: And now to every one Farewel.
But yet remember when I leave this land,
And among all ome pilgrim hall demand,
Who was't, O Virgins, that with harmony
Could most affect your charmed ears? Reply
With one conent, and thus my praies tell,
A Poet blind, in Chios who doth dwell.

div.p: Lemnos unto men unkind.] This is an Iland in the Aegean Sea, called Ardens by Seneca, Herc. Oet. v. 1362. It is decribed by Valerius Flaccus, Argonaut. lib. 2. Here Cicero, de natura deprum, placeth Vulcan's Forge. Statius, Thebaidos l. 5.

q.l: —Aeg • o premitur circumtua Nereo
Lemnos, ubi igniera feus repirat ab Aetna
Mulciber.
To Lemnos in th' Aegean waves retires
The wearied Mulciber from Aetna's fires.

div.p:
Here Vulcan was bred, and had in great veneration. In his injuries the Inhabitants held themelves o concerned, that they
hated Venus for her adultery with Mars, Alexand ab Alex. l. 2. c. 14. Wherear the goddee being exaperated, infued uch hatred into the women againt their husbands, that they took counell to lay them all at their return from the Thracian War; and did o to all, except Hypipyle, who aved her father Thoas. The tory we have in Statius, Theb. lib. 5.

15. Aegaeons bands.] Aegaeon the on of Heaven and Earth, (Heiod. in Theogon) was called by Thetis to ait Jupiter, when Pallas, Juno, and Neptune would have fetter'd him, Lucian. dial. Martis & Mercurii: But afterwards waxing inolent, (as mot are wont to do after great merits) was himelf fetter'd by Jupiter to the Rocks of the Aegean Sea. And now Neptune having given notice, that he was endeavouring to unlooe his hundred hands, Jupiter ent Thetis to view his chains. She paing by Scyros, and eeing King Lycomedes his daughters at their innocent recreations, and the Iland filled with effeminate Inhabitants, thought preently no place could be more fit for her on's concealment, and reolved thither to bring him. This Giant was named Briareus by the gods, Aegaeon by men, Homer. Iliad. • . v. 403. by Lucian
< in non-Latin alphabet > , Briareum centimanum; and therefore was he bound with an hundred chains, as our Poet here aith. By Virgil he is placed in hell by Chimaera, Aen 6. The ret of the Giants alo are fixed in their everall places by the Poets, as Otus in Creet, Typhoeus in Campania, Enceladus in Sicily, whoe burning Tomb is made famous by Claudian's Mue, de raptu Proerp. l. 1.

q.l: Enceladi butum, qui aucia membra revinctus
Spirat inexhaustum flagranti pectore ulfur:
Et quoties detrectatonus cervice rebelli
In dextrum laevumque latus, tunc Inula fundo
ellitur, & dubiae nutant cum moenibus urbes.
Vat-limb'd Enceladus here buried lies,
From whoe hot breat unwated ulfur flies.
As often as o're-laden with his burd'n,
To eae his wearied ide he trives to turn,
The motion makes the heaved Iland quake,
And with their walls the tottering Cities hake.

div.p:
28. Iris Ocean-nourih'd Bow.] Iris
< in non-Latin alphabet >
nuncio, becaue the Rainbowe telleth of rain either pat or to come, Magir. lib. 4. cap. 5. Our Poet calleth her Thaumantida. In Greek he is called < in non-Latin alphabet > .
And there is no Meteor o worthy of wonder. Its many colours are caued by the reflection of the Sun-beams on a watry-clowd. Aritot. Meteorol. lib. 3. Iris • t arcus multicolor in nube roride, op • c • , & concava, ex radiorum Solis oppoiti reflexione apparens. Virgil. Aen. 4.

q.l: Ergo Ir's croce is per coelum rocida pennis,
Mille trahens varios advero Sole colores.
Swift Iris therefore with her dewy wings,
On which the Sun a thouand colours flings.

div.p:
The difference of its colours arieth onely from the unequall parts of the clowds. According to Aritotle they are three, Funiceus, iridis, Caruleus. Others make them five, as Ammianus Marcellinus, who calleth the firt Luteam peciem, a palih Yellow; the econd, nearer a Tawny; the third, Red; the fourth, Purple; the lat, a mixture of Blew and Green. But it is a trange error in Philoophers, to define the colours of the Rain-bowe, and they almot all differ about them. Yet are the colours they quarrell about not reall, but apparent onely; as the skie eemeth blew, which without doubt is not blew indeed. Nor is it poible, at o great a ditance, to decribe colours certainly. All that can be aid, is, That they appear uch to the eye. Marcellinus, lib. 20. taketh occaion, from the appearing of a Rain-bow, while Constantius beieged Amida, to treat of the reaons of the Rain-bowe, and why the Poets feigned, that Iris was o oft ent from heaven, Indicium est, aith he, permutationis aurae, à udo aere nubium concitans globos, aut contrà ex concreto immutans in erena • s laetitiam coelum. Ideo apud Poet •
legimus aepe, Irim de coelo mitti, cùm praeentium rerum fit tatûs mutario. That is, It is a igne of alteration of weather, gathering clowds in clear skies; or, on the contrary, changing thicknese into erenity. Therefore we often read in the Poets of Iris being ent from heaven, when there was any alteration made of the preent state of affairs. Of this fancy of the Poets, ee Gyraldi Syntagm. 9. For the Philoophie, experience contradicteth it. And Plinie aith, Nec pluvias nec erenos dies cum fide ab Iride portehdi. They held, the Rain-bowe was nourih'd by the Ocean, by reaon of both the Sun's and the Clowds ariing from thence. Scaliger, Exercit. 10. Sect. 11. peaketh of a Rainbowe that appeared in the night-time, and was een by Albertus and many others. And i • eilio, in his anwer to the E. of Mirandula, concerning the poibility of a Rain-bow's eeming entirely circular, though not being o, affirmeth, that he aw four uch at once in Padua.

33. So wift, o kind to men] Plinie aith, Dolphins are the wiftet of all fih, and a morous. Agellius, lib. 7. c. 8. relateth a tory of a Dolphin that loved a Boy o paionately, that his life was tied to the Boy's life. The ame Author, lib. 16. c. 19 out of Herodotus, etteth down the tory of Arion's being carried by a Dolphine, charmed by his Muick, irg. Ecl. 8. Orpheus in • ilvis, inter Delphin • s Arion. The tory is alo related by Plutarch in Symp. but mot weetly by the weetet of all the Poets, Fast. lib. 2. who thus decribeth Arion, when the covetous Mariners threatned him with drawn words.

q.l: Ille metu pavidus, Mortem non deprecor inquit;
Sed liceat umta pauca referre lyra.
Dant veniam, ridentque moram. Capit ille coronam,
Quae poit crines, Phoebe, decere tuos.
Induerat Tyrio ditinctam murice pallam.
Reddidit ict a uos pollice chorda onos.
Flebilibus numeris veluti, canentia dura
Trajectus penna tempora, cantat olor.
Protinus in medios ornatus defilit undas.
Spargitur impula caerula puppis aqua.
Inde (fide majus!) tergo Delphina recurvo
Se memorant oneri uppouise n • vo.
Ille edet, citharamque tenet, pretiumque vehendi
Cantat, & aequoreas carmine mulcet aquas.
He frighted, cries; I ask but that you'd give
Me leave to touch my Harp, not leave to live.
They grant it, • miling at his fond delay,
Whilt he aumes a Crown, which, Phoebus, may
Become thy locks, and on his houlders bound
A purple Robe. The tricken trings then ound.
The dying Swan o, when his fate begins
Near to approach, in mournfull numbers ings.
And o adorn'd, he leapt into the flood:
On the hip's ides the dah'd up waters tood
When traight his crooked back a Dolphin how'd,
And plac'd it under the unuuall load
He its, holding his Harp, and whilt he plaies,
The Sea growes calm, and for his portage payes.

div.p:
48. Otbrys.] A Mountain bounding Thealie on the South, Herod ••
l. 7. It hath on the Wet-ide Phthiotis, Strab. lib. 9.

51. The Fawns lament his loe.] Thee were Silvane gods, whoe Chief • as Pa • , lacivious like all his followers, who were held trangely amorous of men and women. The Chorus in Seneca, Hippol. act 2 believe it impoible, that Hippolytus living in the woods, hould ecape being ollicited by them:

q.l: —Te nemore abditum,
Cum Titan medium contituit diem,
Ci • get turba lice • s, Na • ades improbae
Formoos olitae cla • dere fontibus:
Et omnis facient inidias tuis

L •
• ivae nemo r • m deae,
Montiv • gique Panes.
For whilt in hades you bide, and day's
Divided by the god of Rayes,
The Naiades thy beauty moves,
Who in their fountains hut their Loves:
And the lacivious gods that keep
In woods, will court thee in thy leep.

div.p:
The quetion, Whether Spirits affect carnall copulation, hath been diputed by many: I hall onely relate thee few opinions. P • utar • h de Or • culor. defect. aith, that fury attendeth their unatiated last Paracelus relateth tories of ome; who have been married to mortall men. Cardane, de Subtilit. & variet. rerum. aith, They are as apt as dogs to be familiar with men. Plato was believed to have been begotten on a Virgin by the phantam of Apollo, by reaon of his admirable widom. Cardane, de var. & ubt rer. lib. 16. c. 43. peaketh of ome, who had had familiar company with Spirits for many years. And Agrippa, de occ • lta Philo. lib. 3. cap. 24. aith, Sunt adhu •
• o • ie qui commercium & conjugalem commixtionem habent cum Daemonibus. Burton in his MELANCHOLY relateth a tory of Menippus Lucius, That between Cen • hrea and C • rinth he met a Spirit, in the habit of a fair Gentlewoman; and, deceived by her allurements, married her. To the Wedding, among other guets, came Apollonius, who by conjectures found her to be a Spirit. When he aw her elf dicovered, he begged of Apollonius to be ilent: But he refuing, he vanihed with all her houe and furniture. Sabinus, in Ovid Metam. lib. 10. hath the like tory. Florilegus, ad Ann. 1 • 58. telleth of a young Gentleman of Rome, who, the ame
day he was married, going to play at Tennis, put his ring on the finger of the image of enus; and returning to take off his ring, enus had bent-in her finger o that he could not get it off. Whereupon loath to make his company tay, he left it, intending the next day to ue ome other means for it. Night being come, and going to bed to his Bride, Venus interpoed between, telling him, He had betrothed himelf to her by the ring he put upon her finger; and thus troubled him for many nights, till by the advice of Palumbus a Magician, he was releaed from his unwelcome Lover. Lavater, de pectr. part. 1. cap. 19. telleth this tory, I have heard, aith he, a grave and a wie man, in the Territory of Tigure, who affirmed, that as he and his ervant went through the pastures in the ummer time, very early, he epied one (as he thought) whom he knew very well, wickedly committing lewdnese with a Mare. At which being amazed, he returned back again, and knocked at his houe whom he uppoed he had een. There he certainly undertood, that the man had not been that morning from his chamber. pon which, dicreetly earching into the buinee, he aved the man, who ele had uffered for the deluding Damon. Corn. Agrip. de ocult. Philo. l. 3. c. 19. citeth a paage in St. Augutine, that Spirits are ubject to thee luts. And Mr. Burton quoteth Pererius in Gen. lib. 8. c. 6. v. 1. who affi meth, that thee Genii can beget, and have carnall copulation with women. In that fair Temple of Belus, as Herodotus aith, there was a Chappell, in which was plendidè tratus lectus, & appoita • en • aurea. Into this adorned bed none came, but the woman whom the god made choice of, as the Chaldean Priets told him; and their god lay with her himelf. Of this opinion is Lactantius. And Lipius relateth proofs thereof in his daies, in the City of L • vain. Further dicoure on this point I hall reerve for a place more worthy of it.

75. If Hercules thus learn'd to pin.] The • is being come to the Iland where he intended to place her on, letteth him know, that for his afety, he would put him into woman's habit. And knowing that the greatnee of his pirit would corn uch a diguie, he ertteth Hercules before him, who at the command of Omphale in uch a dree at pinning, Seneca Hippolyto, act. 1.

q.l: Natus Al • mtna pouit pharetram,
Et minax vati polium Leonis,
Pasus aptari digiti • maragdos,
Et dari legem rudibus c • pillis.
Crura ditincto religavit • uro,
Luteo p'ant •• cohibente occo:
Et manu, clavam modo quâ gerebat,
Fr • d deduxit properante fuo.
idit Peres, ditique • r • x
Lydia regni, dejecta eri
Terga Leonis, bumeriqu • , quibus
Sederat alti regia coeli,
Tenu • m Tyrio tamine pallam.

div.bibl: id. Herc. Furent. v. 465. & Herc. Oct. v. 372.

q.l: Great Hercules once threw away
His Quiver and the Lion's prey:
His fingers he adorns with rings,
And his rude hair in order brings:
His legs with gold embraced round,
His feet with yellow buskins bound:
That hand, which o well arm'd had been
With his great Club, now learns to pin;
By Perians and rich Lydians corn'd,
Not with his Lion's skin adorn'd.
Thoe houlders on which Heav'n hould ret
Were in a woman's habit dret.

div.p:
77. If Bacchus] Bacchus alo diguied himelf in a Virgin's habit, for fear of his mother-in-law Juno, Senec. O • dip. v. 417. Mythologers undertand this of the effects of Wine, which ometimes rendreth men eteminate, and otherwhile giveth courage to the mot womanih mind: And therefore was Bacchus aid to be of both exes. Origen lib. 3. contra Celum aith, that Bacchus was thought ometimes to have worn a woman's habit. Euebius, de Pr • p. Evang. l. 3 c. 9. giveth this reaon, why a woman's form (and therefore habit) was acribed to
• acchus, • t vim illam quae plantarum fructi • us i • et ex macula foemineaque conflatam ignificet; To ignifie, that the trength was of both kinds by which fruits were produced.

78. And Jove himelf.] The tory is commonly known: Jupiter going to viit the world, injur'd by Phaeton's Lightning, employed his firt care on Arcadia; where his eyes told his heart uch wonders of Colito's beauty, that he counterfeited the hape and dree of Dianae, (Quis Divûm fraudibus obstet?) and o enjoyed the deceived Calito, <> . Metamorph. lib. 2.

•
Coeneus] Who being ravihed by Neptune, and having the grant of • ih for her recompence, deired to alter her ex, that he might •• r uffer uch a misfortune more. Unto this the too kind god
added her beeing invulnerable. Yet in the battell of the Centaurs, and the Lapithae, he was preed to death: So impoible it is for power, any way applied in this world, to alter detiny. Nor do our fond attempts give occaion to Him above, to appoint new accidents: It is He, that permits thoe fond attempts, and letteth them be the means of thoe accidents, which we would mot avoid. The fable ometimes goeth, that he had power to change her ex. Otherwie the ene remaineth not perfect. In the other World, Virgil heweth her in her firt ex, Aen. 6. v. 448.

q.l: —Et juvenis quondam, nunc foemina, Coeneus,
Rurus & in veterem fato revoluta figuram.
And Coeneus once a Youth, but now a Maid,
By fate into her former ex convey'd.

div.p:
85. If by the Stygian arming waves.] Thetis to prevent the mortality of Achilles, which he had received from his Father, dipped him in the Stygian flood, all but the heel, which he held by; In which mortall part, he was hot by Paris. By this River, the gods took their inviolable Oaths, Virg. Aen. 6. Seneca, Thyet. v. 667. giveth it this Character,
Deformis unda, quae facit caelo fidem.
And Homer, Ody.
< in non-Latin alphabet > .
— < in non-Latin alphabet >
< in non-Latin alphabet > .
The greatet Oath among the bleed Gods.

The fable is, that Victoria the daughter of Styx, aited Jupiter in his War againt the Giants; For which ervice, he gave this honour to her Mother, that the gods hould wear by her, and inviolably keep their Oath, or ele be banihed from the banquets of the gods. This affordeth ome illutration to vere 213. Where Thetis wihing honour to the Iland Scyros, aith,

q.l: Let thy name be the Seamans acred vow.
Sicut qui argillam tractat, fingere
Ex ea animalis fo • mam potet,
Rurúmque diffingere, iterúmque ae
Quoties libet perpetuò vices itasrepetere:
Sic etiam Natura ex eadem materia
Olim avos nosiros, potea patres pro-
tulit, deinde nos, ac deinceps a-
lios ex aliis evolvet. Ac fluvius
Ille ortûs notri abque intermi-
Sicut & interitûs flumen hujus
C • ntrarium, five is Acheron et.
Prima ergo Caua, quae nobis Solis offendit
J • bar, eadem ad calig • ioum Orcum adducit.
As one that chafes the pliant clay, may bring
The ubtance to the form of any thing;
Again, detroy the pecies, and by skill
Repeat the ame as often as he will:
So nature alo at the firt, from clay
Our Ancetors did to the World convay,
Our fathers next; to them do we ucceed,
Others to us; and they hall others breed.
This flood of Life, flows at a contant rate,
Conuming till, as do the treams of Fate.
This flood's Cocytus, or ele Acheron,
Which tream the Poets et thoe names upon.
Thus the firt caue, which hews us the Sun-light,
Retores us back unto Eternall night.

div.p: 120. Receiv'd Love's flames.] Thoe thoughts of glory, that would not uffer Achilles to conent to his kind Mother's advice, yield to Love's power, by which all the World is fettered. Which matter is excellently expreed by Seneca, Hippolyt. act. 1. Chor. The greatnee of which power, joyned to the wiftnee of its execution, made the Antients believe, it was a facination; So Dido, at the firt ight of Aeneas, received a paion as durable as her life, ince he could find no way but one, to end both. The amorous Sappho, having expreed all the ymptoms of a powerfull paion, expecteth the ame fate.

q.l: —Velut herba pallent
Ora: pirandi neque compos, Orco
Proxima credor.
My lips grow pale, and my diordered breath
Is pent in ighs: ure, the next thing is death.

div.p: Ex interpretatione Henrici Stephani. According to thee examples, there is reaon enough to believe Claudians amorous begger;

q.l: Paupertas me aeva domat, dir • que Cupido:
Sed toleranda fames, non tolerandus amor.
In Loves and Fortunes fetters I remain:
One may endure the hunger, not the flame.

div.p: Aelian, Variae hit. lib. 12. c. 58 relateth the tory of Dioxippus, the famous Wretlet of Athens; Who coming into the City, as the manner was, after thoe exercies, fell in Love with a Maid, (like Achilles here) at the firt ight, as he paed along.

123. Maagetans.] A people of Scythia, inhabiting Caucaus, who ued to break uch in pieces, as died of old age, and to throw uch to Wild beats, as died of dieaes, Strabe. lib 2. They worhipped the Sun chiefly; to whom they offered an Hore. When they travelled through a wildernee, they were wont to drink Hores blood mingled with milk. So Claudian,

q.l: Et qui cornipedes in pocula vulaer • t aud • x
Maagetes.

div.p: 170. Altars witneing.] It was an oberved cutom, when any thing of con • q • ence was to be aid, or petitioned for, to do it before the Altars of the gods. So when I • rbas heard of Dido's paion for Aeneas, Aen. 4.

q.l: Ique amens animi, & rumore acceuus amaro,
Dicitur an • e • aras, m • dia inter numina Divûm, &c.
Enrag'd ('t is aid) at this unwelcome fame,
Among the Altars of his Gods he came.

div.p:
This he did, that he might perform that uuall ceremony of hol •
ing the Altars; as a little below, Talibus orantem dictis, • ráque tenentem. And the ame Prince of Poets, Aen. 12. Tango • ras, • edios ignes acnumina tetor.

And Macrobius, Saturnal. lib. 3. c. 2. aith, that Jupiter heard him, non quia orabat tan • ùm, ed quia & aras tenebat. And he citeth Vario, Divin. lib. 5. who aith, Aras primùm dictas, quòdeet nece •
rium à acrificantibus eas teneri. Anis autem olere teneri vaa, quis duhitet? Alexander a • Alexandro. lib 2. c. 18. aith, It was a cutom for thoe that were piouly praying to the gods, to embrace their knees, i. e. the knees of their Statues. And this certainly, is the onely meaning of that in Juvenal, 8 a • . 10. 55.
—genua incerare Deorum. But becaue incero ignifieth to cover with wax, ome hold, that they waxed-on their Petitions on the knees of their Statues. Turnebus lib. 1. cap. 17. aith, That they he • d the Statues with uch aiduous fervency, ut udore incraarentur, & videretur illis qua • cera uperpoita. Were it poible this place hould till remain unperfect, after its having paed through o many learned hands, I hould guee the word inuccare, to make moit, more apt to the ene, epecially to the interpretation of the mot learned Turnebus.

159. Nor Gymnick game.] Gymnad • s, from < in non-Latin alphabet > , Exerceo; or rather from < in non-Latin alphabet > , Nu • o. For they which exercied thee Games were all naked. Thee were invented by Lycaon of Arcadia. And the Spartan Vi • gins ued to practie all manly exercies naked. Alexand. ab Alex. lib. 2. c. 25.

208. As Creet to Rhea.] Thetis having now taken leave of her diguied on, and being entred the waves, turneth her eyes towards the Iland, and beggeth of it to perform its trut as jutly, as Creet had done to Rhea: Who, when her husband Saturn intended to murder all his children, being told that he hould have one, who would depoe him from his throne, hid her on Jupiter in Dicte, a Mountain of Creet, where the Corybantes her Priets, with their ounding Brae, drowned the noie of the child's crying, Natalis Comes. lib. 2. c. 1. Saturn was a great devourer of children, for to him the Carthagenians offered their ons, Plato in Minoe. By Saturn was undertood Time; by Jupiter, Heaven, which is not ubject to the power of Time: And therefore was it aid, that Jupiter was not devoured by Saturn. Gaffard in his Curioities, part. 3. chap 11. ect 8. aith, The antient Hebrews tood in much dread of the malignancy of the Planet Saturn. And the Chaldeans, who gave themelves over to the worhipping of fale gods, oberving this Star to be hurtfull, thought good by ome acrifice to render it more propitious to them. And no acrifice being fitter than that on which it wrought its ad effects, they began to acrifice children to it under the name of Moloch. And this, he believeth, was the originall of the Fable, why Saturn was aid to devour his children. And the Priets were aid to have made a noie with their brae, to drown young Jupiter's crie, from the cutom which they had to make uch
noies when the children paed through the fire to Moloch; which was no other then ome particular Daemon-rite. For MOLOCH ignifieth as much as BAAL. So we read, Pal. 106. 37. Mactârunt <>
•• s & filias daemonii • , as Mr. Selden rendreth it, De Dî • Syris, cap. de MOLOCH; to whom, and Saturn, children were the uuall acrifices, as he there heweth.

argument.head: The Argument.
argument.l: An Oath obligeth the revengefull Greeks,
At Aulis took. The ly Ulyes eeks
The wih'd Achilles; who, diguis'd, doth move
Unto the Conquet of his Mitree Love.

lg.l: IN the mean while, the fatall love of Arms
Stirrs the fierce Greeks. The Princes give th'alarms,
Soliciting revenge. The Ilians crime
They thus enlarge; that in a quiet time,
