No wars, the *[Helendaughter of great Jove by them
Was injur'd, with the Laws of god and men.
How hall the common people fare, if thus
They venture firt their injuries on us?
Thus all prepar'd for war; not alone The Inhabitants of Pelopon • eus. thoe
Whom the two Oceans do almot encloe,
Or round Malea dwell, but alo thoe

Who do inhabit where *The Hellepont.
Propontis flows.
Europe from Aia parting, and again
Thoe where the waves pread in a larger Main.
The wretched love of war warm'd every breat.
Fam'd Temea gave Bras; rigg'd Navies pres'd
The waves of the Euboean hores; and in

l.hi: Mycoena,

lg.l: Her Chariots Pia ends for warlick ue,

l.hi: Nemaean-
l.U: hades the skins of Beats produce.

lg.l: Cyrrha the Quiver fills; and for the Shields
Lerna gives Hides: the bold Acarnan yields
Bodies of Foot o doth th' Aetolian; Hore,
In Troops from Argos ent, compl • at the force,
Fetch'd from Arcadia's fair now-emptied plains.
For war her famous breed Epirus trains.
Aonian Woods and Phocis Arrows lend:
Their Engines Pilos and Meana end.
No place left free. They Arms from Pillars tore,
There by their Ancetors hung long before.
The gifts to gods the melting flames devour,
Alter'd to erve a far everer Pow'r.
No antient hades on th'hills mut longer grow:
Taygetus now and Othrys naked how.
Great Oaks for Ships, lee Trees for Oars they trim:
Whole Woods do now on the vat Ocean wim.
Iron by skilfull workmen is deign'd
For various ue; the beaks of Ships to bind.
For Armor, and for Bridles, and for Nails
On arming-coats, et like to fihes cales;
For Swords, for Darts, which, dipp'd in poion, throw
Death in the wounds they give. The whettones grow
With harpned weapons thin. Some pieces bring
In forms for Bowes, ome Bullets for the Sling
Prepare, ome harden Stakes, ome places gave
To Helmets where th'advanced Plumes hould wave.
Among thee tumults Thesalie remains
Alone unactive, and alike complains
That Peleus was too old, his on too young.
All-emptied Greece, now mad with fury, throng
To Ships, the crowded hores do eem to glow,
And enible of heat the billows how:
The jutled waves eem to preent a torm;
The Ships that raie it on the wellings born.
Under their weight the Ocean almot fails,
And all the winds carce erve to fill their ails.
At firt the waves by rocky Aulis bore
The warming Greeks, the much affected hore

Of Cynthia. There loud Proteus
Caphareus hows
His head, and back to th'waves, their clamors throws.
When all thee warms of ails came to his ight,
Thrice he preag'd a ad prodigious night.
Here firt Troy's fatall foes-united are,
And all by Oath oblige themelves for war,
Untill the Sun had pa'd one annuall coure,
And Greece appear'd in her united force.
Into a formed Army they compoe
Their diff'ring people, and a Generall choe.
So the wild multitude that hades enjoys,
Enclo'd with toils, frighted with fire and noie,
Fly to imprioning valleys, and admire
To ee their Mountain leen by the fire.
There the wild multitude know equall fear.
The Boar, the Woolf, together with the Bear
Imprioned lie: the fearfull Harts by them
The fetter'd Lions in the toils contemn.
Though both th' Atridae with the Army came,
And Diomede ambitious of great fame,
With Sthen'lus, and Antilochus appears
More mindfull of the war than of his years.
Though Ajax brought his Shield of even hides,
In compae like a welling Mountain ides.
Though lie Ulyes was among the ret;
Yet of Achilles all a want expres'd.
His name brings joy. He mut be Hector's fate,
And ruine of great Priam and his State.
"For whoe firt teps but his were taught to go
"In the Aemonian Valleys thorough Snow?
"Whoe youth uch rigid principles was taught?
"His line from Heav'n o directly brought?
"For whom, but him, uch care would Thetis have,
"To arm his fair limbs with the Stygian wave?
This through the Camp while all the Greeks proclaim,
The Captains joy, though vanquih'd, at his fame.
So in Phlegraean fields when the gods were
Aembled, and great Mars aum'd his Spear,
Pallas her Snakes, his Bow Apollo took;
Yet Nature till wore an affrighted look,
Till Jove himelf loud torms and thunders rais'd,
And from the clowds Aetnaean lightning blaz'd.
Whilt here the Captains by their Troops enclos'd
Conulted on thoe ways to peace oppo'd,
Protetlaus, who mot active how'd
I'th War, and on whom fate was firt betow'd,
Thus unto Calchas aid; Thetorides,
Sure thou forgettest Phoebus Oracles:

l.hi: For when can thy inpired lips relate
Better then now the hid decrees of Fate?
Dot thou not ee how all amaz'd admire

lg.l: Aeacides, the object of deire?

l.hi: The Calydonian Prince now all contemn,

lg.l: Slight either-Ajax too, and me with them.

l.hi: But ince our valour now is corned thus,

lg.l: Both Mars and ruin'd Troy hall peak for us.

l.hi: For him, the Princes all neglected are,
And he is honour'd as a god of war.
Speak quickly, (or ele why hould we allow
Thoe acred wreaths on thy adorned Brow?)
Where larks the Youth? for now, as men report,

lg.l: Hee's not in Chiron's Cave, nor Peleus Court.

l.hi: Speak then: if ever, now let thy deires
Wih for Prophetick breat-inpiring fires.
Thou halt ecure from war and danger ret,
Thoe gentle Wreaths with Helmets ne're be pres'd.
Be happy in th'eteem which all will ow

lg.l: To thee, if thou to us Achilles how.
Calchas this while his eyes doth wildly throw,
And his pale looks the god's approach do how.
His cheeks traight glow with heat: nor can he find
Or friends, or tents; o wild he is and blind.
Now in the sky great troops of gods he pies,
Now from the Fowls he takes his Auguries,
Now asks the Fates below their hid deigns,
And then conults the bright perfumed Shrines,
Snatches the tops of the acending fires,
And with the holy fume himelf inpires.
His hairs erected tood: in no one place
His neck kept fix'd, nor keep his feet one pace.
Tired at length and trembling, a voice broke
Through the oppoing furie, and thus poke.
Whither dot thou Chiron's lov'd charge now bear,
Thetis, with Woman's craft? Return him here.

l.hi: Hee's due to us: though waves obey thy will,

lg.l: Yet Phoebus too a god my breat doth fill.
Where dot thou hide the Trojan's fate? I ee

l.hi: The Cyclades and hores ought out by thee,
Where thou of thy unworthy theft art cas'd,
The guilty Land of Lycom • des pleas'd.
O crime! thoe hamefull flowing garments tear,
And be not ubject to a Mother's fear.
Ah me! now from mine eyes, hee's ravih'd quite,
What guilty Virgin's that alutes my ight?

lg.l: Then taggering, by his trength and rage forook,
He unk down by the Altar whilt he hook.
Then to Ulyes, Diomede thus aid,

l.hi: This buinee now eems to require our aid.
For I hall ne'r refue to go with thee,
If the deigne doth with thy thoughts agree.

lg.l: Though he in Tethys hollow ounding caves
Were hid, or wrapp'd by Nereus in his waves,

l.hi: Thou 'dt find him out. Let thy care be expre'd
From that great pring of counels in thy breast.
For, which of all our Prophets can deny
Thy judgment equall to their Propheie?

lg.l: Ulyes pleas'd, repli'd, What thou wouldt do,
Great Jove ait, and's blue-ey'd Daughter too.

l.hi: We run a hazard, 't is an act of weight

lg.l: To arm Achilles; and a hame as great.

l.hi: If our deigne be frutrated by fate:
Yet what the Grecians wih, I'le venture at,
And with me, the Peleian Prince I'le bring,
Ele Calchas tongue did uninpired ing.

lg.l: The Grecians hout: and Agam • mnon too,
Excites them unto that they meant to do.
The Councell then diolv'd, the Grecians rie,
And with a gentle murmur hew their joyes:
So at the night's approach, calm Hybla ees
Return, with buzzing noie, her Laden bees.
Now Ithacus a properous gale implores
To fill his ails, the youths too ply their Oars.
Farre off Achilles his diguie conceal'd,
Who to Deidamia now mut be reveal'd.
She, though the crime were hid, did fear expree,
And thought her Siters at the thing might guee.
For as Achilles tood among the bright
Fair charming troup, (his bluhes put to flight)
He choe his lov'd companion, (though the fair
Enamour'd troup for him had equall care)
And practic'd the unknown deignes of love,
Which in her breat could no upition move.
With hate, he follows her from place to place:
His eyes no buinee find but in her face,
Repeating looks; he ueth to abide
A cloe companion by her lovely ide:
Sometimes about her, flowry wreaths he trows,
And ometimes at her, harmlee javelins throw.
Now chants he Layes, that Chiron taught, and brings
Her courted fingers to the warbling tring;
Straight his obliged lips to hers are fix'd,
And praies with a thouand kies mix'd.
She gladly learns how Pelions top was rai'd,
And who Achilles was, and hears amaz'd
His name, with his atchievements of great things,
Whilt he himelf, himelf there preent ings.
She teaches then his gentler arms to pull,
In long extended threds, the following wool.
Setling the haken ditaffe in its place,
And his full voice admires and trong embrace:
Oberves his looks on none but her were fix'd,
And all his words with long-fetcht ighs were mix'd.
Now going to reveal his flame, he flies
With Virgin-fears, and his deign denies.
So Heavn's great Ruler in his tender years,
Ki'd his affected Siter without fears:
But Nature's laws being oberv'd no more,
She fears that love, he bluh'd not at before.
At length, his Mother's craft he did dicloe,
A grove there was, whoe top to Heav'n aroe.
Sacred to Bacchus, in whoe hades by nights
The women paid their Trieterick rites.
Whole herds they laughtered, pears from Trees they rent,
And to the God their gratefull furies ent.
The Law forbad all Males: yet that command
Was giv'n anew. Beides, a Priet did tand
To watch the bounds, left they might be defil'd
By ome rah man. At this Achilles mil'd.
Before the troup he with the Enigne goes,
And in unpractiz'd ways his arms betows.
Such as became the ex, and help'd the tales
His Mother told. Wonder on all prevails
To ee Deidamia's elf excell'd, as he
From her fair Siters challeng'd victory.
But from his nowy neck, that o exceld,
When the Hart's skin was thrown with Ivy held,
His hining brows with purple ribbands bound,
And to'd his pear with Vines and Ivy crown'd.
The troup then all amaz'd the acrifice
And rites forook; on him to feed their eyes.
So Bacchus look't, whil't he had yet reign'd
To Theban luxuries his looened mind,
Then leaves oft wreaths, his green pear head's with teel,
And now his nobler force the Indians feel.
Now Cynthia, in her Silver Chariot rode
On heaven's highet road, when the dull God
Of Sleep payes viits to the earth, and flings
Over the ilent world his heavy wings;
The tired Company then weary grown,
Lay down to ret. Achilles all alone
Thus with himelf begins, How long hall I

l.hi: Endure a Mo • hers fearfull ubtilty?
And in this oft eeminate Prion loe
My noblet thoughts? May not my right hand choe
One armed dart, nor more purue wild game?

lg.l: Doth not Sp • rchios till for me complain?

l.hi:
And prom •
• d hairs? Mut I for nothing look,
That's brave, who uch a Mater o forook?

lg.l: Or to the hades do all believe me fled,
And Chiron mourns me without iue dead:
My darts and bow are now employ'd by thee,
Patroclus too, and hores train'd for me;

l.hi: Whilt I brandih a pear with Ivy dres'd,
Or learn to pin, I bluh while't is confes'd.

lg.l: Why dot thou hide thy paionate deigne,
And in diimulation bury time?
Shall till thee flaming words conume thy breat,
And leave thy ex and paion unexpret?
This aid, and pleas'd with the conc • aling time
Of night, leep too aiting his deigne,
She now no more his feign'd embraces found,
Whilt he by force his burning wihes crown'd.
The Stars all mil'd, whilt they the wantons pi'd,
And Cynthia, her bright horns with bluhes di'd.
The Woods and Hills rang with her noie; when all,
Rou'd from their leep, thought it the ignall call.
At which the ecchoing grove with clamours hakes,
Whilt he again, his wreathed Thyrus takes:
But his afflicted mitree firt thus chear • ,

l.hi: 'T is I am he (why dot thou hew thee fears?)
Born of the Oceans Queen, who did betow
My breeding on me in Thealian now.
Nor had I e're endur'd this oft diguie,
Had not I firt been charmed by thine eyes.
It was thy pow'r beides, that did command
A Timbrel and a Ditaff in this hand.
Why dot thou weep, ince to the Ocean's King,
Thou art a Child, that mut Heav'n iues bring?
And ere thy Father hall diturb my joy,
Storms and unvanquih'd flames hall all detroy.
I am not turn'd a woman quite with this,
But yet awhile conceal this tealth of blie?

lg.l: At this, new fears amaz'd th' affrighted Queen,
Though till upicious of him he had been.
Trembling when he came near, now he fear'd more,
When he confe'd what he believ'd before.
Should he her Father tell, (what hould he do?)
And with her elf ruine the lov'd Youth too?
For his dear ake, he rather choe to be
By ilence made as deep in guilt as he.
By joynt conent, one confident they choe,
To whom they did their ecret theft dicloe,
Her womb now wells: and, all her heavy time,
She cunningly conceals her hame and crime.
Till Nature's jut deigned term did come,
And kind Lucina did unload her womb.

div.head: ANNOTATIONS on the Third Book of STATIUS his ACHILLEIS.
div.p: STatius, in the beginning of his third Book, (according to the Paris-Edition, for that of Amterdam maketh but two) repreenteth Greece preparing war againt Troy, and declaring their affection to it. This was the firt war we read the Greeks were engaged in, Thucyd. lib. 1. And therefore it is the lee wonder that they loved war, eeing they undertood it not. Since alo we have montrous examples of ome, that have been weary of peace, giving it no better a name than Idlenee, and making it the candall of a Nation. When it is wanted, it will be eteemed. Such is the fatall folly of frail nature. Sylla told King Bocchus, that the gods advied him, when he choe any peace rather then war. And when ome diliked the effects of the Treaty, Salut Bell. Jug. excellently aith, Scilicet ignari rerum humanarum, quae fluxae & mobiles aepiùs in advera mutantur. Expectation of better is the great couenage of this world, at leat the attempts and profeion of it.
10. Two Oceans.] Peloponneus, now called Morea, hath the Ionian Sea on the right hand, and the Aegean on the left, being a Peninula, in whoe ithmus tood the City of Corinth.
11. Malea.] A Promontory in Laconia, between which and Taenarus is the Laconian Bay, Strab. lib. 8.

16. Temea.] A City of the Brutians, famous for Brae-mines; after called Tempa, Plin. l. 3. c. 5. There is a Town of this name in Cyprus alo famous for Brae. One of thee afforded matter for the tately Hore of Domitian, Statius Silv. lib. 1. in Equo. Domit.
div.q: Et quîs e totis Temee dedit hauta metallis.

q.l: Upon which large and tately Statue, hrines
The City Tem • a's exhauted Mines.

div.p: 17. Eubaea • hore.] Euboea aited with hips, being an Iland oppoite to the Continent of Attica, Boeotia, and Locris, extending from Sunium as far as Thealie, Strab. lib. 10.

18. Mycena] A City o near Argos, that, as Strabo aith, their names were oftentimes promieuouly ued for one another. It was once the head of Argia; ditant from Argos but fifty furlongs, Str • b. lib. 8. & Pauan. in Corinth. It received its name (as Etepha • us aith) from the handle of a Sword, which the Greeks call < in non-Latin alphabet > . The word ignifleth properly a Mubrain. It is ued alo for the lower part of the handle of a Sword, which is like a Muhrum. Mycena had its name from hence, becaue Pereus letting the handle of his Sword fall there, was commanded by Mercury there to build that City.

19. Pia.] A City near the River Alpheus, where the Olympick Games were celebrated, eated in Elis, a Region, which with Meena takes up the Wet-part of Peloponneus. Here Salmoneus once reigned, whoe ambition and punihment is thus decribed, Aen. 6. 585.

q.l: idi & crudeles dantem Salmonea poenas,
Dum flammas Jovis & onitus imitatur. Olympi.
Quatuor hic invectus equis, & lompada quasans,
Per Graiûin populos mediaeque per Elidis urbem
Ibat ovans, Divûinque ibi poeebat honorem:
Demens, qui nimbos & non-imitabile fulmen
Ae • e & comipedum curu fimulârat equorum.
At Pater omnipotens dena. inter nubila telum
Conto • fit (non ille faces nec fumea tedis
Lumina) praecipitemque immani turbine adegit.
I alo aw Salmoneus cruell fate
In tortures held, who trove to imitate
Jove's lightning, and the noie that heaven makes.
By four Steeds drawn, a puttring Torch he hakes,
And through fair Elis crowded treets he drives,
Ambitious of the gods prerogatives;
Mad man to think, that Flame which thought exceeds,
To imitate with Brae and trampling Steeds.
But through the cracking clowds enraged Jove
A fatall ruhing Dart whirl'd from above,
(Not Brands, nor moaky Torches) and him cat
Headlong by that unimitable blat.

div.p:
20 Nemea.] A Wood of Achaie, where Hercules lew a Lion. Servius aith, Nemca et vicina ylva Thebis, in qu •
Hercules interemit
Leonem. But this is a great error in the learned Servius. For Nemea is a Forret between Cleona and Phlius, Strab. lib. 8. & Thucyd. l. 5. which Towns are far ditant from Thebes, which is in Boeotia.

21. Cyrrha.] A City of Phocis, in the Corinthian Bay, Strab. lib. 9. Pauanias in Phocicis, makes it all one with Cria; Plinie, not. Here Apollo was worhipped: And therefore the people haply aid to have delighted in Arrows.

22. Lerna gives hides.] Near Argos is a Lake of this name, where Hercules lew the Hydra, notwithtanding that in the room of one head lopped off, three new ones till prouted forth. Servius believeth, that in this place there was a wift River, which overflowed the neighbouring Towns, and being topped in one place, broke forth in many others with greater impetuounee: Which michief Hercules remedied, by damming up the whole Lake. There is a Town alo, as Britannicus aith, of this name.
23, 24. Acarnan—with th' Aetolian.] Aetolia bordereth on Phocis, Acarnania on Aetolia, betwixt which runneth the river Achelous. The Bay of Ambracia parteth Acarnania from Epirus, Strab. l. 9.

¶ Argos.] Here Juno had a Temple, whence he was called Juno Argiva. It is commonly placed in Maps a great way from the Sea; but Pauanias in Corinthiacis aith, It is but forty furlongs off; which Thucydides alo confirmeth, lib. 5. where he aith, that the Argives fearing the Lacedaemonians, and renewing League with the Athenians, raied large Walls from their City down to the Sea-hore, to the end, that if they were hut up by Land, they might, by the Athenian's help, receive in fitting proviions by Sea.

25. Arcadia.] A Region in the midt of Peloponneus, Strab. lib. 8. remote every way from the Sea; famous for pature, and much more, in having been the ubject of o many excellent Pens. For which caue it needeth no more of mine.

26. Epirus.] A Country bordering on Greece, on the Eat divided from Achaia by Achelous, on the Wet by the Acroceraunian Mountains, which lie upon the Adriatick hore; on the North it is bounded by Macedonia: Its South-ide is wahed by the Ionian Sea. It was firt named Moloia; afterwards Chaonia, from Chaon brother of Helenus; now, Albania. Once it was full of Cities and Inhabitants; but after it was vanquihed by the Romans, it long retained the marks of a conquered Nation. Among other things it was famous for wift Hores, Servius in Virg. Georg. 3. That incomparable Poet (Georg. 1.) alo acribeth the ame to it, —Eleadum palmas Epiros equarum.
Ep • rus Breed by wiftnee gains
The Garland in th' Olympick Games.
Servius in loc. out of Plinie, giveth this reaon of their wiftnee, that they tale in their coures; which is not onely ridiculous, but impoible. Georg. 3. 273. The Poet relateth the fond opinion of Mares generating with the wind, which Servi • s alo out of Varro conirmeth. In thee latter days, Epirus gained its greatet fame, by being the place for which the generous Scanderbeg performed o many glorious actions.

27. Aonian hades, and Phocis.] Both Regions of Boeotia. The Phocians inhabit the Eat-ide of Para • us the Mue's Hill, Sirah. 1. 9. Aonia alo had a Fountain dedicated to the Mues: Whence Juvenal Sat. 7.

q.l: —aptuque bibendis
Fontibus Aonidum.

div.p:
28. Pyles & Mean • .] Pylus is a City of Meenia, on the Promentory Coryphatum. Thucydides, lib 4. relating the advice of Demothenes to fortifie Pylus, taketh occaion to hew its ditance from Sparta to be four hundred furlongs, and that it tandeth in the Territory, called by the Lacedaemonians Coryphatum, that once belonged to the Meenians. This was Netor's Country. There is alo in Elis a City of this name; Strabo peaketh of them both, and alo of a third in Arcadia, Meene, here called Meana, is a City and Region on the Wet-part of Peloponneus, conining on Arcadia, Elis, and
• aconia. But Meana is a Town in Sicilie, near Pelorus. Strabo lib. 8. aith, it was called Zancle: Which name, Ibucydides, lib. 6. aith, the Sicilians gave it, becaue it was like a Sickle, which they called < in non-Latin alphabet > . After, it received the name of Meana, from Anaxilas the Tyrant of Rhegium, being the name of the Country whence he was antiently deeended; but others ay from the Meenians, a people in Achaia.

34. Täygetus] A Mountain of Laconia, beginning at the Sea, and reaching up towards Arcadia as far as Lacedaemon, Sirah. lib. 8. It was acred to Bacchus, as Servius aith on thee words, Georg. 2. —et virginibus Bacchata Lacaenis Täygeta.
—And on Täygetus top, where all
Laconian Virgins pay their Bacchanalls.
Cicero de divinat. lib. 1. aith, The Lacedaemonians being warned by Anaximander to leave their houes, they were uddenly thrown down by an Earth-quake, with part of the mountain Täygetus.
45. Stakes] The Antients made ue of takes in war, harpned at one end, and hardned in the fire, Virg. Aen. 11.
57. Aulis] An Haven (or an Iland, as Servius aith, in Aen. 4.) of Baeotia, where the Greeks made their great rendezvous, and took an Oath to detroy Troy, or never to return, Senec. Agam. 170.

q.l: Cruore ventos emimus, & bellum nece
Non et oluta propero clais Deo.
Ejecit Aulis impias portu rates.
War and th' obliged Winds by blood were brib'd.
Not a propitious Power was their guide,
When from the Port of Aulis firt they fled,
And their well'd ails the impious Navy pread.

div.p: This blood was Iphigenia's, who was acrificed to Diana, becaue Agamemnon her father had killed a Hart which the goddee loved. Much contention there is concerning her transformation; Mot agree he was turn'd into a Hinde. Ludovicus Coppellus in his Diatriba de vot • Jephtae, compareth the condition of Agamemnon and Jephtha together, and maketh them contemporary, and fetcheth the name Iphigenia from Jephtha, quai Iephthigenia; and conceiveth the fable of her tranmutation aroe from the tory of Iepthah's daughter wandring on the Mountains. Of this acrifice peaketh Nazianzen, Orat. 20. And Euebius, de praeparat, Evang. hath much of human acrifices; which are aid to have been performed by divers Authors. The Fable of Agamemnon's daughter is et down by Hyginus, lib. 1. cap. 98. Ovid, Metamorph. lib. 13. Euripides, in Iphigenia, Seneca in Agam. Dictys Cretenis, and many others.
79. Antilochus] the on of Netor, famous for his actions againt Troy. Statius here giveth him this character,

q.l: —nec cogitet annos
Antilochus.

div.p: This, Britannicus interpreteth of his youth, and his doing actions, that uch years as his were not wont to produce. But had he remembred, that his Father had been at the hanting of the Bore with Meleager, Ovid. Metamorph. lib. 8. fab 4. and had already lived two ages, when he came againt Troy, Homer, Il. a 250. he might with more reaon, have believed Juvenal, concerning the age of Antilochus Stat. 10. 250.

q.l: —Oro, parumper
Attendas, quantum de legibus ipe queratur
Fatorum, & nimio de tamine, cum vidci acris
Antilochi barbam arden • em, cum quaerit ab omni,
Quiquis adet ocius, cur haec in tempora duret,
Quod facinus dignu • tam long • admierit aevo.
Hearken a little, how old Netor cries
Againt the Fates, and too kind detinies;
The beard of brave Antilochus, while he
Upon the funerall pile doth flaming ee.
Of every one, demanding what trange crime
Prolong'd his age to uch a wretched time:

div.p: 85, 86. He mut be Hectors fate, And ruine of great Priam] The death of Hector, I have above et down. The ruine of Priam is jutly attributed to Achilles, in that he begat Pyrrhus, who killed him before the Altar, Virg. Aen. 2 554.

q.l: Haec finis Priami fatorum; hic exitus illum
Sorte tulit, Trojam incenam & prolapa videntem
Pergama, tot quondam populis terri • que uperbum
Regnatorem Aiae, jacet ingens littore truncus,
Av • l • mque humeris caput, & ine nomine corpus.
This was of once great Priam the hard fate,

l.hi: Troy
l.U: een on fire, and his ruin'd tate;

q.l: He who o're part of Aia late did reign,
Now headlee lies, a corps without a name.

div.p: We read of few examples, of o great alteration of fortune, unlee this later age hath produced them; Who now perhaps, take uch a propect of their corned bodies, as Lucan, lib. 9. v. 10. giveth pompey of his from Heaven,

q.l: —Illic post quam e lumine vero.
Implevit, tellaque vagas miratur, & atra
Fix • polis, vidit quanta ub nocte jacere •
Nostra dies, riitque ui ludibria trunci.
There with true light inpir'd, the wandring fires
And fixed tars for ever he admires.
The day ees wrap'd in night, which us beguiles,
And at his corn'd and headlee carcae miles.

div.p:
95. Phlegraean fields] Phlegra is a valley in Thealy, where the mountains Pelion and Osa tand, on which the Poets feigned the Giants a ••• lted heaven. There is another Phlegra in Campan • a, near Cume, which ome make the tage of that bold attempt, Strab lib. 5. Some reduce it to a truth, as ridiculous as the fable; How that a proud Nation, of montrous dipoitions, rather then tatures, warred againt Hercules, and were here overthrown by help of lightning, which aroe by agitation of winds, the ear • h being ulfurous, and o • ubject to burning: From whence it had the name Phlegra,
< in non-Latin alphabet > ignifying to burn. Cicero, in his Ca • o major, aith the War of the Giants • ith the gods, was nothing but Men' rebelling againt Nature. And Macrobius, Saturn, lib. 1. c. 20. decribeth them to have been an impio • s race of men, who, denying the gods, were therefore aid to attempt the dethroning of them, And their lower parts, feigned to be like the winding voluminous tails of Dragons; ignified their indirect and crooked affections. Vadianus, in his learned Notes on Mela, undertandeth this Gig • ntomachia, of the encloure of air in the earth, which forceth its way forth, as it were with defiance to Heaven, which is Jupiter; And this glanceth at th • Mythology, that Macrobius giveth. Ovid, Fastor. 5. thus expreeth the Fable.

q.l: Terra feros partus immania monstra gigantes
Edidit, auturos in Jovis ire domum.
Atque ait, In magnos arma movete Deos
Exstruere hi montes ad idera u • m • paraban,
Et magnum bello ollicitare Jovem.
Fulmina de coe • i jaculatus Jupiter arce,
Vertit in autores pondera vasta uos.
The Earth brought forth Giants to vatnee grown,
That durt attempt to torm Jove's tarry Throne.
A thouand hands he gave them, crooked thighs
Like nakes, and bids them war with Deities.
They hills on mountains pil'd to reach the tars,
Attempting Jove himelf with impious wars.
From whoe revenging hand, the lightning blaz'd,
Turning thoe mountains on them which they rais'd.

div.p: This, learned Bochartus accurately applieth to the builders of the Tower of Babel, Geograph. Sacr. lib. 1. c. 13.
175. Hybla.] A City in Sicily, abounding with flowers and bees. Senec • , O • dip. 601.
div.q: Nec vere tores Hybla tot medio creat.

q.l: Nor doth the fragrant Hybla bring
So many flowers in the pring.

div.p: 213. Heaven's great Ruler.] Jupiter was bred with his iter Juno in Creet. See on Book II, vere 208. He was aid to marry her by reaon of the propinquity of the Fire and the Air; Hence alo it was, that he could not match with Thetis, that is, the Sea. He is called < in non-Latin alphabet > in Greek, < in non-Latin alphabet > , from being the gi • er of Life. Aulus Gellius, lib. 5. c. 12. Jovem Latin • veteres à ju •• hdo appellavere; eundémque alio vocabulo juncto Patrem dixerunt: Which by the cutting off, and altering ome Letters, is Jovipater as Marpater, or Marpiter. This, unimitable Selden condemneth, Syniagm. 2. de Ba • l and Belo.

219, 220, 221, A grove there was—Sacred to Bacchus, in whoe hades by nights, The women pay'd their Trieterick rit • s.] I hall venture to be judged impertinent, rather then neglect th • e two ubjects, conecrated Groves, and the Rites of Bacchus; Of thee, with as much brevity as is poible. A Grove is called in Latin, I ucus, quòd non luceat; non, quód int ibi lumina caua religionis, ut quidam volunt, as Servius, in Aen. 1, And in Georg. 3. he affi • meth, that all Groves were conecrated to Diana; Perhaps, it was generally believed o, by reaon that he was reputed the Goddee of the Woods. For Servius certainly, could not forget that vere, Aen. 7.

On which both himelfe and Sabinus relate, that the grove of this Goddee, Feronia, being burnt down, and the people going to carry away her Statues, immediately it prung up again, freh and green. Suetonius in Auguto, peaketh of a grove, acred to Liber or Bacchus, where Octavius conulted concerning his on; Thee Groves were ued for Temples by the Germans, Alexand. ab Alex. lib. 4. c. 17. And Tacitus, de morib. Germanor, cap. 9. aith, Lucos ac nemora conecrant, Deorúmque nominibus appellant ecretion illud quod olâ reverentiâ vident: A decription of thee groves, fee in Seneca, Oedip. act. 3. and in our Poet, Thebaid 4. I have in ome of thee Notes, given hort intimations, that there was nothing in the worhip of Daemons, which was not an imitation of the worhip of the true God: Larger proofs whereof, time perhaps may favour my intentions to produce. Among other things, Groves will appear to have had • ch an originall; Learned Mr. Mede, on Joh. 24. 26. heweth that the Jewes had their praying places, beides their Synagogues, out of a notable place of Epiphanius, a Jew bred and born in Palae •• ine. Which, he aith, were open places, and calleth them Proeuchas. Of which Juvenal, Sat. 3. 296.

On which words, the Scholiat and Lubine ay, Proeucha ignifieth a place, where Beggars ue to inhabit. For < in non-Latin alphabet > is Orare, to beg or pray. Yet the Scholiat immediately addeth, Et Proeucha, locus Judaeorum, ubi orant; Mr. Mede alo citeth a place of Philo Judaeus, in his de legat. ad Caium, where he commendeth the exceeding clemency of Augu • ius Caear, in allowing the Jewes their Proeucha's. But he denieth not but that, under that name, Philo comprehendeth Synagogues alo; Politian Micell. cap. 30. faith, the word is ued, pro Templo & Synagoga Judaeorum. Some held the Jewes had no Synagogues before the Captivity: and their reaon, perhaps, is the ilence of the Scripture, which mentioneth them not, till the Jewes were returned from Babylon: This Mr. Mede taketh notice of, and letteth it pae for currant; But as for Proeucha, or conecrated Groves, he proveth them to be near as antient as Johuah: hewing the Oak of Shechem, to have been uch an one, and not a ingle Tree, as the common interpretation rendieth it. That Trees were in thee Proeucha's, may be gathered from another place of Philo, cited by the ame worthy Author, where relating the outr • ge of the Gentiles, at Alexandria, againt the Jewes, there dwelling in the time of Caius, he faith, Of ome of the Proeucha's, they cut down the Trees, others, they demolihed
to the very foundations. This alo is implied by that of Juvenal, Sat. 6. 542.
Arcanam Iud •• tremens mendicat a • aurem,
Interpres legum Solymarum, & magna acerdos
A • boris.
And Sat. 3. 12. he complaineth, that the Jews had leave to live in the wood, which had been acred to the Maes. Whence this joyning of Trees and Jews together, but from their having their Pro • ucha's ordinarily et with them? I could et down many Texts of Scripture, which directly ditinguiheth between thee Groves and Temples, as Pal. 74. 7. though not rendred o in the Vulgar. Tranlation. So Gen. 13. 4. it is aid, that Abraham went unto the place of the altar which he had made at firt, and there called on the name of the Lord. Which is explained by Gen. 21. 33. a place expree to our purpoe, And Abraham planted a grove in B • erheba, and called there on the name of the Lord, the everlasting God. Luk. 6. 12. we meet with one of thee praying-places. There it is aid of Jeus; < in non-Latin alphabet > , He went out into a mountain to pray, and continued there all night p •• ying to God. So Beza rendieth the place, Abii • in montem ad precandum, & pernoctavit illic preca • s Deum, which certainly will not eem a jut interpretation to any eyes: but it would be much more genuinely tranlated in proeucha Dei, than, taking < in non-Latin alphabet > for a Genitive cae of the Object, in precatione ad Deum. And in this ene, witho • t doubt, the word is to be undertood, Act. 16. 16. < in non-Latin alphabet > , euntibus nobis ad proe • cham, or locum • rationis. Beza here alo tranlateth it ad precationem. But v 13. it is aid, that Paul and his company went on the Sabbath day out of the city Philippi by a river ide, where prayer was wont to be made. If the word < in non-Latin alphabet > be here taken for prayer, neverthelee it importeth a place where it was ued, and that by a river's ide: And it could not be a Temple, becaue they went out of the city to it, and Temples always tood in Cities. Therefore •• judge the word mot properly to be taken for a place, that is, a Proeuchs, or grove. Thee Dae • ons taught the Gentiles, in imitation of the Jews, to ue uch places of devotion. H • rein abominable ceremonies were practie, as frequently appeareth in Scripture, and therefore were they forbidden. See Ia. 57. 5. Ho. 4. 13. Ezek 6. 13 Thus much of Groves. Now for Baechus and his rit • s, I • hall firt et down the Fable, which hath more reflexion on the
truth than is generally conceived. The Poets ay, that Semele deiring to embrace Jupiter as Iuno was wont, and being burnt for her ambitious appetite; Iupiter caught his little imperfect Infant from within her, and having ewed it up within his own thigh, kept it there till the time was compleat that it hould have lien in the womb Then iuing forth, he was bred up by Nymphs, and became the inventer of Wine. Of which, ee Euebius de praeparat. Evang. lib. 2. cap. 2. who there peaketh of another Bacchus the on Iupiter and Proerpine, much antienter than the on of Semele. But this is rather from others fancies, than from proofs either of his own or theirs. As little will it be neceary to take notice of the endeavours of Macrobius, to make Bacchus all one with Apollo, Sat. l. 1. c. 8. Which opinion is condemned by Eaebius, de praepar. Evang. l. 3. c. 13. It will be onely in ome mall manner convenient, to take ome leight notice of ome Phyicall applications of the Fable. Bacchus, they ay, was feigned to proceed from his father's thigh, becaue Vines proper bet in a warm oil. His lips were anointed with Hony by the daughter of Aritaeus; for the Antients held Wine a friend to Eloquence. He continueth till young; for Wine preerveth the heart from cares, which are a greater caue of wrinckles and gray hairs than age. Hence alo was he called Liber. Other reaons of which name, ee in Plutarch, Quaet. Roman qu. 25. Many other appellations of his ee in Ovid Metam. l. 4. Aelian
• r. hist. l. 3. c. 41. Alex. ab Alex. l. 6. c. 4. Natal. Com. l. 5. c. 13. Pier. Hieroglyph. l. 27. Gyrald. Synt • gm 8. All which, having no relation to the truth, I forbear to meddle with. For declaring who Bacchus was, and what his rites and ceremonies were, I hold it req • iite to hew who Saturn the father of Iove was, by whom Bacchus was begotten; and herein I hall wholly follow learned Bochartus. Saturn he accurately proveth to be Noah. For, as the Scripture tyleth a Souldier, a man of war, Joh. 5. 4. a murderer, a man of blood, 2 Sam. 16 7. &c o it ty • eth Noah onely, a man of the earth, that is, an Husbandman: Which title Saturn had, and was, as Noah, believed the firt planter of Vineyards. Therefore to him they attribute the ue of the Reap-hook, and picture him with one, Plutarch Quaet. Rom. 42. Macrob. Saturn l. 1. c. 7, & 10. And as if Noah, by his being a man of the earth, had indeed married the earth, Saturn was aid to be t • e husband of Rhea, which eemeth to be derived of < in non-Latin alphabet > , to flow, and ignified the earth, which is the ea • of moiture. For, according to antient Philoophers, all Rivers are generated, and have their coures under ground. This Virgil heweth, Georg. 4. who aith,
That when Aritaeus was admitted into his mother's kingdom,
Omnia ub magna labentia flumina terra
Spectabat divera locis.
—There under ground he pi'd
How everall ways the wandring Rivers glide.
Macrobius Saturn l. 1. c. 10. deriveth Saturn's name à a • u, to wit, from planting or owing. Satur, that is, plenteous or abundant, is nearer to it; and Sator, that is, a Sower or Planter. From Noah's being drunk, Bochartus lib. 1. cap. 1. bringeth the ue of the Saturnalia; and inerteth a pretty obervation concerning his curing of Cham, becaue he had een his ecret parts. The like the Heathens held proceeded from Saturn. For Minerva having tricken Tire •• as blind for eeing her naked, thus excueth her elf to his mother, Callimach. Hymn.
—non per me, perdidit ille o culos:
Nec mihi luminibus pueros orbare volupt • s,
Ast à falcigero lex Sene l • t • jubet.
t poena graviore luat, te • eraria quiquis
Auit in invitos lumina ferre deos.
'Twas not by me: nor do I take delight
Or pleaure to rob any of their ight.
The Law from Saturn came, That he hould be
Punih'd, who e're th'unwilling gods hould ee.
For this, Actaeon uffered. And to this Law Propertius alludeth, lib. 3.
•• eg. 12. peaking of the Golden age, Non fuerat nud •• poena videre deas. The on of Noah or Saturn which was cured, was Cham or Ham; who, by reaon of his being the younget, or rather becaue cured by his father, inhabited the andy and barren parts of Africk, where he was worhipped by the name of Jupiter Hammon, or Ham. Now Ham had a on or grandon called Nimrod, who was all one with Bacchus, as Bochartus, without any quetion, concludeth, lib. 1. cap. 2. For Bacchus is the ame with BAR-CHUS, that is, the on of Chu ••
or C • h, as Nimrod was, Gen. 10. 8. So Darmeek and Dammeek is all one with Damacut. One of Bacchus his antient names
is < in non-Latin alphabet > , which ignifieth a mighty Hunter, as Nimrod was, Gen. 10. 9. And this is the reaon why ome held Bacchus the ame with Pluto, Pluto enim defunctorum • nimss venatur & captat. Bacchus was alo called < in non-Latin alphabet > , from < in non-Latin alphabet > , an Hind's Calf, becaue himelf and his frantick adorers were uually clad with Stags skins. This alo hath relation to Nimrod's being termed an Hunter: And Bochartus heweth Nimrod and Nebrod to be all one. Bacchus was aid to be born of Jupiter's thigh: Now ome will not have < in non-Latin alphabet > to ignifie a thigh, but to be the name of an Hill where he was born, by Nya in India; o Mela, lib. 3. cap. 7. and Plinie, lib. 6. cap. 21. Others conceive, it ignifieth the ide of a mountain, as Iudg 19. 1. < in non-Latin alphabet > , in the thighs, or ides, of mount Ephr • im. And 2 King. 19. 23. < in non-Latin alphabet > , to the thighs, or ides, of Libanus. So perhaps Bacchus was aid to be born out of his father's thigh, becaue he was born on the ide of ome mountain, not that of India. But I much rather believe this part of the Fable aroe from mitake of the originall word < in non-Latin alphabet > , femur, that is, the thigh, or the leg, which the Scripture ueth for a modet expreion of the place of generation, as Mr. Mede teacheth on Gen. 49. 10. where he interpreteth alo the words, [from between his feet] to ignifie his poterity. Gen. 46. 26. it is aid, All the ouls that came with Jacob into Egypt, which came out of his loins, &c. And Exod. 1. 5. All the ouls which came out of the loyns of Jacob. But in both places the Hebrew ignifieth thigh, as the Marginall Notes in our Bibles how And learned Bochartus aith, the Phoenician words, which properly ignifie the thigh, ignifie alo the generating parts. Thus Bacchus his proceeding from the thigh of Jupiter, according to the Orientall expreions, (from whence this Fable came) implieth no more, than that Bacchus was the on of Jupiter. Now I hall briefly conider their Rites, which will appear the ame with the worhip of Heroes and Daemons. Jupiter the on of Saturn or Noah was the ame that was named Baal or Belus, as Bochartus heweth, Geogr. acrae. pag. 189. Bell was the proper • h • ldaean word, Baal the Phoenician, as the mot learned Selden aith, Syntagm. de Baal & Belo; both which names (as he heweth) are promicuouly ued by Fl. Joephus. The ame illutrious Author proveth Baal to be Jupiter; and withall maketh it appear, that Baal was a generall name for all the gods of the Gentiles. And Belus might be taken for Heaven: and o perhaps the Altar which Manaeh raied to the hot of heaven was erected to Baal or Bell. Euebius de praepar. Evang l. 1. c. 10. aith, Beel-ames ignifieth the Lord of Heaven, who by the Greeks •• called < in non-Latin alphabet > , Jupiter. As the Altars of Baal which Joiah threw down
Were in high places, o Delrius in Senecam. Hercul. Oct. citeth a place of Herodotus, to prove that acrifices were performed on the Tops of high mountains. Omnis autem mons, aith he, Jovis mons dicitur, quoniam mos fuit antiquorum ut upreme Deorum in ublimi l • co acrificarent. This he citeth out of Melanthes, that every mountain was called th • mountain of Jupiter, becaue it was the cutom of the antients, to acrifice to the mot high God in an high place. Now as the Babylonian Bel, differed from the Phoenician Baal. or Bel, o Jupiter Hammon, from Jupiter Capitolinus, and others. St. Paul, 1
• or. 8. 5. aith, Sunt dii multi, & domini multi. Which Mr. Selden alloweth to be many Bels; or, as the Europaeans peak, many Joves. And thus the name of Belus; was conferred on many; But that-Baal or Jupiter who was the on of Noah or Saturn, was the firt we read of, th • t was worhipped; though the worhip of Ba • ls, was the worhip of Heroes or Daemons; To which we now decend. And that it may appear mot reaonable, to apply this worhip to the mot early perons, that we read of in the World; two things are to be thought on, 1. That the Devill no ooner fell from Heaven, but he began to act againt God: as we ee in his tempting of Eve, 2. That he found, all men would be apt to ado • e mot, what they knew here, and from which they received mot benefit; Whic • was the ol • reaon, that Plato and other Heath •• s give for the worhipping of Heroes. And in the time of Noah, there being none beides him and his ons to leave beneficiall directions for the ucceeding age, it is likely, that they were the firt, who, by the Devil's means, were worhipped as Heroes: To whoe worhip, the Daemons jo • ned their own. That their worhips were the ame, Cicero confirmeth, making Gods and Heroes all one Divas, & cos qui coelestes empe •• habiti, colunto; & illos quos in coelum merita vocaverint, that is Thoe Gods which have ever been in Heaven, are to be worhipped; and thoe alo, whom their deerts have called th • ther. And again, By death they came to be Gods; Apuleius alo, Et uperius aliud augutiu • que Daemonum genus, &c. There is, aith he, a more high and excellent kind of Daemons, which never were imprioned in bodies: And thee Pl • to be • ieved, were the directers of the minds of men. And Plato in his C • atylus, giveth the ame Title un o He • oes; affirming, that Heiod and other Poets, ay excellently well, that good men, when they die, attain great Honour and Dignity, becoming < in non-Latin alphabet > , wie ones. And in his de Republ. he would have all that die valiantly in the field, to be worhipped as Daemons, and all that <> any thing profit • ble for their Country; Cicero, alo in his
<> S •• p. maketh him ay, that all which died in the ervice
of their Country, be rewarded with Divinity: On which, ee Macrobius, lib. 1. c. 4. There are ome, that believe Serapis, whoe Idol had a Buhell on its head, was Joeph worhipped by the Aegyptians; Mr. Mede, in his Apotaie of the lat times, citeth Ph • lo Byblius, who in his Preface, to Sanchuntathon, the antient Phaenician Hitorian, aith, The Phoenicians and Aegyptians, account thoe as the greatet Gods, who had found out any thing profitable for the Life of man, or deerved well of any Nation. See Euebius, de praepar. Evang. l. 2. c. 6. about the middle; To thee alo, were Temples erected as well as to their Daemon-gods. Thu • ydides, lib. 2. aith, The Athenians, who after the Perian War, inhabited the Country, altering their reolutions, went to dwell in the City; but finding it not large enough to • eceive them, they filled alo the Temples and Chappels of the Heroes. Clemens Alex. in his Protrept. and Strom. giveth many the like intances, which I forbear to adde; Onely hewing, that the Daemons joyned their own worhip to that of Heroes, or deified men, as being the aptet coure to draw men from the worhip of the true God; Religion, in the infancy of the World, being mot confirmed by viibilities: Which way God himelf was pleaed to allow, and the Devils imitated. The worhip of thee Heroes, or Baalim, we find to have been wholly Tragicall, as Plutarch, de defectu oracu • or. decribeth it: ut collig • mus ex utrorumque acrificiis, orgiis & ritibus acrorum multa admixta funebria & lugubria cernentes. Now this was an expreion of orrow for the deceaed; which grew a part of the religion. Wherefore we read, Lev. 19. 28. Ye hall not make any cuttings in your fleh for the dead. So Lev. 21. 5. They hall not make baldnee on their heads, nor make any cuttings in their fleh. This cutting off hair, we find often an expreion of orrow among the antient Poets; And its being forbidden by God, is a plain Demontration, that it was part of the Idolatrous worhip of Daemons or Heroes. Yet ometimes it was ued onely, for an expreion of orrow, See Jer. 48. 37. To this effect, Saint Augutine de civ. dei. l. 6. c. 10. q • oteth a place of Seneca's, not extant in his works ••
• ut praefixed by Lipius in his Edition; who thus decribeth this ••• latious and Tragicall employment, Ille viriles ibi partes amputat, ille lacertos ecat. Se ipi in temp •• s contrucidant, vulneribus uis & anguine upplicant. An exacter decription, cannot be had of their cutting and lancing themelves, and making their wounds their upplications. This ad manner of worhip, we may plainly ee to be no other th ••
•• at of Baal or Jove, as it is expreed, 1 Kings 18 28. And th •• cried aloud, (that is, the Priets of Baal) and cut themelves after their manner
with knives and lancers, till the blood guhed out upon them. Thus have we een the worhip of of Baal or Jove; that is, Cham or Ham the on of Noah; Whoe ill mind, it is probable, was eaily enticed by Spirits, to caue himelf to be worhipped when dead. We hall find his on Bacchus to have had no other rites but thoe of his. I will not tand to dipute when Bacchus lived, whom Clemens Alex. lib 1. Strom. placeth after Moes. Neither will I et down the reaons of learned Voius, who aith he was Moes. This would be too large a field to walk over, and at this time not greatly to my purpoe. I will onely hew, that his worhip was the ame with that of Daemons or Heroes, as Baal's or Jove's was. Firt, it will not be amie to take notice, that Bacchus had the title of Heros given him, Plutarch Quaet. Graec. 36. His name BACCHUS ignifieth omething fu • ious. So he is alo called Maenoles, • b inania: of which, ee Euebius, Praep. Evang. l. 2 c 3. who expreeth it according to Clemens Alex. in Protreptico, where he applieth the word Evan, which when they kept their Bacchanalta, they ued to houl out, being crowned with Serpents, to the firt Serpent the Tempter, Et ignum Bacchicorum orgiorum est Serpens initiatus myteriis. And, by the way, this perhaps was the caue why in thee rites they ued to be crowned with Ivy: This, being always young and flourihing, is the hieroglyphick of the Serpent, who, by cating his skin, reneweth his youth. Bochartus heweth, how Bacchus his name commeth à luctu, from the funera • l rites and howlings ued in his worhip. But uch were not proper to Bacchus, but common to all Daemons or Heathen gods. Alexand. ab Alex. lib. 3. c. 12. Non animali victimâ, nec hotiâ, ed uo cruore acrificant. And perhaps thee ad ceremonies of wounding themelves, were by ome over-devout Zelots extended to human acrifices, which were offered to divers Heroes, and among them to Bacchus, as Clemens Alex. in Proireptico, reporteth from Doidas and others. Euebius Praep. Evang. l 4. c. 16. relateth the ame out of Porphyrius, where he mentioneth others beides Bacchus, to whom human acrifices were offered. The <> of his Priets we often met with, leaping and dancing on the <>
•• horus's. So Baal's Priets are decribed, 1 King. 18. 26. And •• y leapt upon the altar which was made. The Margin • ll Note, according to the Hebrew, is, They leapt up and down a (or about) the altar. The cries and wailings in the Bacchanalia were • o other, than the howls which accompanied thee ceremon •••
<> Ia. 15. 2. Moab hall howl over Nebo and over Medeba: on all th •
<…> hall be baldnee, and every beard cut off. And that the rites <> appear the ame in all things, we may ee the very cutting
and lanching, that is, the effuion of blood, mentioned in Baal's Worhip, to be alo performed in the Feats of Bacchus; as Statius intimateth, decribing the wandring Polynices, who leaveth
—Ogygiis ululata furoribus antra
Deerit, & pingues Baccheo anguine colles.
Thoe caves which furious rites with howlings fill,
And with Bacchean blood th'enriched hill.
Upon which, Lactantius aith, Citheronem ignificat, ubi e Bacchae ecant in honorem Liberi; that is, By the hill is meant Citheron, where the Bacchae, the Priets of Bacchus, cut themelves in honour of Liber, or Bacchus. Thus have I made it appear, that the worhip of Bacchus was exactly the ame with his father Jupiter's, and both no other than that of Heroes and Daemons. And herein was there an imitation of the worhippers of the true God, as may be gathered from Jer. 41. 5. There came certain men from Shechem, from Shiloh, and from Samaria, even fourcore men, having their beards haven, and their clothes rent, and having cut themelves, with offerings and incene in their hand, to bring them to the houe of the Lord. And becaue the Lord aw that this would be converted to Daemon-worhip it was therefore perhaps forbidden in the above. quoted places of Leviticus, and Deut. 14. 1.

254. Dóth not Sperchios.] A river in Thealie, to which Peleus promied his on Achilles his hairs, if he returned afe from the Trojan war. Maturantius aith, It was a cutom to offer the hair of Youths to the gods of Rivers, becaue moiture is the caue of encreae. But I read of no uch cutom. I have rather given an undertanding of this in the precedent Note, where I hewed, that the cutting off of hair was a acred ceremony, performed to Heroes or Daemons. And no River antiently being thought to be without a Deity, Peleus vowed the hairs of Achilles to Sperchios, that is, he promied he hould be worhipped by him with the performance of that Daemon-rite. And thee words of Achilles, which Homer Il. '. maketh Achilles peak over the body of his dear Patroclus, hew, that Peleus had built Temples to Sperchios.
< in non-Latin alphabet > ,
< in non-Latin alphabet > ,
< in non-Latin alphabet > ,
< in non-Latin alphabet >
< in non-Latin alphabet >
< in non-Latin alphabet > .
< in non-Latin alphabet > ,
< in non-Latin alphabet > .
< in non-Latin alphabet >
< in non-Latin alphabet > .
In vain, Sperchios, Peleus vow'd to thee
At my return to Greece thee Locks from me,
Beides a Hecatomb, hould then be paid,
And on thine altars fifty Weathers laid,
Near to thoe fountains where thy Temple's rais'd,
And odors on thy fragrant altars blaz'd.
So Peleus vow'd. But he's unatisfi • d.
And ince my Country I am now deni'd
For ever, thee hairs to the Stygian hade
In my Patroclus hand hall be convey'd.
This aid, in his friends hand his hair he pres'd,
Whilt every one affected grief expres'd.
Alexander ab Alexandro lib. 5. cap. 25. aith, This Ceremony was performed by the Delian Youths and Maids, over the Hyperborean Virgins, the Men laying their hair on the Sepulchers, the Virgins upon the Tombs. And lib. 3. cap. 7. that it was ued by the Barbarians, not onely in funerals, but in any great adverity; and that the Perians at funerals non tantum eipos ed & equos & jumenta tondebant: But, that the Romans and the Greeks were wont for expreing their grief, to let their hair grow, and onely their women to have theirs. Hence it appeareth, that the Antients thought it the greatet expreion of grief to take away thoe Ornaments, which they preerved in conditions of better atisfaction That which he aith of the Greeks, is to be undertood of the later Greeks, who, by letting their hair grow long, did expree an alteration from content: And becaue that could be no expreion in women, they till retained the old cutom of • utting off their hair. In thee later times, it hath been uuall to neglect our elves, when the World or Fortune have feemed unkind to us, letting our hair grow to rudenee and undecency, quitting vanity upon no other caue but misfortune, nor ceaing to care for our elves, till Fortune appear carelee of us.

30 •
•• cina] Juno and Lucina are taken for the ame, Macrob. Saturn. l. 1. c. 15. And Alexander ab Alex. lib. 6. c. 4. giveth Juno
the name of Lucina, and Opigena, quod parturientibus opem ferat. Therefore haply was he held the goddee of Mar • iage. Vi • g. Aen. 4. 59.
Junoni ante omnes, cui vinc'la jugalia curae.
—and Juno mot of all,
Propitious to the marriage-thrall.
And after, ver. 166.
—et pronuba Juno.
But the confuion of the names of the Heathen gods I will not here tand upon, having poken omething thereof el • where. The etymology of Lucina Ovid thus delivereth, Fator. l. 2.
—dedit haec tibi nomina Lucus;
Aut quia principium tu, dea, lucis habes.
Parce, precor, gravidis, facilis Lucina, puellis,
Maturumque utero molliter aufer onus.
From acred groves they thee Lucina call;
Or ele becaue thou givet light to all.
Spare, kindet goddee, every teeming Maid,
And gently too their fruitfull wombs unlade.
Mr. Selden Syntagm. de Atoreth, condemneth thoe who eek the etymology of < in non-Latin alphabet > , that is, Lucina, from the Greek; and he deriveth it from the Arabick word Alileth, which ignifieth Night. The Hebrews alo from Lailah, that is, Night, called this goddee Lilith, which may be rendred Noctiluca, or Nocturnus daemon. To keep this Daemon away from women in travell, the Jews at this day are wont to write this charm on the walls of the chambers where they are, ADAM, CHAVAH, CHUTZ, LILITH; Be far hence, Lilith. Perhaps the Moon was adored by women in that condition, by reaon that it maketh their labours eaier when it is at the full. Ier. 7. 18. he is called the Queen of heaven: The women knead their dough to make cakes to the Queen of heaven. Some tetimony of that cutom remaineth in thee days, cakes being till commonly made at uch times, and the children themelves being called by the name of Cake-bread.

argument.head: The Argument.
argument.l: The Grecians at the lat Achilles find,
Who is betray'd to what the fates deign'd.
Fair Deidamia mourns her Love with tears;
Whoe theft had more of joy, though more of fears.

lg.l: ULyes now through the Aegean eas
Chang'd, as he pas'd, the cattered Cyclades.
Olearos and Paros hid, they by
Lomnos next ail, and leen as they flye
The Ile of Naxos: Samos bigger grew,
And Delos made the Ocean lee in view.
Here they with offerings did the God implore,
For to confirm what Calchas told before.
Apollo heard. From Cynthus-top kind gales
Ended their doubts, and tretch'd their welling ails.
Their hip in afety rode. For Jove forbid
Thetis to trive to hinder what Fate did;
Who griev'd he could not, being o confin'd,
On loath'd Ulyes throw waves well'd with wind.
Now Phoebus near his journeye's end arrives,
And to the waves his weating Hores drives,
When Scyros hew'd. Ulyes bids them all
Furl up their ails, (At his Command they fall)
And with united trength to reach the hores:
The inking wind, the Youths upply with Oars.
Now all perceiv'd that Scyros they had found,
And aw the hore with Pallas Temple crown'd.
Leaving their Ship, the Heroes went on hore,
And there the kind Tritonia they adore:
When wie Ulyes, l • t the City might
At ight of all his Troup receive affright,
Commands them all within the hip to tay,
Whilt they alone attempt the rocky way.
But Abas, that kept watch, had told before
Of trangers, though all Grecians, on the hore.
Like Wolves the Heroes went, who although prone
To eae their young ones hunger, and their owne.
Yet on they lily creep, diembling want,
Let dogs hould make their Maters vigilant;
• o low, they took the nearet way that bent
Towards the gates, dicouring as they went.
Tydides firt began; How we hould find

l.hi: This truth, is alway running in my mind.
Why were thee Thyri and thee Timbrels bought?
Why Mitres, Drums, and gilded Stags-skins brought
Hither with us? Mut thee oft things employ,

lg.l: And arm Achilles for the War of Troy?
To him Ulyes miling aid, To thee
Let this uffice: If that Achilles be

l.hi: Under a V • rgin's habit here conceal'd,
By thee fond Toyes, thou 'lt ee the Youth reveal'd.
In thee attempts let this alone be thine,
To bring the things when't is a fitting time.
And joyn to thee the fairest painted hield,
On which the Gold doth radiant lutre yield.

lg.l: This hall uffice. But let Agyrtes too

l.hi: His Trumpet bring, to help what we must do.

lg.l: Then eeing to the Gates the King was come,
Shewing an Olive branch, he thus begun.

l.hi: I do believe that Fame hath fill'd your ears,

lg.l: Bet Prince, with Europe's and with Aia's fears,

l.hi: Preparing war. If you our names would know,

lg.l: On whom great Agamemnon did betow
This trut, Hee's Diomed, who hath giv'n Fame
The bravet tales; Ulyes is my name.

l.hi: To tell the caue I come I need not fear,
Since you're a Greek, in friendhip tooo clear,
Tis that in afety we may still employ

lg.l: Our hips this way againt injurious Troy;
The King thus tops his peech, May ye still find

l.hi: In all ye do the Gods and Fortune kind.
But now let me be honour'd by your tay

lg.l: Within my Court. This aid, he leads the way.
The Tables traight were pread, the Beds laid out,
In the mean time Ulyes ought about
If any Virgin, of too large a ize,
Might give upition to his doubting eyes,
Thus roam'd he round the houe. So every way
Through fields the Huntman his undoubted prey,
Trails with Moloian hounds, till in the hade
He finds the Beat, his head on cool Turfs laid.
By this the news was to the Virgins got,
How that a Ship had Grecian Princes brought.
They all expree their exes fears, beides
Aeacides, who carce his new joy hides,
Greedy to ee the Greeks. The room with guets
Was fill'd, who on rich Beds receiv'd their feats.
The Princees came, ent for by the King,
Like thoe fair Amazonians that did bring
Their Troph • ys with them by Maeotis, round
With Scythian and with Getan conquets crown'd,
(Whoe ruin'd walls in their own ahes lie)
Now eated at their feats, their Armes laid by.
Then traight Ulyes with his buie eyes
Oberv'd them all. But night, that great diguie,
Deni'd the Heros hould be quite reveal'd,
Whom lying on the bed the boord conceal'd;
Yet To Diomed. to his friend, he hew'd his wandering eye,
How unconfin'd by Laws of modety.
For had not kind Deidamia's care compell'd
His temper, and his arms from moving held,
And with his veil, his mighty houlders hid,
And naked breat, the full bowls too forbid.
And on his head, ettled his tottering Crown,
Achilles then had to the Greeks been known.
Three coures now had atiated their ouls,
When thus, inviting them to crowned bowls,
The King began, The glory of your deeds,

l.hi: I do confee, in my breat envy breeds.
I wih I were now with that Youth inflam'd,
Wherewith the Dolopes on thee hores I tam'd:
As tokens of which victory, their torn
And hattered hips do till our walls adorn.
Had but kind Nature, made my children men,
To erve you now, my joyes had perfect been.
You ee old age's witnee on mine head,
And thee oft pledges of my marriage-bed,
When hall the wih'd-for iues from thee come?

lg.l: Ulyes catching at thee words begun.

l.hi: Thy wih is jut. For who would not have fled
To ee uch warms, by troops of Princes led?

lg.l: Th' united trength, that Europe now affords

l.hi: All worn to jut revenge upon their words.
Cities are empti'd, mountains naked how,
Sails without number on the Oceanthrow
A darkning hade: Fathers deliver arms
To the inflamed Youths, who ruh in warms.
Fame for attempting-pirits ne're did yield
So fair an object in o jut a field;

lg.l: Whilt thus he pake, he aw how the Youth's ears
Drank up his words, the ret expreing fears:
Then thus proceeds, Who'ere proud in the name

l.hi: Of Ancetors, or in his Nation's fame,
Who manageth his Hore, or ele can throw
His dart with fatall aim, or ue his bow;
Here all their aemulating deeds are paid,
Virgins and fearfull women carce are staid.
But that baewretch, who this brave action fears,
Hated by Heav'n, hall pend his fruitlee years.

lg.l: At this how the Youth mov'd, Deidamia's eyes
Soon found, and gave her iters ignes to rie,
Leading him forth. Yet he departed lat,
And till his eyes upon Ulyes cat.
Who having paus'd a little, thus again
Aum'd his p • ech, May you, bet King, remain

l.hi: In peace, providing marriage-beds for thee,
Wh • e heav'nly beauties equall Deities.
How much their looks amaz • , in which doth hine
Mingled with beauty omething maculine!

lg.l: The King replies, If now their looks invites,

l.hi: What would it do at Bacchanalian rites,

lg.l: Or circling Pallas hrines? This hall appear,

l.hi: If the kind croing winds detain you here;

lg.l: At this new hope, their ilent wihes bles'd,
With hate accepting it. The Court in ret
Was now laid free from cares; only the night
To wie Ulyes eem'd too low of flight.
The morning carce appear'd, when Diomed,
Bringing the gifts, with him Agyrtes led;
The Scyrian Virgins too roe with the day,
Unto their guets the promis'd rites to pay.
Before the ret, Achilles with the Queen
Appears. Pallas and Cynthia o were • en,
With the Elyian King's lov'd Proferpine,
By Aetna's rocks among the Nymphs to hine.
Now they began to move in meaur'd time,
And from th' Imenian pipe they took the igne.
Four times the troakes on Rhea's brae rebound,
As many times the Evian Timbrels ound.
Four times their meaures chang'd: at once they threw
Their pears all up, which fell together too.
Now they like the Curetes all advance,
Then they preent the Samothracian dance:
Now all do ide like Amazons, then all
Into Lacaenian circling figures fall.
Achilles now mot plain appears, and tands
Neglecting the jut time of joyning hands,
Scorns the oft meaures, and to be o dres'd,
Forgets his part, diturbing all the ret.
Afflicted Thebes aw Pentheus thus depie
His mother's tymbrels and the acrifice.
The praied Chorus from their acred port
Were now dimis'd, and all return'd to th' Court:
Whither the gifts Tydides had convey'd,
And all before their eyes in order laid.
With thee they eem their welcome to requite,
And every one unto her choice invite.
The King conents, too innocent to find
The Greeks, and what Ulyes had deign'd.
They (by their nature to uch choice apply'd)
The Thyrus took, or ele the Tymbrell tri'd,
Or Jewels choe. The hining Arms they view,
And thought them preents for their father too.
But fierce Aeacides, till kept his ight
Upon the Shield, as if prepar'd to fight.
His face with fiery bluhes grew inflam'd;
Then to the warlike pear his eyes were chain'd.
His brows in furrows knit, his taring hairs
Grew tiffe, and he forgat his Mothers cares.
With his owne Love: Nothing durt then employ
His high-erected thoughts but War and Troy.
So from the teat, when a young Lion's brought,
And againt nature an obedience taught,
Nor is an anger of his own expres'd:
But if the hining teel threaten his breat,
His faith then flies; he makes his Lord his prey,
Scorning a fearfull Mater to obey.
But when he nearer came, and in the bright-
Reflecting hield, aw the contemned ight
How he was cloth'd, then his fierce looks proclaim
In his inflamed bluhes rage and hame.
Then lie Ulyes coming to him, aid
With a low voice, Why are we thus delay'd?

l.hi: We know where thou wert bred, how thou dost pring
Both from the Ocean's God and Heaven's King.
For thee the Grecians doubting-Army cal • s,

lg.l: And at thy name Troy hakes her nodding walls.

l.hi: Let Ida hrink, and pleae thy Fathers ears,
Who bluheth at thy crafty Mother's fears;

lg.l: At this, his garments from his breat were cat,

l.hi: Agyrtes

lg.l: Throwing their gifts away, the Virgins run
For helter, and believ'd a War begun.
His robes untouch'd, fell down at the alarm,
Snatching the pear and hield upon his arm.
He taller far then Ithacus appears,
Or Diomedes. Swift dipering fears,
Fill the affrighted Court, whilt in his gate
He eem'd now eeking to be Hector's fate.
The fair troup the Peleian Virgin eeks,
At whoe dicovery Deidamia hreeks.
Whoe well known voice, no ooner fill'd his breat,
But Love began to plead his interet.
His hield unk down, and on the King his eyes
Fixing, amaz'd at all thee prodigies,
He till thus arm'd to Lycomedes aid,

l.hi: 'Tis I, dear Father, (be not now afraid)
Whom the immortall Thetis bore. To you
This glory to oblige the Greeks is due,

lg.l: In giving them Achilles. Thou halt be

l.hi: (If it be jut to ay) dearer to me
Then Peleus or lov'd Chiron. Yet attend
Thee words with kindnee, and attention lend:
Peleus and Thetis adde a child to thee
By either ide • rung from a Deity.
They do require one of thee Virgins here.
Dot thou agree? or ele do I appear
Degenerate from them? Our hands then joyn
With free conent, and pardon thoe are thine,

lg.l: With thy Deidamia's rape. Who can retrain

l.hi: Thee limbs attempting to appeae their flame?
If thou 'lt revenge, to me it • s onely due,
See how I wait it thus unarmed too.
Why do thy angry eyes o madly run?

lg.l: Thou art a Father-in-law. Then throws his on
Before his feet, and then again proceeds,

l.hi: By this a Grand-father. New rigour needs

lg.l: More then uch troups to punih. Th' Greeks with him
Joyn all their reaons to appeae the King.
He with his daughter's injury though pres'd,
And with the words of Thetis till poes'd,
And loth to break his trut, yet fears to tay
The Grecian War, and Fate's deigns delay.
His Mother now, if there, in vain might ue
Her power: Nor could he uch a on refue.
Thus he was vanquih'd; When yet full of fears
The fair Deidamia, bluhing till, appears;
She could not think her Father yet was made
So kind, the crime upon Achilles laid.
The news of all to Thealy he convaid,
And to his friends and ubjects ends for aid.
The King for his new Son, two hips prepares,
And blames his power hort for uch affairs.
The day was pent in feats; the Lovers ty'd
In Hymen's knot: The gentle night comply'd
Now to their bold embraces. He in dreams
Fancy's the war, Xanthus and Ida's treams.
The Grecian hips; whilt unto her a fright
The thought of waves did give, or morning's light.
About her Lovers neck her arms he pred,
And mingled with her tears thee words he hed.

l.hi: Shall I e're ee thee more, and thus remain?
May we be worth thy viit once again?

lg.l: Will not Troy's ruine, your wel'd mind forbid

l.hi: To think where you were like a Virgin hid?
Ought I to beg, or onely to have fears?
Should I ue words, that carce have time for tears?
Is this our nuptiall bed's deigned right,
To be betow'd and ravih'd in one night?
Is this free Hymen? O thou kinder theft!
What we have leave to love, must thus be left.
Go, go: I dare not ask thee to remain,

lg.l: Go then; Yet think not Thetis fear'd in vain.

l.hi: Go, and return again to me, but mine
I wih too much. Thoe charming eyes of thine,

lg.l: Will give uch paion to Troy's beauteous Dames,

l.hi: They they'l forget their Country's for thy flames.
Perhaps on Helena, thou'lt be inflam'd,
Whoe beauty by her rape is o much fam'd;
Whilt I hall ne're be mention'd to be thine,
Or made the ubject of thy youthfull crime.
But yet, why hould not I till go with thee,
And bear thine enigne? Thou hat born with me

lg.l: The ditaff, and the arms of Bacchus too;
Which Troy will hardly credit you did do.

l.hi: Your Image though, the comfort of my breat,
Never forget; nor yet this one requet.
Let not a barbarous Love enjoy my place,

lg.l: And bring to Thetis an unworthy race;
This aid, the haken Youth comforts her fears,
Swears her his faith, and eals it with his tears:
And promieth he hould alone enjoy
The Captives, and the wealth of ruin'd Troy.
His fruitlee words thus trove to eae her care,
And his vain promie lot it elf in air.

div.head: ANNOTATIONS on the IV Book of STATIUS his ACHILLEIS.
div.p: 3. PAros.] One of the Cyclades, famous for clear Marble.

5. Nax • s.] Another of the Cyclades, acred to Bacchus, who is aid to have been here nourihed. Here, they ay, Ariadne was married to Bacchus, haply becaue being here foraken by ungratefull Theeus, he here found a remedy, at leat an end of her mieries. Bacchus, from his eaing of cares, received the names of Liber and Lyaeus, and from his pitty, of Eleleus, from < in non-Latin alphabet > , Miericordia. But this I conceive rather commeth from < in non-Latin alphabet > , clamo, and hath relation to his rites.

Samos.] An • land famous for the birth of Pythagoras. There be three Ilands of this name: One but a little ditant from the Continent of Aia, an • onick Iland, having a City of the ame name, Strab. lib. 14. Here Juno lived whilt a Virgin: whence the Iland was called Parth • nia. Another, not far from the Bay of Ambracia. The third, in the Aegean ea, over againt the mouth of the Thracian River Hebrus, Plin. lib. 4. This is here meant.

24. Kind Tritonia.] Pallas was ever kind to the Grecians, and the Trojans enemy. So Ovid, Aequa Venus Teucris, Pallas iniqua fuit. And Virgil Aen. 1. aith, that among other Pictures that Aeneas aw at Carthage, one was of Trojan women going to the Temple, non-aequae Palladis, of unjut, or ungentle, Pallas. And Aen. 2.
Omnis pes Danaûm, & coepti fiducia belli,
Palladis auxiliis emper • etit.
All the Greeks hopes and co • fidence which choe
Th'attempted war, from Pallas helps aroe.
Her particular kindnes to Diomedes Homer heweth, Iliad 5. Servius in Aen. 2. aith, he was called Tritonia,
< in non-Latin alphabet > , to fear; Pallas being commonly repreented terrible with her Snakes. Or ele he was called o, in relation to the three concerns of Widom, Memory of things pat, Judgment in things preent, and Providence for things to come. Or he had this name from a River, as Lucan there cited, Ete dilectâ Tritonida dixit ab unda. She was called Trigemina by the Aegyptians, Alexand. ab Alex. l. 6. c. 4. the ame perhaps with < in non-Latin alphabet > , and < in non-Latin alphabet > , from < in non-Latin alphabet > . which in the Cretian Language ignifieth a Head.
85 Maeotis.] A Lake of Scythia, receiving the River Tanais, with many others, and divided from the Euxine Sea by the Cimmerian Bophorus.

86. With Scythian and with Getan conquets.] Scythia was divided into two parts, the European, and the Aiatick. The European from the banks of Tana's, by the hores of Maeotis, and the Euxine Sea, reacheth to the mouth of Iter. The Aiatick from the oppoite hore extendeth to the Eat, and is bounded by the Ocean on the North, and by the mountain Taurus on the South. The Getae were a People of Scythia Europaea, called Dacians, as Britannicus affi • me • h, and Plinie l 4 c. 12. But Strabo lib. 7. placeth the Getans towards Pontus and the Eat, but the Dacians towards Germany. The G • tae were famous, or rather infamous, for cruelty. So Ovid, Nulla Getis toto gens et truculentior orbe. One of their cruell cutoms was, to kill the wife, that by her death they might appeae the ghot of the husband, Alex. ab Alex. lib. y. c. 26.

102. Inviting them to crowned bowls.] It was a cutom oberved by the Antients, epecially at their Entertainments, to drink freely after their feats, Virg. Aen. 1.
Postquam prima quies epulis, men • que remotae,
Crater as magnos ta • uunt, & vina co • enant.
The firt Feat ended, on the tables hine
The weighty bowls, crown'd till with parkling wine.
At the beginning, mall glaes went about, but at the end they enlarged their draughts, Alex. ab Alex. lib. 5. cap. 21. The Greeks had a Law, ut biberent, aut abirent. How Anacreon liked this cutom of drinking, appeareth from this Ode of his concerning himelf, H. Stephano interprete.

q.l: t me ubit Lyaeus,
Tune cura dormit omnis,
Croeumque perno prae me.
Dulcis repente notro
Erumpit ore cantus:
Hederâ comaque cingens
Proculco mente cuncta.
Ad arma currat alter,
Ad pocula ipe curram.
Puer, ocyùs cyphum da:
Nam praetat ebrium me
Quàm mortuum jacere.
When powerfull Bacchus rules my breat,
Then I am from all cares releas'd:
Scorn'd Croeus too eems poor to me,
Whilt charming Lays take liberty
Through my melodious lips, and round
My brows with winding lvy crown'd,
Contemning all things in my mind.
Some are for war and arms deign'd;
But the crown'd bowls do fill my head:
'Tis better to lie drunck than dead.

div.p: 106. The Dolopes] A People on the borders of Thealie, overcome, as it eemeth, by Lycomedes in a Sea-battle. See Servius in Aen. 2. ver. 7.

162. Imenian pipe.] Imenus is a River of Boeotia, not far from Aulis, where the Greeks made their great Rendez-vous. In this Country tood Thebes, where Bacchus was much worhipped: For which City, Statius here putteth the River Imenus. A liberty frequently taken by the Poets. So Achaia and Pelagia, being but Regions of Greece, are commonly put for Greece it elf. There is alo a Hill of this name by Thebes, whence Apollo was called Imsnius. Plutarch in Pericle peaketh of a Trumpeter of this name, of whom Antithenes, Si probus eset, tibicen non eet.

163. Rhea's Brae.] Rhea was held the mother of the gods; Who had divers other names et down by Alexander ab Alexandro lib. 6. c. 4. She was Saturn's wife, and taken for the Earth: The reaon whereof ee on Book III. ver. 220. Alexander ab Alex. lib. 3. c. 12. aith, A Sow, which was called Praecidanea, was offered to Ceres, or Rhea, becaue (as ome conceive) a Sow, being a fruitfull creature, was thought a fit Preent for the Earth, which was undertood by Ceres. But I rather chue the reaon of Servius in Georg. 2. where he oberveth, that the acrifices to the gods were all performed, either by imilitudes or contrarieties: By Similitude, as a black Beat to Pluto: By Contraries, as a Sow to Ceres, becaue an enemy to Fruits; a Goat to Bacchus, becaue an enemy to Vines. This Agellius l 4. c. 6. eems to confirm, where explaining the word Praecidanea, he addeth, Porca etiam Praecidanea appellata, quam piacul • gratiâ ante fruges novas captas immolari Cereri mos fuit; that is, A Sow was called Praecidanea, or a preceding acrifice, by reaon that it was a cutom to offer one to Ceres before harvet. Rhea was commonly repreented with Towers upon her head, and drawn by Lions. And hereby the Earth is ignified. Which Macrobius Saturn. l. 1. c. 21. affirming, addeth alo, Haec dea Leonibus vehitur, validis impetu atque fervore animalibus. Quae natura Coeli et, cujus ambit • Aer continetur, qui vehit terram; that is, This goddee is drawn by Lions, creatures of great trength force and fervour: Which is the nature of the Heaven, in whoe compas the Aire is contained, which carrieth the Earth. On which words Pontanus citeth thee Veres of Lucretius;
Hanc veteres Graiûm docti cecinêre Poetae
Sublimem in curru bijuges agitare Leones,
Aeris in patio magnam pendere docentes
Tellurem; neque poe in terra itere terram.
The learn'd and antient Grecian Poets ung,
This goddee was by Lions drawn along;
Teaching that round the reting Earth is laid
In Aire: for Earth by Earth could not be taid.
A Philoophy contrary to that which is now received. This goddee's Priets were called Galli, from Gallus, a River of Phrygia; and Corybantes, which ome derive from < in non-Latin alphabet > , which ignifieth to to • e the head in any violent motion: Which frantick action they ued in their mad ceremonies. But Turnebus Adver. lib. 13. c. 24. undertandeth
the word otherwie. Their rites et down by Clemens Alexandrinus Protrept. and repeated by Euebius, de Praepar. Evang. l. 2. c. 3. little differed from thoe of Bacchus, altered onely by the fancy and interet of everall people And all the worhip that we read to have been performed to everall gods, was no other, than that which from the beginning of the world was taught by Daemons.

175. Afflicted Thebes aw Pentheus.] Pentheus was killed by his zelous mother Agave, and other frantick women, for contemning their Bacchanalia. Natalis Comes, lib. 5. cap. 13. thinketh Pentheus was ome jut and temperate Prince, who triving to uppree thoe rude ceremonies, was murdered by his dipleaed ubjects.

argument.head: The Argument.
argument.l: For fatall Troy Aeacides now goes:
And as they ail, he from Ulyes knows
The wars originall; which having known,
Deir'd, he payes the tory with his own.

lg.l: NIght's hadowes now began to flye away,
When from the waves, the Ruler of the day
Began to pread the promies of light,
Yet injur'd by the trugling hades of night.
When now Aeacides, (his oft robes corn'd)
Appears in his firt courted arms adorn'd.
For now the winds invited. Now no more
Durt they remember how he liv'd before.
So chang'd, as if he were not now the ame
That liv'd in Scyros, but from Pelion came.
Then, as they us'd, Ulyes did advie
To offer to the Ocean Deities.
To Neptune on the flames a bull was laid,
To Thetis an adorned heifer paid.
Achilles having then the entrails flung
Into the briny waves, he thus begun.

l.hi: I have obey'd thee, Mother, though't was uch
A hard command: I have obey'd too much.
Now with the Greeks, I go fam'd Troy to find,

lg.l: This aid, into a nip he leapt. The wind
Drove them from hore: the clouds till thicker grew,
And Scyros leen'd to their hindred view.
The whilt Deidamia on a Tower appears,
Accompany'd with her ad Siters tears,
Holding young Pyrrhus. Still the waves he view'd,
And that which bore him with fond eyes puru'd.
He too his looks ends to th' affected walls
And widow'd houe; then with a igh recalls
What he had left: His fire burns again,
And his great thoughts give way unto his flame.
Ulyes gues'd his paion by his grief,
And ought by this diverion his relief;

l.hi: Wert thou, (to whom the fate of Troy is due,
Whom Oracles and Grecians call for too
And war within the open threhold tay'd)
Dres'd by thy crafty Mother like a maid?
Could he herelf to all be o unjut,
To act uch theft, and yet expect a trut?
Her fears were much too great in all he did,
Should o much virtue in a hade be hid.
Which at the Trumpet's ummons, freed thy breat
From thought of friends, and thy lov'd flames uppres'd?
Nor is this glory to our elves aign'd,
To bring thee now: It was above deign'd.

lg.l: Aeacides reply'd, Too long't would be

l.hi: To tell my Mothers crimes. This word for me,
And my diguie hall at a handome rate,
Plead and excue, though't were the guilt of Fate.

lg.l: You rather, whilt ot Zephyrus conpires

l.hi: With the mooth Ocean calm'd to our deires,
Relate, why Greece thus for revenge prepares,
That my reent may be as jut as theirs.

lg.l: Slie Ithacus repli'd, If that we may

l.hi: Give credit to the tales of Fame, they ay;
Once on th' Hectorean hore, three goodly fair
Dienting Goddees had equall care.
