For their diputed beauties: And all three
Agree'd the Trojan Swain, their Judge hould be.

lg.l: Sowre Pallas pleas'd not his deciding eyes,

l.hi: Nor the immortall Mitree of the skies:

lg.l: Onely fair Venus looks his mind inclin'd,

l.hi: This trife aroe when firt the Gods deign'd

lg.l: Peleus for Thetis, and their happy eed,

l.hi: Thy glorious elf, was for our aid decreed.
The vanquih'd Goddees hid paion fires:
The Judge his fatall recompene requires;
Straight ees in Sparta his admired Love;
Then fells the holy hades, and Cybele's grove
Falls on the earth, and the forbidden Pine,
Though acred, mut ait his foul deigne.
His hips, now built, do through the Ocean pae
To the Achaian hore. His crime, alas!

lg.l: The injury on potent Europe leaves,

l.hi: Which first the tained marriage-bed receives

lg.l: Of Menelaus, when he his ravih't joy,
Helen, with captive Argos bears to Troy.

l.hi: The news through every City Rumour flung,
And to their arms the willing Grecians throng.
For who can bear at o unjut a rate,
Stains on a marriage-bed, with uch deceit?
Plunder of grain, or cattell, caue affords
To men of valour, to employ their words.

lg.l: Agenor brook'd not uch a rape, when Jove

l.hi: Had through the waves born his affected Love;

lg.l: But ought Europa, when the fact was done,

l.hi: Scorning the God of Thunder for his on.

lg.l: Aeetes o follow'd his child's ecape,

l.hi: Though Semi-gods were guilty of the rape;
Yet he puru'd the ravihers with War,
And that fam'd hip, in Heaven now a Star.
Shall we endure thee Phrygians, but half-men
Seeking upon our hores their plunders then?
Are we grown bankrupt and unarmed thus?
Or will the waves be leer friends to us?
What now, if from the Scyrian hores hould flie

lg.l: Unto thine ears, thy lov'd Deidamia's cry,

l.hi: Ravih'd by ome, and calling on thy name?

lg.l: With that unto his word his fingers came,
And 's face with angry bluhes grew enflam'd,
Ulyes then in ilence pleas'd remain'd.
Then Diomede ucceeding him begun,

l.hi: Thou worthy Iue from a Godhead prung,
Tell thy admiring friends, from thy firt age,
What practice did thy youthfull thoughts engage;

lg.l: The wayes to virtue taught by Chiron too,

l.hi: And how thy limbs and mind enlarged grew.
Let this requite our eeking Scyros hores,
Through tedious waves, and plying of the Oars:
You need not be aham'd to tell your deeds.

lg.l: At this he bluhing, as compell'd, proceeds;

l.hi: When Chiron firt receiv'd me to his cave,
The food which to my tender years he gave,
I 've heard was much unus'd. For from the breat
My hunger with oft milk was ne're uppres'd,
But with firm fleh of Lions; and I uck'd
The marrow from wild Beats yet-dying pluck'd.

lg.l: This was my firt chear: Chiron bred me o,

l.hi: Till Time with larger tricles taught me to go.
He led me then to th' Woods, without amaze,
Teaching mine eyes upon wild beats to gaze,
And not to fear the noie which billows made
On Rocks, nor th' horrid ilence of a hade.
I now a quiver got, and with a pear
To arm my youthfull hand was all my care.
As unconcern'd, I uffer'd the extreams,
Of binding cold and Sol's reflecting beams.
My tired limbs, a oft bed never pres'd:
I with my Mater on atone took ret.
When now almot to twice ix years I came,
He taught me to purue the wiftet game.
And the fierce Lapithae; and when I threw
My darts, to overtake them. Sometimes too,

lg.l: Chiron would follow me through fields and plains,

l.hi: Till age deni'd; and tired with my pains,
Would lay me on his neck. He made me bold
To pae the frozen Rivers bound with cold.
Thee were my youthfull ports. Why hould I need
To tell my warres, i' th' woods from roars now freed?
He taught me, not to hunt thoe beasts whoe fear
Urg'd their wift flight, the Lynx, and fallow Deer;
But force the Bear to her affrighting roars,
The cruell Tigres, and the foming Boars.
Or from the mountains fetch the Lions young;
Whilt in his cave he look'd to ee me come
Bloody; Nor took me in his arms before
He aw my pear colour'd with bluhing gone.

lg.l: And now my Age, and Chiron, did deigne

l.hi: My arms for nobler Wars. All dicipline
Of Mars I us'd. I practic'd how to throw
The Macedonian pile: I learnt to know
The ue, as Sauromatians do, of pears;
Or Getans, of their crooked emitars:
And how the fam'd Gelonians ue the bow,
And how the Balearian lingers throw
With ounerring aims the circling lings,
Which wound as ure and oft as motion flings.
I carce remember all. I learn'd the art
To leap vat dikes, whoe banks were far apart;
And the high tops of airy hills to gain,
To get me breath and wiftnee for the plain.
Then, the true image of a fight to yield,
He made me take huge miltones on my hield;
To enter burning hovells, and with force
And peed, to tay wift Hores in their coure.
Once I remember, how diolved now,
And contant howres had well'd Sperchios o,
That with its furious tream it drove a throng
Of torn-up Trees, and rowling tones-along:
Then where the waves, the horrid't force expres'd,
He bad me to oppoe my youthfull breat,
And top the welling billows as they run;
Which he with all his feet could carce have done.
Nor could th' impetuous tream a conquet gain,

lg.l: Whilt Chiron threatned, urging till my hame.

l.hi: Thus glory I attain'd by his command,
Who till a witnee of my toils did tand.
To fight with arm'd fits, and th' Oebalian tone
To throw and wretle with oil'd limbs, alone
Were ports, nor eem'd more toils then when
I took my harp, and ung of famous men.
He taught me too, which herbs for health were good,
And which would top effuion of much blood.
Which would cloe wounds, and which procure kind ret,
How gangrain'd parts to ever from the ret.
What ulcers herbs would care. He alo taught
Still to make Jutice guide of every thought.
Thus the Thealians he made happy till,
And thus he wrought his Centaurs to his will.
Y • ave heard, my friends, thoe acts that did employ
My early years: Thee I recount with joy.

lg.l: The ret my Mother knows. Thus he gave o're

l.hi: His tale, and came unto the Trojanhore.

div.head: ANNOTATIONS on the 5th Book of STA • IS his ACHILLEIS.
div.p:
13. A Bull.] This was the uuall acrifice to Neptune. Yet Ovid, Metam. 4. when Andromeda was freed, aith, A Bull was offered to Jupiter. And Silius Italicus, lib. 15.
—cadit ardua Taur • s
ictima, Neptuno pariter, pariterque Tonanti.
And Virgil, Aen. 3. Caelicolûm Regi mactabim in littore Taurum.
—upon the hore
To Heaven's King a Bull I lew—
On which place Servius aith, that Aeneas did this contrary to reaon, in relation to the event, a Bull being the acrifice of Neptune; reembling the roughnee of the waves, and the nature of Neptune, and other Sea-gods, as ungentle as the waves that bred them: as Agellius l. 15. c. 2. Ferociimos & immanes & alienos ab omni humanitate Neptuni filios dixerunt; that is, Neptune's ons were aid to be mot fierce and ungentle, and strangers to all humanity. See Macrobius, l. 3. c. 10.
15, 16. Having then the entralls flung Into the briny waves] This manner of throwing the entralls into the Sea, when acrifice was performed to the Sea-gods, Virgil etteth down, Aen. 5.

q.l: Dii quibus imperium pelági, quorum • quora curro,
Vob is laetus ego hoe candentem in littore taurum
Contituam ante aras voti re • s, exteq • e alos
Porriciam in fluctus.
You gods whoe empire in the Ocean lies,
Over whoe waves I ail; this acri •• ce,
A <> Bull as due to you I pay—
And in the briny waves the entralls lay.

div.p: For in a acrifices the entralls were a thief part of the ledication; as Juvenal, Sat. 10.

q.l: Ut tamen & pocas • liquid, voveaqae • c • llis
Ext • , & candid ••• divi • a t • macul • p • rci.
That thou mait omething wih, and at the hrine
Offer the acred entralls of white Swine.

div.p:
This ceremony of throwing the entralls into the Sea, was, becaue Neptune, to whom the acrifice was offered, there reigned. Suetonius in Auguto hath thee words,
• uneiata repentè hotis incur •• one, <>
•• pta faco proacuit; alque it a praelium ingreus, victor rediit; that is, Hearing of the incurion of the enemy, he cut off the entralls half-raw, natched from the fire; and o going cut to Battle he returned victorious. On which words, Salmaius, Partem extorum proecandam & Diis porriciendam arae uper-impo • ebant & diis adolehant; They laid that part of the entralls on the Altar that was to be cut off, and acrificed it to the gods. Reliquam partem vecebantur qui acrificio intererant. The ret was eaten by uch as were preent at the acrifice. All the actions about the entralls, looking into them and examining them laying, them on the Altar, eating what is to be eaten, Arrianus comprieth under this one Verb < in non-Latin alphabet > . This cutom, among others, which in the Notes I have given hort hints of, was taken up by the Heathen in imitation of the true God's worhip as will appear from Levit 1. 9, 13. The inwards and the legs hall he wah in water, and the Priet hall burn all on the Altar. Of the Priets eating part of the acrifice, • e Levit. 2. 3. 10 and 6 26. Ecclus 7. 31. Likewie the baked and broiled meats ave • e the Priets, Lev. 7 9. Here imita • ed by the word emicruda. And we read but of few
ceremonies among the antient Gentiles, that had not uch a beginning.

35. War within the open threhold tai'd.] The Poet meaneth the Temple of Janus, which in Peace was ever hut, and open in War. From Janus the gates of any private houe were called Januae. The gates of Janus were hut but twice before the time of Augutus. Janum Quirinum emel atque iterum a condita Vrbe memorium ante uam clauum, in multò breviore temporis patio, terrâ marique pace partâ, ter cluit, aith Suetonius, in Auguto, c. 22. That is, The Temple of Janus, from the beginning of the City, was but twice hut before the reign of Augutus; but in his reign, in a much leer pace, he being at peace with all the world, it was thrice hut. The firt time it was hut was in the reign of Numa Pompilius; The econd, when T. Manlius Torquatus, and Attilius Balbus were Conuls: but it was opened again (as many ay) the ame year, and o continued till Augutus. Perhaps Rome's not enjoying peace was not the leat caue of its properity. For in troublous times, mens endeavours commonly are united for the publick afety, but purue private interets in times of peace and idlenee; o hard it is to make true advantage of God's greatet bleings. Augutus firt hut Janus his Temple, Anno ab . C. DXXV after the overthrow of Antonie; Himelf the fifth time, and Sextus Apuleius being Conuls. Four years after he hut it the econd time, M. Junius Silanus being Conul with him. The third time he hut it was about the time of our Saviour CHRIST, the Prince of peace. The next time we read of its being hut, was, when Nero, and Valerius Meala, were Conuls, Anno . C. DCCCXI. which Tacitus and Oroius reckon not, becaue Nero hut it upon no jut grounds. So Suetonius in his life, Janum geminum clauit tam nullo quam reiduo bello; which • aernus readeth, Tanquam nullo reiduo bello: that is, He hut the Temple of Janus, as if there were no ignes of war remaining. The eventh time it was hut (or, more truly, the ixth time) was, Anno . C. DCCCXXIV. Vepaian and Nerva being Conuls. After this time, Hitorians ay nothing concerning the gates of this Temple. Yet Capitolinus in Gordino Juniore, affirmeth, that the cutom till remained. Alexander ab Alexandro lib. 1. c. 14. conceiveth the reaon, why Janus his
Temple was the tetimony of peace and war, was, his being the Pr • ident of the revolutions of times; o his Statue intimated, having on its hands the number of the days of the year figured. As he was figured with two faces, o he had alo two gates, one toward the Eat, the other toward the Wet. Thee Macrobius, Saturn. l. 1. c. 9. ueth for arguments, to prove Ianus the ame with the Sun, according to his deigne. But I rather judge this aroe from Saturn, (by vvhom Time vvas meant) his being perhaps all one vvith Ianus. But Macrobius cap. 7. believeth, Ianus's tvvo faces related to the prudence and care of a Prince, who looketh both on what is pat, and alo on what is to come. Ianus made Saturn partner with him in the Kingdom, for the benefit he received from his intructions about Hu • bandry: And after his death, in honour of him, and in memory of the hip which brought him to Italy, he caued the figure of a hip to be tamped on one ide of his Coine, which on the other had his own Image. Hence came the Game, cùm pueri denarios in ublimi jactantes, CAPITA AUT NAVIA, luu tete vetutatis, exclaman • ; which in our days till remaineth, being now called Croe or Pile. Cap. 9 he telleth this originall tory of the opening of Janus's gates in War; When the War of the Sabines was in favour of their rav • hed Virgins, the Romans hastned to hut the gate at the foot of the Hi ••
Viminalis, (which from the event was after called lanualis) by reaon the enemy was ruhing in that way. After it was hut, it traight opened again of its own accord. Which having hapned twice or thrice, they tood to defend it with Souldiers, becaue they could not hut it: wh • n uddainly there came a report, that on another ide of the City the Romans were bea • er by Tatius: At which, the Romans that defended this gate, affrighted fled. And when the Sabines were breaking in, it is aid, that from the Temple of fanus a violent torrent of hot water isued, and overthrew the preing enemy For this caue in war the gates were always et open, as it were in expectation of uch help, and as repreenting the god himelf going out to their aistance. And this no doubt proved very advantag • ous, for the encouragement of the common people, who are apt enough to believe any, that tell them of a god's going out with them. To this purpoe alo, Servius rela • eth the tory, in Aen. 1. and aith, the reaon of Janus his being figured with two faces, was the confederacy of the
two Princes, Romulus and Tatius. The bet reaon he giveth, as he thinketh himelf, is, That thoe that go to war wih to return. But certainly he is unjut to himelf, having before aid, vel quòd ad bellum ituri debent de pace cogitare, that is, or becaue that thoe that are going to war ought to have their thoughts on peace.
55. Hectorean hore.] That is, Trojane.
58. The Trojan Swain.] Paris, o called, from his having been bred up among hepheards. See Annot. on Book 1 v. 33.
6 • . So roe the strife, &c.] For they fell out, when they were at the marriage of Peleus and Thetis, about a golden Apple cat among them by Dicord.
73. Europe] is here put for Greece.
83. When love, &c.] love ravihed Europa in the hape of a Bull. See Ovid Metam, lib. 2.
87. Aeetes.] The father of Medea, who purued the Argonauts that carried her away in the Ship Argo, which was after made a Contellation.
150, The Macedonian Pile.] See on Book 2. v. 6.
151. Sauromatians,] a people of Scythia, commonly called Tartars.
152. Getans.] See on Book 4. v. 86.

153 Gelonians,] a people alo of Scythia, o called from Gelonus the on of Hercules. They are now comprehended under the name of Tartars. They were wont to paint and dicolour their faces, that they might appear the more terrible in Battle. Hence Virgil calleth them Pictos Gelonos, Geor. 2. They were famous Archers: Hence Horace, lib. 3. od. 4. calleth them pharetratos Gelonos: And Virgil Aen. 8. Sagittiferos Gelonos. They ued, as the Maagetans, to drink Hores blood mingled with milk.

154. Balearian Slingers.] The Baleares are two Ilands belonging to Spain, commonly called Majorica and Minorica. Some hold, they received their name from Baleus, a companion of Hercu • es, there left by him. But rather they were o called < in non-Latin alphabet > , from Slinging: For the inhabitants were very skilfull in the ue of the ling, and bred their children to it. When their children were hungry, they laid their victualls on a high beam, and they were to trike it off with a ling before they had it, Flor. l. 3. c. 8. and Alex. ab Alex. lib. 2. c. 25.
The Greeks formerly called them Gymne • aus, from their cutom of going naked.
177. To fight-with armed fits.] See on Book 1. v. 219.
Oebatian quoits.] This was a weight with a • ing in it, which they ued to throw. At this Exercie Apollo killed his Beloved Hyacynthus. See Alexand. ab Alex. lib. 3. cap. 21.

178. And wretle with oil'd limbs.] I have hewed above; why places of Exercies are called Gymnaia. Thoe that w • et • od were naked, and had their limbs anno •• ted! Thucydides, lib. 1. aith, The Lacedae monians firt intituted Wretling naked, with oyled limbs: but he there affirmeth, that the more antient cutom was to wear Breeches. This exercie was in ueh eteem, that one that was excellent in it was valued as much as the bravet Souldier, Alex. ab Alex. l. 2. c. 25. For which reputation's ake, they ued aiduous-practie before they came to the place: And then, as Clemens Alexandrinus lib. 7. Strom. reluteth, looking on the Starue of Iupiter, they made this prayer to him, If all things, O Iupiter, are rightly. performed by me for the Combat, give • e the deerved Victory.

lg.l: 'TIs not your pow'r, that has inpir'd my mue,
T'were mean to praie that which you corn to ue.
'Tis that above the reach of pow'r in you
I praie, Victorious over Conquet too.
Yet you more truly glorious will appear,
To dipoe Scepters, than you could to wear.
For ravih'r Crowns are till another's due,
But thus betow'd, they are all ow'd to you.
How much your Debtour is our Nation grown,
People their freedome owe, the Prince his Throne.
Brought from his barbarous exile to be Crown'd,
And practice mercy that he never found.
So when the Aeneas o decribed by Virg. lib. 1. Trojan Prince was almot lot
In Storms, among ungentle billows tot,
Dipleaed Neptune from the urges roe;
And torms of frowns among the tempets throws.
At which the waves no longer durt apire,
But to obedient calmnee all retire.
At your approach, phanatique torms o hrink,
And factious waves to eeming quiet ink.

That La •
bert. Wave which to the vatet welling roe,
Found detiny in attempting to oppoe.
Under your weight and principles they unk,
And his unto your brighter Genius hrunk.
So common fires eem to be undone
At the victorious hining of the Sun.
He too that hated King's, jut fate deignes
Should toop to one prung from a Prince's loins.
Yet little does your birth hare with your deeds,
Your Godlike acts, your Princely • ace exceeds.
Whilt you depie thoe long prevailing charms
Of pow'r, ready with its open arms.
So holy men, in heavenly firmnee taid,
Refus'd thoe honor's others would have paid;
T'was uch a Temper only could have brought,
That which we trongly hop't, and weakly ought.
Such conquets as to mighty minds are due,
Sought your embraces; whilt alone for you
So clearly victory it elfe declar'd,
That neither common word, nor fortune har'd.
Whilt we amaz'd your perfect conquet find,
Wrought only by your conduct and your mind.
Their pow'r and fates that you before you aw,
Did not excite your thoughts, nor could they awe:
You took no meaure from their fates or them,
Whilt pow'r and danger you alike contemn;
For their ambitions were not your deignes,
You did not fear their fates, but fear'd their crimes.
Yet by degrees you mov'd, as after Night
The Sun begins to hew the World its light.
At whoe approach, darknee its place reignes,
And though it eems to move not, yet it hines.
So oftly you began to pread your beams,
Through all our factions dark in all extreams.
And though at firt, you carce a motion how'd,
Yet early glory from your actions flow'd.
May you till hine, as now at your full height,
Till you to greater glory pae through fate.
You that a KING a Scepter gave to way,
And taught rebellious Subjects to obey;
